- The two proposed changes to family tax benefit Part B mean that secondary earners in families with a child under 5 will be able to earn $18 600 before losing entitlement to family tax benefit Part B. Families with a child over 5 will be able to earn $14 184 before losing entitlement to family tax benefit Part B.
- The financial cost of the family tax benefit changes is around $14 billion.

The bill also provides further help for those balancing work and family responsibilities by the introduction of a new maternity payment. The new payment of $3000 will be payable as a lump sum to all mothers, regardless of income, from 1 July 2004. The maternity payment will increase to $4000 in July 2006 and $5000 in July 2008.

- The new maternity payment will replace the current (means tested) maternity allowance and the Baby Bonus. The Baby Bonus scheme will be closed to new claims after 30 June 2004 but existing claimants' entitlements will be maintained for up to five years.

- As the new maternity payment will be non-means tested, provisions are included in the bill to ensure that maternity immunisation allowance is not means tested and is payable for all children who meet current immunisation requirements.
- The financial cost of introducing the new maternity payment is $2.5 billion over four years.

The measures contained in this bill will provide significant additional assistance to families. The Government has taken significant steps to improve rewards for working families since coming to office. The measures contained in this bill add to this in a major way. Since 1996, the amount of assistance through family tax benefit Part A and its predecessors will have increased by over 100% in real terms with the inclusion of the additional $600 per child per year provided for in this bill. The measures are also a concrete expression of this Government's commitment to assisting families with their work and family responsibilities. They provide greater choice for families in balancing their work and family responsibilities, through the new universal maternity payment, which will provide extra support for families with a new baby. In addition, the substantial increase in the level of tax-free assistance for families with dependent children in receipt of family tax benefit Part A and the changes to the income threshold and withdrawal rates for family tax benefit Part B will mean that couple families can increase their level of paid work without losing entitlement to benefits.

para.inline: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MORE HELP FOR FAMILIES—ONE-OFF PAYMENTS) BILL 2004

speech.para: The measures contained in this bill and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 represent the largest package of assistance for families ever. The measures will provide very substantial increases in the level of financial support to families with dependent children as well as giving better rewards from paid work. They will help families balance their work and family responsibilities.

The bills underpin the Government's More Help for Families package announced by the Treasurer. This package provides additional assistance for families with dependent children of more than $19.2 billion over 5 years. The 2004-05 Budget measures build on the Government's Family Tax Initiative in 1996 and the increased assistance, which formed part of A New Tax Systemin 2000. Compared to the situation in 1996, total assistance to families from this Government has increased by over $6 billion a year.

However, the measures contained in these bills go further. They provide major increases in assistance to help families raise their children. They provide better rewards from paid work and will help families balance their work and family responsibilities.
This bill will provide three one-off payments that will generally be paid in June 2004.
The first one-off payment, of $600 per child, is to families. Eligibility for the new payment will be linked to:
- receipt of family tax benefit Part A in the Budget for Centrelink instalment customers;
- a confirmed entitlement to family tax benefit Part A in the Budget in respect of the 2002-03 income year for lump sum claimants through the Australian Taxation Office and Centrelink; and
- receipt by parents and nominees of dependent youth allowance for 16 to 17 year old children in the Budget.
The second one-off payment, of $1000, is to recipients of carer payment in the Budget.
The third one-off payment is to recipients of carer allowance in the Budget, payable as an amount of up to $600 for each eligible carer receiver.
These payments will be credited directly to customers' bank accounts without the need for a formal claim process.

In addition, an administrative scheme will be established to pay families who did not meet the criteria already noted for the one-off child payment in the Budget but who subsequently have a confirmed entitlement to family tax benefit Part A for the 2003-04 income year on reconciliation. No one eligible for family tax benefit Part A in the 2003-04 income year will miss out on the lump sum one-off payment.
- Guidelines will be established by the Minister for Family and Community Services to enable payments from this scheme.
- The fund will have a sunset clause of three years.
The bill contains provisions to ensure that the one-off payments will be exempt from tax and will not be included as income for the purposes of the social security law.

As a broad principle, there will be no debts arising from these one-off payments. A debt would only arise in relation to one of the proposed one-off payments where some or all of the payment was incorrectly paid because an individual knowingly made a false or misleading statement or knowingly provided false or misleading information.
The measures included in the first bill demonstrate the Government's firm commitment to assisting families with raising their children and will cost $2.2 billion in 2003-04.

Together with other measures announced in the Budget, the Government has recognised the substantial contribution made by carers in providing care for people with a disability or severe medical condition. The one-off payment to carers will cost $255 million in 2003-04.

talk.start.para: —The Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 flow from the government's budget handed down on Tuesday night and are the work of extraordinary—I stress `extraordinary'—cynicism. For the government to come forward in this way and seek to progress legislation as we have just discussed, with the pace and process that it has, can only alarm many people. I stressed earlier, though, that we support any support getting into the pockets of Australian families as soon as possible but there are going to be countless questions—some of which I will refer to if I get the time in this second reading contribution—and concerns about the application of these bills. That is beyond the broader question, which is: what do the bills really do to solve the problems in the system itself? We know the bills do a minimal amount.

speech.para: Let me start by concentrating on what the bills involve. The Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 contains five elements. Firstly, there is an ongoing payment of $600 annually for each family tax benefit child, to be paid as a lump sum on income reconciliation for the 2003-04 income years and later years. That is the lesson the government learnt from their last election bribe of the $1,000 waiver—people understand that the system rolls on regardless of whether it is an election year or not—and now the government have proposed to pay $600 in the later years as well.

Secondly, the bill involves a reduction in the rate at which family tax benefit part A reduces from the maximum rate to the base rate—from 30c in the dollar to 20c in the dollar. This is a good measure. It is desperately needed by families because the work disincentives involved in women returning to work and the amount of family support they lose in the process has been a significant and growing problem for some time. It is a problem that the Prime Minister has been promising to address for some time but we waited and waited and, as everybody knows, the family benefits barbecue went cold. It is good to see we have a little bit of warmth through this measure.

The next element is a new maternity payment of $3,000 and the phasing out of the baby bonus. Of course everybody knows now, and finally the government cannot pretend not to understand, that the baby bonus was an enormous flop and did not work. This new measure is going to provide significant support for Australian women having children but again I highlight, as I said before, that the last time there was any support for women having children was when Labor introduced the maternity allowance in 1995. The changes that were meant to occur after that to improve that level of support have stagnated under the Howard government until today. Of course we welcome the fact that this measure is now here but highlight that, gee, it has been a long time coming—certainly much longer than the gestation period for a baby.

The fourth element of the first bill is a reduction in the rate at which the family tax benefit part B is withdrawn, from 30c in the dollar to 20c in the dollar—again a good measure, particularly for women returning to work. The fifth element is an increase in the amount of income a secondary earner in a partnered relationship can earn before entitlement to family tax benefit part B is affected, from $1,825 to $4,000 annually. This recognises that many people—because it is men as well as women who are the primary carers of children—do and can earn some small amounts of income to support their family's wellbeing. The punishment that those families have suffered for many years any time they have earned some small amounts of money is finally being loosened just that little bit.

The second of these bills makes provision for the three one-off payments that will be generally paid in June 2004. There will be a one-off payment of $600 per child to families receiving family tax benefit part A, a one-off payment of $1,000 to recipients of carer payments on budget night 2004 and a one-off payment to recipients of carer allowance on budget night, generally payable as an amount of $600 for each person who attracts carer allowance. In all of this there is very little good policy to show for three years of almost endless boasting about how work and family would be a priority. The government's commitment to match Labor's baby care payment is of course welcome. Its limited reforms to the tapers for family tax benefit parts A and B will also benefit some families, and we would never oppose measures, however limited, that put money in the pockets of struggling families. But it must be said again that the bulk of what the government has produced here is just a short-term political fix.

In its eight years in office, the Howard government has failed to protect the financial interests of Australian families. Before the last election the Prime Minister promised his third term would rectify this neglect but those three years have been wasted, as Neil Warren highlighted in the Australian today. Since the introduction of the GST Australian families have wrestled with a family payment system that is deeply flawed and will continue to be deeply flawed. In the three years in which the scheme has operated 1,639,378 overpayments have been issued. Around 600,000—one in three receiving payments—have received a debt each year since the scheme began. Fancy a scheme that manages, year by year, 600,000 debts! Why can't the government fix that? The government in this process has screwed $1.5 billion out of these families, and no advertising campaign is going to fix that. That is an average of $900 per family per year which this system continues to claw back.

It is no wonder the government's backbench have been concerned about this issue, and I am surprised not to hear more grumbling from their backbench about how this fundamental problem has not been fixed. Families will continue to accrue more and more debts. They may get $600 reductions to their debts but they will still accrue debts. The cause of the problem in this system is the requirement that families estimate their income a year in advance. This has not changed. The government has recognised in some areas that this is the fundamental problem in the system but it has not fixed the problem. So families whose incomes fluctuate—and that is most families, a growing number of Australian families—will still run the risk of underestimating their income and they will still accrue a debt.

Think of the example I raised in question time yesterday. A family estimates its income; it has three kids, one of whom is an older teenager at school who decides to take up a job. Whack! And it is not fixed. Whack goes the family budget simply because its child decided to make the transition from school to work. How ludicrous! The reason John Howard is offering families two $600 payments before the election and only one after is that he knows that in the run-up to the election families are going to get debts averaging $900. After the election of course the government will not care that the annual payment will not cover the size of the debts that families accrue. So we have, as I have said, this short-term political fix—a cynical ploy aimed at winning an election that does not meet the long-term financial needs of Australian families.

We know from leaked cabinet documents that the government was provided with a series of work and family policy options almost two years ago. This included the need for a baby care payment, extra child-care places and family payment reforms. We know that the policy work is being done within the department, but John Howard and his government have sat on these proposals. He did not want to spend any money on families until two minutes before he asked them for their vote. Is it any wonder that this sort of material is being leaked? Those public servants who have been concerned about genuine policy interests all this time cannot help but be concerned about the cynicism of a government that sits on the needs of Australian families until two minutes before an election.

Australian families have been left to fend for themselves for three years. The government's refusal to act has prevented serious reform to the family payments system. Having failed to address the cause of the problem, the government must then put a bandaid on the wound in the face of an election. It is important to note that this new payment, contrary to the government tables published in the last day or so, will not be paid as an additional fortnightly entitlement to families. It is a new payment, a tack on, and it is not paid week to week when families need it. The misrepresentation that has occurred in the cameos about families that have been put out by the government is atrocious. To me, the most obvious flaw in them is that, 12 months in advance, they have been trying to convince people that they will get tax relief that simply will not be there. It is one argument that a pro rata $600 payment is added into the yearly rate when most people will end up losing much of it in debt, but to then count forward tax relief that simply will not occur for another 12 months is outrageous.

After eight years, the Howard government has still failed to address the tax and benefit traps that rob families of the reward for their hard work. The changes announced by the government fail to make sufficient inroads into incentives and, disturbingly, effective marginal tax rates will actually increase for families moving from welfare to work. Secondary earners in dual low-income families attempting to move into work will see their effective marginal tax rates increase from 87 per cent to 93 per cent—a six per cent increase due to the stacking of family tax B and the partnered parenting payment tapers. Who did the background work here? The Prime Minister promised to deal with effective marginal tax rates and, in this particular case, they will increase—so much for welfare reform.

Secondary income earners in middle-income families will still not have sufficient reductions. For those with children in child care, marginal tax rates may fall to 100 or 110 per cent from the existing spike of 120 per cent—big deal. To make matters worse, the government's changes are extraordinarily complex. For example, family tax benefit A will now have two withdrawal rates of 20 per cent and 30 per cent. Under the Howard government, almost one million Australians lose more than 60c in each additional dollar they earn. This figure has doubled since 1997 under the Howard government. Three-quarters of those paying high effective marginal tax rates are middle-income families with dependent children. Parents returning to work face effective marginal tax rates of up to 120 per cent after child-care costs are taken into account.

You do not just need to listen to the opposition highlighting these points, many of which get lost in the complexity. A recent study of 30 OECD countries found Australia had some of the worst work incentives in the Western world. Let me repeat that: Australia had some of the worst work incentives in the Western world. I will cite some. Australia has the third worst performance when examining the work incentives for a couple on average earnings with two children. They lost 61.5c in each additional dollar earned—22.4c more than the OECD median. For a single parent on two-thirds average earnings with two children, Australia was dead last. Single parents lose 70c of each additional dollar earned—32.8c more than the OECD median. The Howard government has yet to come to grips with the failure of its tax and transfer payment reform—its announcements last night were a bandaid.

I move to carers. The one-off payment for carers is also a pretty obvious election bribe. We have 2.3 million carers in Australia who provide care for those they love. They make sacrifices to improve the quality of life and to care for another person. Clearly, we as a society should value human life. Carers need a long-term national strategy to help them with the problems faced by taking carer responsibilities and this problem will only grow. Unfortunately, the government's budget only delivers, again, short-term fixes. There is nothing in the budget to help carers combine work and carer responsibilities. There is nothing in the package to help carers' education, training and skills development. There is no extra funding for counselling for carers. Carers, through their efforts, save the community more than $20 billion per year. They deserved that bit more.

Carers contribute to social capital; they build family relationships and help include many disabled and older Australians in the community. They deserve better from this government than an election bribe. John Howard has done nothing for carers in the last three years except leave them prone to savings strategies that his government has finally accepted it should not apply. It has left them at risk wondering where their support was going to go and now, on election eve, they get a bribe. John Howard has saddled thousands of carer payments recipients with large Centrelink debts, which have arisen because of the government's administrative mistakes over the last seven years. He has stripped 30,000 parents caring for children with disabilities of their fortnightly carer allowances. A leaked budget submission showed his minister, Kay Patterson, was planning to cut backdating provisions for carers until Labor exposed what she was up to.

Carers should expect that a re-elected Howard government will revisit these nasty proposals. They should expect work force age payment reforms to involve a reduction in the generosity of their entitlements. I am glad that carers will get this $1,000, but I fear that the Howard government will go about clawing that money back if they are re-elected.

In conclusion, the Howard government has failed to meet the challenge posed by changing family life. The scrapping of its unfair baby bonus and its tinkering with the family tax benefit B show that the government knows that its approach to family policy is deeply flawed and out of step with modern families, who are juggling their jobs and their caring of children and others they love. But the real killer—the government's jarring family payments system—has been left unamended. Families will continue to face the pain of a system that asks the impossible of them—to estimate income a year in advance and then be delivered with a large debt at tax time. We know that $600 will not be enough to sponge up these overpayments. Families who know the system will not buy an election year bribe that cannot deliver what they need most—a stable, accurate payment system when they need it and regular payments when they are caring for a child, not a bandaid that withholds the support they desperately need until the end of the financial year. These families will see the government's budget for what it is—an attempt to buy another term of government.

While we are supporting the bills today, I want to add one caveat. These bills have been brought into the parliament very quickly, and we have had very little time to examine them in detail. To the extent that we are taking the government on trust that there are no hidden clawbacks or tricks in either piece, we reserve our rights in that matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004. With remarkable rapidity, these bills were introduced into the other place yesterday afternoon, giving the Senate less than 24 hours to consider their content. This is yet another example of the government rushing legislation through, as Senator Collins has indicated, with insufficient time for the Senate, in its proper role as the house of review, to accord to this bill the deliberate and reasoned consideration that all legislation deserves.

speech.para: I contrast the unreasonable haste of this bill with the treatment of the Veterans' Entitlements (Clarke Review) Bill 2004, which corrects a longstanding lack of parity in the treatment of war disability pensions by Centrelink and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. That bill arose from a promise by the government in 1996 that it would fix the anomaly. The bill has taken eight years to come to the Senate and regrettably has dropped off the list yet again. However, we have before us now a bill which was only announced to the Australian people 36 hours ago and which is now being rushed through the parliament, giving us little chance to really consider it.

That we are told that the bill contains one-off bonuses for Australians in the very appealing form of a lump sum payment does not automatically make it infallible, as we will demonstrate later. Nor does it justify the bill being railroaded through to reduce its proper scrutiny by the Senate. The Democrats strongly assert that the government's action in gagging the debate on this bill in the House of Representatives yesterday, followed by the insistence that it be given less than cursory attention by the Senate, is a sheer abuse of the parliamentary process. You cannot get a more important issue to the Australian people than help for families. There is an opportunity for us to get better results for the Australian people. If that can be done, the Democrats will do that and will not be bullied by the government into abrogating the role of the Senate.

The Democrats certainly welcome the one-off payment to families of $600 per child and the increase in family payment. At the same time, it is disappointing that the budget offers family assistance to those who need it but offers tax cuts to those who do not. While most families will get around $600 a year, or roughly $11.50 per week, from the passage of the bill, high-income earners get on average an extra $42 per week in tax cuts. At the same time as the government purports to assist families, its failure to introduce paid maternity leave and to adequately fund child care in the budget will override the benefits and incentives the budget delivers to working families through any improvements to the family benefit payments and these one-off bonuses.

What Australian families win today, they risk losing tomorrow. Families with young kids will no doubt find many uses for the one-off payment but the tax cuts mean that in the future they will be hard pressed to pay for the health and education of their children. Of course, not all families will be able to spend the bonus, as they will have to put it towards repaying Centrelink debts they incurred in the problem-fraught family tax benefit income estimate system. We welcome the $600 to be paid to families as a one-off payment. However, it remains that paying the $600 increase next year, only after families have reconciled their family tax benefit, thinly disguises the reality that the unnecessary complexity of the FTB total income estimate system creates an overpayment and the government has done nothing to rectify that complexity. It is, in essence, compulsory deferring of a statutory entitlement, thereby denying families the opportunity to receive the increase when they need it on a weekly basis from 1 July 2004.

The average family tax payment debt is now $900. These are not families who rort the system. For many, the overpayment could not have been prevented, because the change in their circumstances came to them late in the financial year and could never have been anticipated. The fact remains that most of the $1,200 for families provided by these bills will simply be eaten away by the FTB debts. This very much suggests that more fundamental reform of the income test is what is really needed. Regrettably, we were unable to achieve the major legislative amendment that these bills required for that reform in less than 24 hours, as the government is asking us to do today. Nor is it true that all families will benefit to the same degree from the changes announced in the bill. Children get more expensive as they get older, especially in teenage years. The bill does not significantly improve payments for struggling families with older children. A family with a main breadwinner on, say, $30,000 to $40,000 a year with one child under 16 and a 16-year-old on youth allowance loses 68c for every extra dollar when their partner starts work, even with the improved income taper of family tax benefit proposed in this bill. They receive nothing from tax cuts.

Furthermore, in relation to poverty traps, the fact that this government has amended family payments but not youth allowance is also significant, particularly given that youth allowance has a cumulative income test. The Democrats note that the changes to family tax benefit A are positive in bringing in more low- to middle-income earners and families and also providing women who are the secondary earners in a family with greater incentive to choose to take on more paid work. However, we do have concerns that FTB part B is not income tested and can be paid where the primary income is very high. The Democrats are therefore less enthused about the changes to FTB part B than those to FTB part A in these bills and, whilst supporting them today, would suggest that the funding from FTB part B be reallocated in part.

We can further improve taper rates and income tests for family tax benefit and introduce new measures for the jobless as they earn so that low-income people can keep more as they work. Again, the time limits imposed on us in railroading these bills, though, prevent us achieving the necessary amendments. However, we give notice that we will closely examine the impact of the legislation and will seek to amend the primary act at a later date to ensure better targeting.

The bill also provides for bonuses to carers. This is a positive move. For too long now, carers of elderly Australians or those with disabilities have been overlooked. Carers are known as the `silent army', if you like. There are more than 2.5 million carers in Australia, and governments have an obligation to try to meet their unique needs. Carers provide by far the major proportion of both health and community care for people with special needs. Most do so willingly as members of the family or friends and do it for love or duty at a substantial sacrifice to their own life and their own commitments. However, caring often causes stress in financial, practical and emotional terms. For too long, carers have been calling upon the government to recognise their role and to identify key areas of action such as health and social care, information support, young carers and employment. Governments have an obligation to recognise the care that a carer is providing and to listen to the views of the carer in deciding what their requirements are and not to take the carer's contribution for granted.

We Democrats know that it is no exaggeration to say that carers are the backbone of our whole community care system. We simply could not manage without the vital work that they do. The bill, however, while paying them a $1,000 bonus, does nothing to recognise the crucial role of carers as partners in providing care, nor does it give them any more rights and recognition than they have ever had in the past. The Democrats for the most part welcome the changes for carers. While these bills do not fully compensate carers for their work—in fact, they come nowhere near it—the carer bonus of $1,000 or $600, the removal of the coresidency rules for carer allowance, new initiatives for young carers and the recognition of ageing carers who are caring for their sons and daughters with disabilities are all welcome moves.

There is, however, a glaring oversight in the payment of the $1,000 up-front bonus to carers. Certainly carer payment is made to people who provide constant care in the home of the person under care—adults and children with a severe disability or medical condition which requires such care. But there are many people who have a primary entitlement to another social security income support, such as the age pension, disability support pension or parenting payment single, who are providing the same level of care. Because carer payment is paid at the same rate and income test, there has been no advantage to them swapping to carer payment before today, and Centrelink have advised people of that. To make it worse, social security income support recipients who were on carer payment would have been automatically transferred over to the age pension when they reached the age of 65.

This budget changes the `no real advantage' rule because the bonus of $1,000 is now only going to be paid to people on carer payment and not other pensions, notwithstanding that they may be providing equal amounts of care. The end result is that the number of people on carer payment is significantly less than the number of people who are actually providing full-time care to disabled and highly dependent family members or friends but who receive other social security income support. This creates the anomaly that the many carers who receive income support payments other than carer payment from Centrelink will miss out on the $1,000 bonus. They may have identical caring responsibilities but, because Centrelink moved them from carer payment onto the age pension, because they have a child and therefore receive parenting payment or because they have a disability and receive disability support pension, they will not receive the $1,000 bonus.

The carers who miss out on the bonus of $1,000 are the ones who can least afford not to receive it. While not holding up passage of the bill, we Democrats will address this anomaly in the payment system. Our amendment gives a period of about six weeks for people on income support payment to claim carer payment in lieu of their current income support from Centrelink. Provided their claim is lodged before 30 June and they satisfy the caring requirements, they can be granted carer payment, with qualification, backdated to the date of claim and be entitled to receive the bonus. They will not be double-dipping and will not receive two payments, but they will rightly qualify for the bonus.

The Australian Democrats would rather have not imposed on Centrelink these additional administration obligations over less cumbersome measures. However, this was tempered by the government's insistence that this bill be passed today and dealt with quickly. We call on the government to support this with an information program to ensure that information on qualification for carer payment and the bonus is communicated to carers.

Recognition for carers and the government's responsibility do not end with the payment of a $1,000 bonus. For many carers, the lack of respite care available to them means they will struggle to find the time to spend it. The payment of bonuses without addressing the ongoing social, economic, health, education and employment problems and needs experienced by carers is simply one-off welfare and we need to move beyond it.

The Democrats welcome other measures for carers in this bill particularly in providing extra assistance to some particular groups which have been overlooked in the past and did need extra support to carry on caring—although I note that they do not address the fundamental problems of carers that I mentioned earlier. Young people caring for their parents are at most risk of being unable to complete their schooling because of their caring responsibilities. Their eligibility for additional respite during school terms will assist them to remain in education. However, they too will not qualify for the $1,000 bonus.

Likewise, the provision for increased access to respite for carers over the age of 70 is very welcome. But they are a group that will miss out on the $1,000 bonus because they will largely be age pension recipients. My office receives many heartfelt pleas from elderly parents of children with severe disabilities who write out of sheer desperation and who are weary with fatigue but whose commitment to continue caring is resolute. Four weeks a year respite will be welcome, and we call on the government to ensure that this is available to carers in rural and remote regions of Australia. The Democrats welcome this bill and give notice that we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak to the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004, I want to mention the way in which they were rushed into the parliament. The government gagged debate on these bills yesterday in the House of Representatives after debate had just begun. The Minister for Children and Youth Affairs snuck these bills into the House of Representatives without notice on Tuesday night following the budget statement and the government is attempting to push them through both houses of parliament in just two days. It is very odd, given that this government has done nothing to address the enormous levels of stress it has caused families in Australia. It has lumped them with enormous debt for years and then, with the whiff of an election in the air, it is rushing to hand out lump sum payments to make up for the neglect and dismissal of Australian families. The government could have introduced this legislation at any time. It is not as if it did not know about the financial problems that its current system has caused thousands of families in this country.

speech.para: Legislation needs proper and detailed consideration. Community groups need time to scrutinise this legislation to identify whether the bills inadvertently create any new poverty traps. It is clear that the package introduced with these bills is a cynical election stunt, an insult to Australian people who the government believes will not recognise this budget for what it is: a blatant attempt to buy votes in what is set to be a tight election. Certainly the comments that I have been reading today in the letters to newspapers show that Australians are not the dummies the government is expecting them to be. Australians have identified this for the election stunt that it is and for the vote buying exercise that it is.

The government is trying to sell its measures as the `largest package of assistance for families ever', and this is true. The package costs $19.2 billion over five years. It provides three payments. The first one-off payment, of $600 per child, will be paid to families who receive family tax benefit A. The second one-off payment, of $1,000, will go to recipients of the carer payment. The third one-off payment will go to recipients of the carer allowance and will be $600 for each eligible carer. It is not surprising that this government is trying to look generous right now, given the way it has squeezed families throughout the country during its term and given the way it will be happy to continue to squeeze families if it wins the election.

The Greens are obviously not opposed to one-off payments to families and carers. However, we are cynical of the effect that one-off payments can have on struggling families and carers who have ongoing financial challenges. The Greens believe that one-off payments do not represent a genuine commitment on the part of this government to help families in need. The government could assist families by establishing a paid parental leave scheme and if it were genuine this is what it would do. The government could assist the long-term needs of Australian families by investing in public services, by funding child-care places appropriately. It could assist by reversing the neglect of our public services like health and education. It could assist by fixing up the problems in the family tax benefit payment system that result in the family tax benefit debts that families face through no fault of their own. But the government has lost this opportunity and instead is attempting to bribe families with a short-term injection of cash that will provide no lasting relief for families.

The government has failed to deliver the much needed and much called for national paid maternity scheme. The maternity payment that is in this budget is not a maternity leave scheme; it is simply a welfare payment. The point of maternity leave is that a woman is able to maintain her attachment to the work force, receive income for the period of time she is looking after and bonding with her child, and then return to the work force. Unless a scheme ensures a continuing attachment to the work force, Australian women's rights to engage in paid work will continue to be restricted. The government's maternity payment does not ensure a mother's right to return to work, nor does it cover the 16 weeks off work that the World Health Organisation recommends.

In addition, as the federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner has said, a lump sum payment with no requirement to stay out of work means that, for some women, pressure from their employers or financial circumstances will force them to return to work less than 14 weeks after the birth of their child. It is good that the government has finally recognised that the baby bonus was a dud, but it is disappointing that it did not decide to introduce a national paid maternity leave scheme. The Australian Labor Party lowered the bar on this by announcing their own form of maternity payment, rather than a paid maternity leave scheme, some weeks ago. That allowed the government to simply come in and introduce a maternity payment rather than a leave scheme, as that was what Labor had done.

The Greens have developed a paid parental leave scheme that will deliver replacement income to 75 per cent of women for 18 weeks, with a further 34 weeks of unpaid leave, a right to return to work part time and to share the leave period with a partner. This scheme can be funded by redirecting the baby bonus, which the government itself has abandoned in this budget. Australia can afford a scheme of this kind and Australian women deserve it. Until the government provides practical assistance of this kind to families it has no credibility in claiming to support families and women wanting to return to work after the birth of their child. The Greens will be moving a second reading amendment to the increased payments bill calling on the government to introduce a national paid parental leave scheme.

Unmet demand for child care, high fees, and pay levels as low as $12 an hour for child-care workers are major problems the Howard government has failed to address. The drive for private child care will only exacerbate these problems. The Greens welcome the government's provision of more child-care places in this budget, but the places that are provided meet only a quarter of the unmet demand for child-care places.

The long overdue extension to carer allowance is welcome, but it is difficult to see how a one-off payment of either $1,000 or $600 just prior to an election is anything more than attempted election bribery. If carers are so deserving, in the Treasurer's own words, this payment should be ongoing, rather than just one-off. Sara Trad, who after a spinal injury has been confined to a wheelchair and has her daughter as her primary carer, commented in today's Sydney Morning Herald that she believes the Prime Minister is simply trying to buy votes.

The government has belatedly recognised the design flaw in its family payments system which causes one in three families to have a debt each year. The flaw has not been addressed—a $600 payment will not remove the inherent flaw in a system that is creating these debts for families. The budget has missed an opportunity to help people genuinely in need in this country and has been criticised by welfare groups and other advocates for disadvantaged communities in Australia. High-income earners on more than $1,000 a week gain tax cuts of over $21 a week at a cost of $1.9 billion whilst those on low incomes but higher tax levels, unemployed people, gain nothing and still face paying 70c in the dollar on casual earnings through taxation.

There is little equity in this vote targeted, economically irresponsible budget. Once again the government has passed over the opportunity to use a significant surplus to invest in public services. At the same time, single people and families with no children miss out altogether. Young people in particular get nothing from this budget. Few young people earn enough to benefit from the government's tax cuts for the rich. Young people without children get absolutely nothing. The government has again missed the opportunity to extend rent assistance to Austudy recipients, a small cost for the government that would make a big difference to student poverty in this country. At the same time, the government's higher education reforms mean that students are paying more, either now or later, for their university opportunities.

The government claims to be helping families and those in need, but if it were genuine it would invest in public education—in schools and in tertiary education. It would also invest in ensuring that the bulk-billing rate stayed high so that families did not have to fork out huge sums of money when they take their children to the doctor. It would spend money on the environment so that our children would not have to pay for massive and unchecked environmental damage.

This government is not interested in these problems. It is simply interested in winning votes, and that is why we are hurriedly considering these bills today. The government has a record of giving more to the rich and failing to be generous to those who are in genuine need. This budget is no exception to that pattern. The two million eligible families who will receive the $600 lump sum payment before 30 June, at a cost of more than $2 billion, plus another $600 after they have handed in their tax return can clearly see—and they have already commented in the media today—that this is an election bribe being waved in front of them by the government. This government is trying to cover up problems that families have encountered with debt, but payments will not ease the stress that many families have endured due to the failed policy. This payment must be considered an apology as much as anything else.

The budget has been widely acknowledged as a desperate attempt by the government to buy votes. Billions of Australian taxpayer dollars are being utilised by the federal government to buy its way back into government. Whilst the Greens will not oppose more money for families and carers—in fact, we support it—we do object to the underlying strategy and the inability of the government to properly address ongoing policy failures. This pool of money being used to bribe Australians could have achieved a fully funded, free tertiary education system, more teachers and better resources for our public schools. It could have paid for the expansion of Medicare to cover dental services, a boost in bulk-billing and the establishment of new community health centres. These measures would have achieved true and lasting assistance for families.

Instead, schools are struggling, students are being slugged by higher fees, and doctors' fees are rising. Families will continue to suffer as a result of this government's policy failures. This is why the Greens see this budget as an abject failure. On behalf of the Australian Greens, I move the second reading amendment standing in my name:

quote.para: At the end of the motion, add:
“but the Senate:

speech.para: (a) condemns the Commonwealth Govern-ment for ensuring that Australia is one of only two Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries that does not have a national paid maternity leave scheme; and
(b) calls on the Commonwealth Govern-ment to implement immediately a national system of paid maternity leave”.

talk.start.para: —I begin, as have several colleagues—including Senator Brian Greig on behalf of the Democrats—in this debate on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 and the related bill by expressing my concern about this process. As honourable senators have indicated, there is no lack of desire among people in this place to provide urgent need to Australian workers and Australian families, and no-one seeks to hold up that process. However, it is a sad day for the Senate when we have legislation that is a couple of days old at least, has not been properly scrutinised and yet is expected to be passed by the Senate with minimal discussion and debate.

speech.para: Despite the temptation to refer generally to the budget in my contribution to this second reading debate, I will restrict my comments to that part of the bill that relates to the maternity payment, which—having looked at the legislation in some more detail for pretty much the first time, as would be the case for most of us in this place—I have discovered is not a maternity payment. I thought we were paying $3,000 to mothers upon the birth of a child, but we are not. It is a primary carer payment. So it is $3,000 when a child is born. If I am wrong, I am happy for advisers to correct me. But we are only just getting information from the Parliamentary Library and from departmental officials about this legislation before us, and these are the questions that we in this place should properly scrutinise not in the second reading, not simply in the committee stage of the bill, but in a committee—this is the kind of bill that should be referred to a committee. We are talking about billions of dollars—and this debate is expected to wrap up by 12.45.

So the primary care giver will get $3,000 on the birth of a child. I understand there is sufficient discretion in this bill so that this money can be paid to the most appropriate person. I want to know what security there is in this legislation for women who are in difficult, maybe violent, relationships. I want to know what protections there are for casual female workers. There is nothing in this bill that makes this into a maternity payment, or even a maternity leave payment; that seeks to end what we have dealt with in Australia up until now—that is, the systematic discrimination against women in the work force who decide to have a child. There is nothing to protect casual workers by saying, `You don't have to go straight back to work.' There is nothing to ensure in those cases—and I acknowledge this is an extreme—where women are in relationships that may be abusive or violent that that money goes directly to the women. These are the kinds of questions that we have every right to ask about and have solid responses to before we vote on this law.

I resent the implication—and it is not an implication, because it has been said pretty categorically in this place today to senators who dared to question the exemption from the cut-off provision—that we somehow do not want Australian families to get their money, that we do not want working women to get their money. That is offensive. It is particularly offensive to me as a senator—in fact, I believe I am the only senator in this place to have done it—who has tabled a private member's bill that would legislate for a system of national, government funded paid maternity leave for a minimum of 14 weeks, which is the ILO standard, and that would do so at the minimum wage. That would total around $6,400 per woman over 14 weeks, which would go some way to providing income replacement for most Australian working women.

This $3,000 payment does not go anywhere near that. It is not even half the minimum wage. It is not designed as income replacement—and nor does the government pretend it is so; I acknowledge that—but it is not a payment that will assist those current two-thirds of Australia's working women who get zip, those women who get nothing if they decide to have a child. Indeed, they are faced with choices—confronted, more so—to give up work to look after the child or to give up time with the child after birth, in which case that ILO recommended biological time, that imperative time that women may want or need to spend with their child after the birth of a child, is not available to them. Many women have to work to earn money so that they can support their families, and that specifically includes sole parent families headed by a woman who is working.

There is also the choice as to whether or not you go back to work too early. I have put this on record before, I know, but I am going to say it again: in the Senate committee inquiry into my legislation we did hear horror stories of women who did go back to work too quickly after the birth of a child. It was two weeks after the birth in one case of a women who had a caesarean. We are talking about women who are usually at the lower end of the pay scale and working in lower skilled work environments where they do not have access to paid maternity leave.

For too long Australia has not had access to a system of paid maternity leave. We are one of only two OECD countries—and, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, I acknowledge the second reading amendment from Senator Nettle; she knows it will appeal to me because I have been prattling on about this issue for years—that do not have a system of paid maternity leave. What is the other? The United States. As Naomi Wolf said, I think somewhat flippantly, in a forum on this issue in Australia last year, sometimes she thinks the US exists just to make all the others look good. But on this one the US and Australia are in glorious coalition—not the UK, who have 26 weeks; not our near neighbours New Zealand, who have an appropriate scheme.

This goes to the heart of another problem with the legislation before us today and the `maternity payment'—that is, how it is administered. This has been dealt with as a welfare payment, as a social security payment, as a family payment. It is not considered to be a workplace entitlement. So the challenge is now on for the Labor Party, for Mark Latham and his new beaut opposition, to come up with paid maternity leave, not baby care payments, not one-off payments—and not necessarily means tested, I might say, because that is where the government has got it right. The government has not discriminated—it has provided for universality in this payment. It is for all women who decide to have a child, and thus for all working women who decide to have a child. But the challenge is on. Why doesn't Labor bite the bullet and actually come up with paid maternity leave? What are the major political parties so scared of here? Are they scared that women are going to go back to work, that they are going to maintain their careers, that they are not going to recreate some 1950s paradise that some members of the cabinet might actually emulate and want to emulate in today's society? That is what it is about: some aspects of this budget are social conservatism at its worst.

Two-thirds of Australia's working women have no access to paid maternity leave, and this bill does not do much to fix that. While $3,000 is welcome—and no-one ever sniffs at $3,000; no-one is dismissing it as `milkshake' or `hamburger' amounts of money—for working women with a HECS debt, their increased by 25 per cent HECS debt is more than this $3,000. Because of the income forgone, the lack of assistance they will get with their superannuation—because this is administered as a social security payment, not as a workplace entitlement—and the fact that women still have no real choices in relation to children and work, this is not good enough.

It is a token payment and the government know it. In the lead-up to an election campaign, it is about short-term effort, short-term gain, short-term votes. It is not about long-term sustainability. It is not about keeping up with the rest of the world. It is not about providing real opportunities for women or real opportunities for families. To say that workers will be able to better balance their work and family responsibilities is rhetoric. This has not been sufficiently addressed in this budget and the government know it. They have done the best that they thought they could get away with in order to win votes. They have done the best that they thought they could get away with with child care in order to get votes. And I suppose Australians are cynical enough to expect nothing less.

We had a great opportunity. You have had the longest policy gestation period in the history of Australia with paid maternity leave. You have had one of the most comprehensive fully costed reports from the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward. You have costings that tell you you could do it for around $215 million a year or $352 million a year, depending on what you do with your baby bonus—and I do welcome the government's decision to scrap that ill-targeted, regressive scheme. It is not going to break the bank and it will make a real impact on people's lives. It will make a real impact on women's lives and on the choices that they have.

Economically speaking, why do you think groups like the AIG or the Hotels Association are willing to consider the notion of government funded national paid maternity leave? It is because economically it has benefits, because increasingly women are employees and because increasingly people want to retain those more productive employees. They do not want to have to retrain others, to take new workers on. That is why it makes sense to maintain your work force, particularly in female dominated industries. That is why organisations like Esprit have such modern and progressive paid maternity leave systems. But they are the exception. Qantas, Westpac, Pacific Brands—they are the exceptions to the rule. They are the bigger ones that can afford it. They are also the more enlightened ones.

It is the two-thirds of working women who get zip whom I have been concerned about. In 2001 I took an idea to the campaign. In 2002 I tabled legislation. It is 2004, and we have not really progressed much in this debate at all. The government will get its benefits through today. Its legislation will pass. It will do so with minimal scrutiny because the Senate has exempted it from the cut-off provision. There is no time for analysis in the broader community. It will not go to a Senate committee, as legislation both this complex and this expensive should. It will be passed by the Senate, probably with minimal debate in the committee stage today except for the efforts of my colleague Senator Brian Greig, who has moved amendments.

Once again, this is not paid maternity leave. It is not even a maternity payment. It is not going to meet the objectives of paid maternity leave—that is, to financially support a new mother prior to and post the birth for at least 14 weeks to deal with the recovery period from childbirth, to bond with the child and to establish breastfeeding patterns. Paid maternity leave is, and should be, a workplace entitlement. It seeks to address disadvantage and inequality in the work force, and it is likely to actually encourage work force attachment—as much by the legitimacy it gives working women as by the financial incentive it offers.

The Democrats have long argued in the context of this debate—and I am sure all senators in this place and members of the community would agree—that motherhood is a valuable and important role. We believe that women who choose to stay at home and have a child should have that work recognised. It should be acknowledged. They should be able to do it in a way that is well resourced. Similarly, Australia's working women should be able to choose to have a child and not feel forced to give up income or their employment. A form of systematic discrimination exists in our society against women in the work force who choose to have a child. We all know the stories. Many of them may not tell their employers that they are of child-rearing age, that they are pregnant, that they are going to get married or that they are going to have kids. Many of them when they do have a child feel that they cannot take time off work. We know all these stories and yet we are not doing anything realistically or meaningfully to address those issues.

I await responses from the minister in relation to the payment going to the primary carer. Does the legislation offer any protection to women who are forced to go back to work? The payment, as I understand the legislation today, can be split between parents. I talked about the degree of discretion. I wonder what guidelines are going to be provided in relation to that payment. It is up to the secretary—is that the case? Are we not going to put any more specifics in law? Are we going to get a chance to debate it any further before we pass this law? Are casual employees being forced to return to work to keep their jobs? What protections are there? I understand that there are workplace protections in industrial relations law but, given that this has not been considered a workplace entitlement, I wonder how that will interact. I have mentioned my concerns about households where the payment is not going to the woman but perhaps should be.

While we welcome this token attempt to address the issue of work and family—that barbecue stopper we have been hearing about since 2001 that was the priority of John Howard's third term of office—I am not sure why it has taken this long to get it onto the agenda properly and I am not sure why the legislation is to be dealt with within 48 hours through a guillotine process in the House of Representatives and now what amounts to an implicit guillotine in this place too. I welcome the scrapping of the baby bonus but I am sad that this is the best that working men and women are being dealt. I am sad that we are expected to feel grateful because it is better than nothing when every other OECD country bar us and the US has got it right and has understood the needs of working women. I can only argue that there is a social and a conservative agenda there that is much more sinister.

In the interim I have to take at face value the legislation hastily presented. It will not be analysed properly and it will not be scrutinised in the way we expect the Senate to scrutinise legislation, and I record my and my party's disappointment at that fact. I look forward to the coming campaign. I am sure that there will be cynical members of the community out there but also desperate members of the community who will have to take this payment and accept it as the best thing to alleviate some of their financial and other difficulties. But please remember that this is not paid maternity leave and it is not even a maternity payment in the context in which I think it was initially presented.

talk.start.para: —The two bills that we are rushing through this chamber today, the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004, are an integral part of the government's work and family package. They have the worthy aim of helping to ease the burden on struggling Australian families. They mean that most families with children will get an immediate one-off payment of $600 for each child and as well the basic family tax benefit will be increased by $600, paid at the end of each financial year. Obviously, these are measures that this chamber is not going to stand in the way of, nor will it stand in the way of new mothers getting a $3,000 maternity payment that rises to $5,000 in 2008.

speech.para: This package should be supported but there are better ways, I would argue very strongly, of supporting parents, particularly mothers and women who want to remain in the work force or to maintain their links with the work force particularly for promotional purposes. There are better ways: through paid maternity leave and by looking again at child care to assess how long day care is structured and how it is actually planned. We have a system at the moment of basically leaving it to the market and we have some areas in which there are several centres, none of them really viable, and other areas crying out for some planned approach to long day care. We should have been looking at how the actual payments are made, because it is very difficult for many parents who are working shiftwork out of hours to find long day care at all. But, this is the package that we have before us.

It is a package primarily targeted at a family on average wages: two young children and a wife working part time. But when we move to some other parts of the budget and we tip the tax cuts into the mix and look at who benefits we see that those who benefit most are very much families in the middle- to high-income range, particularly those around the $60,000 mark who typically live in certain electorates that are going to be highly contested in the coming federal election. As we look at the budget more broadly we see that many Australians miss out altogether. Students get nothing. There is a long list, and that simply is not fair. This package as a whole—in total—is not fair. There is a yawning gap and that is the government's neglect of those individuals and families who are on low wages or indeed do not have a job and are struggling to get back into, or indeed into, the work force. I would argue that this is not just unfair but also short-sighted.

Those who miss out on this spending spree are really those who most need support and some assistance. Those on less than $52,000 gain very little, particularly if they are unmarried or without children, despite some positives such as further encouragement to increase savings through superannuation. But the budget does very little, if anything, for the unemployed and it does nothing for the homeless. Where are the funds for public housing? Where are the funds for public transport? Why is the desperately needed money for public schools tied up? So, along with the generosity which we may see in this package, some would argue we have inequity.

This budget is a missed opportunity to use the growth dividend from a strong economy to build a fairer and more equal Australia. Health in the budget is just a matter of changing a few details with a couple of announcements. The new medical school for the University of Western Sydney is certainly welcome but there was so much more that could and should have been done. The budget could have been so different. The financial opportunity was certainly there, and I remember the Treasurer talking about the need to address the intergenerational inequities of the ageing population. I do not want to suggest here that we should simply be putting more money in to pay off public debt but I had hoped to see some really major steps towards restructuring our whole system so that it is prepared to meet the needs of an ageing population. The money for aged care is certainly a positive but there are so many bits and pieces that we are still not addressing, such as the need for dental care for all older Australians. Money allocated to carers, particularly through this measure here, is very welcome but, unfortunately, children who are carers still have the issue of the 20 hours. If they do go to school, they have all sorts of pressures on them and we have to excuse them from that limit of 20 hours of study or indeed study and part-time work before they lose their allowances.

I will quickly look at the $5.3 billion Backing Australia's Ability II package. This is welcome but the emphasis it puts on industry orientated research and commercialisation is a real weak link. We must be looking at the declining level of investment in public research—that is, research for public benefit or that may not be able to be commercialised, particularly in the short term, for example research into cleaner fuels and encouragement of our solar industry and wind generation—and we should be encouraging investment in universities' core research. Australia's investment in R&D currently sits at 1.55 per cent of GDP and over the long term we need to see that moving closer to the international target of two per cent and, preferably by 2020, rising to the target of three per cent.

This weak link also means that Australia will continue to slip further behind in creating an innovative knowledge economy and further behind in new energy research and development—and that does not bode well for our future. Repairing the Murray-Darling Basin is an urgent and high priority. There is virtually nothing for that in this budget. There is a failure to address the need to repair, rebuild and renew Australia's collapsing social and economic infrastructure. Yes, there is something for roads but for rail there is very little. As we look down the list, we see nothing for public housing and we still have telecommunications with a very low basic standard. We should be working to get Australians the Internet, not as a luxury but as an absolutely basic standard. I argue this is very short-sighted. All of this will leave us in the long term with devastating consequences, particularly for the Murray-Darling Basin.

In quickly closing my remarks, given the limited time we have for this debate as the government wants this legislation through in some 47 minutes, all I will say is that if we do not do something very quickly for the Murray-Darling Basin it will be too late. There is nothing here in this budget, despite what we had hoped, to buy back overallocated water. There is no commitment and no structure as to how and where we are going to get 100 gigalitres of water a year for the next 10 years so that the river can have some chance of surviving. There is no institutional mechanism put in place to recover the water and nothing about enabling farmers to provide environmental services instead of, for example, trying to run stock on the Chowilla wetland, which is simply a dustbowl. What we need is a change in attitude by this government and state governments and no more words about upgrades that are supposed to leave the public feeling that something is happening, because upgrades actually mean less water in the river as farmers become more efficient. It is absolutely indefensible that state governments are on-selling water from upgrades to be used elsewhere while the river dies. The real blindness in this budget is the failure to move beyond short-term politics and on to the long-term good of this country. It is the lack of long-term planning and strategic thinking to ensure that all Australians benefit from what is a strong economy and what is a lucky country. But, then, the short-sightedness and the short-term planning can be explained by the fact that it is an election year.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I rise to close the debate on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 bill. I do not need to go through in detail the various measures in the bills. They are very clearly set out in the second reading speech. However, I would like to respond to a couple of things that were said.

speech.para: Senator Collins made a comment that 30,000 carers of children who were receiving a payment for a disability before were no longer receiving the allowance. Because this is a figure that keeps being bandied around, I want to put something on the public record. Yes, 30,000 carers are no longer receiving the allowance but 6,500 people contacted Centrelink and advised that they were no longer eligible for the carer allowance under the new assessment tools. They said that their children would not have qualified under the assessment tool. The assessment tool is about the level of disability. I can remember years ago having a discussion with Senator Richardson when he was the minister for social security and the government of the day was trying to find a way of objectively assessing a disability. Eight thousand and six hundred people did not respond to the review. Centrelink wrote three times to customers and telephoned those customers who had not responded to the correspondence. So half those people no longer receiving the allowance had basically self-selected out of the allowance.

Of the remainder, almost 7,000 customers are entitled to a health care card although they are not eligible for a carer allowance. That was a measure that Senator Newman brought in by going and talking to the people in the social security office. I was with her when she did this. She said, `If you were minister for a day what would you do?' One of the people at the coalface—and again I commend those people who work in Centrelink offices day in and day out facing the public and working with them—said that people were coming in to get an allowance because their child had asthma, and they were trying to get a health care card to get free puffers. They said that we would reduce the number of people on carer allowance if we gave people with children with serious asthma a health care card. So, 7,000 of those customers are eligible for a health care card. The bald facts of 30,000 people not receiving an allowance for a child with a disability needs to be outlined in that way.

Senator Stott Despoja asked about the maternity payment. It is very similar to the maternity allowance. The maternity payment goes primarily to the mother, and that is the case with the maternity allowance, but there are some cases where it can go to the primary carer. I have just been talking to the department and the sort of case where the secretary would use his or her discretion would be where a child has gone into the custody of the relevant state protection authority, for example, or—and sadly it happens—where a mother may have become permanently incapacitated because of either a car accident or something occurring during birth and is unable to make a decision or is not of sound mind in the sense that she can make decisions. They would be extreme examples. If you made it a law that it was payable to the mother you could not deal with that. There would be some situations where you would say that the allowance could be paid to the father. I know a case exactly like this where the mother had a massive stroke and was totally incapacitated. The child was delivered and the mother was not even capable of knowing the baby had been born. They are the extreme circumstances where you would expect that the secretary would have the discretion to make the payment to the primary carer. I believe that that is what happens with maternity allowance now: it goes to the mother but there are some extreme cases. I hope that answers Senator Stott Despoja's question.

Senator Nettle said that there was nothing in this budget for young people. Senator Nettle is very young; she does not remember when interest rates were 17 per cent or when inflation was running at some astronomical number and the unemployment percentage was a double-digit figure. The best thing this government has done for young people—and this is one of the reasons I got into politics; to make sure that kids had the sorts of opportunities I had when I left school under a Liberal government—was to relieve them of $96 billion in debt. We are now saving almost $6 billion on interest that we were paying on Labor's debt. That was the legacy we were leaving the young people of Australia under Labor. I know Senator Nettle is young; she has not experienced what it is like to try to buy a house under Labor with high interest rates, high inflation and high unemployment. We have done a lot for young people and the most important thing we have done is to ensure that when they have a family they will get significant increases in assistance through child care, family allowance and other benefits like the Medicare safety net. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I want to make some brief comments in relation to the second reading amendment. Whilst Labor have some empathy with what is expressed in relation to this amendment, there are some aspects in relation to the national paid maternity leave scheme that I think deserve some comment from the Labor Party. Professor Peter McDonald, in a letter to the editor in today's Australian,highlighted that some of the criticism about the baby care payment or the maternity payment, as it is now proposed, is not actually getting a number of the points. For instance, earlier today Senator Stott Despoja raised a number of issues—and I think Senator Nettle did also—about access to leave.

speech.para: Historically in Australia, leave arrangements have generally been determined through the industrial relations system and, indeed, through the award system. I can recall a time, for instance, when awards provided or imposed periods of leave on women who had had children. I can recall a debate over whether it was appropriate for an award to require that women not work for the period six weeks before birth and six weeks after birth—and certainly I agree that women should be encouraged to take what time they can to bond with, care for and establish breastfeeding with a child—but there were a number of problems with how that might work in application. Ultimately the issue is that it should be the choice of the parents. For instance, I returned to work in this place well before six weeks after my children's birth—and I think there are many things we could do to the way this place functions to make it a bit more family friendly as well. But a blanket requirement that, during a 16-week or 14-week period, women should not work is not necessarily going to solve the issues or the problems for many women.

talk.start.para: —Who is saying that?
—What was said in the debate, Senator Stott Despoja, was that the bill itself did not introduce leave requirements—did not deal with the leave that women should take.
—I was not talking about that.

—You may not have, but Senator Nettle referred to this issue. There was a suggestion that the deficiency in the proposal for the baby care payment was that it did not deal with leave and ensuring that leave was taken. I am just trying to bring to the attention of the chamber that the issue of leave is fraught with a number of other issues that have been dealt with historically and need to be taken into account. I do not see this bill or this payment as the mechanism that should deal with the leave issue. Pru Goward has also raised the leave issue. I think that there are more adequate ways to deal with empowering women in the choices they make about the care of young children.

speech.para: The other issue raised that concerned me was the suggestion that Labor's proposals here—and, indeed, the government's proposals here—do not meet the appropriate objectives. I want to quash that reference as well. When Labor introduced the maternity allowance in 1995, we researched very carefully what would be required for Australia to meet our international obligations. What was required at that point in time was 14 weeks of minimum income support. We introduced seven weeks and promised in the next term in government to introduce the next seven. This would have brought us up to meeting the ILO maternity protection requirements. Fortunately these proposals are far more generous. In addition, they reflect the fact that, unlike many other OECD countries, our social security system has been different for many years.

Our proposals also reflect the fact that for many women it is artificial to say that they are women in the work force. Working patterns of Australian women are such that they move in and out of the work force. This is what the baby care payment or the maternity payment deals with. There will not be artificial divisions about mothers. They will get access to support if they are caring for a newborn, and that is what should occur. Any suggestion that that is not going to meet our international obligations or the international standards in this area is simply false. This is the main reason that I have concerns with this second reading amendment. This payment will meet our international obligations and Labor's baby care payment ahead of it—for which, I am glad, there is now bipartisan support—will also do so. For that reason, we cannot support the second reading amendment.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a short statement on the comments made on the second reading amendment.
—I am prepared to give leave if it is a very short statement.

—I want to respond to the comments that Senator Collins made.
