The Greens' concern with the maternity payment, both from the government and from the ALP, is that it is not a leave scheme that has an entitlement to return to work. That is what our concern is about. In the United Kingdom, for example, the onus is on the employer to say why the woman cannot return to part-time work. That return to work component is not a part of the welfare payment that has been proposed, either the baby care payment or the maternity payment in this budget. So our concern is that it is not a leave scheme with a return to work entitlement component to it. In terms of the international standards that Senator Collins referred to, I made reference in my contribution to the second reading debate to the 16 weeks recommended by the World Health Organisation, which relates to breastfeeding for women. Neither of these payments meet that World Health Organisation standard.

speech.para: Question put:

motion.para: That the amendment (Senator Nettle's) be agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Original question agreed to.
Bills read a second time.

para.inline: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MORE HELP FOR FAMILIES—ONE-OFF PAYMENTS) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I move Democrat amendment (1) on sheet 4224:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 2, item 1, page 12 (line 14), omit “11 May 2004”, substitute “any date between 11 May and 30 June 2004”.

speech.para: As we have argued, there are many carers out there caring 24 hours a day seven days a week for an adult, a child or children with a severe disability or a medical condition who, as a result of the budget announcement, will be expecting to receive the $1,000 up-front bonus to carers. They do not receive carer payment because they have an entitlement to a Centrelink income support payment in their own right, such as an age pension, a disability support pension or a parenting payment. When they took on their carer duties they would have been rightly advised by Centrelink not to claim the carer payment because there was an advantage to not doing so and because when they reached age pension age they would have been transferred off carer payment to an age pension. But the degree of care they provide is no less than those receiving a carer payment.

The legislation before us changed the no-advantage rule because the bonus of $1,000 is now only going to be paid to people on the carer payment, not to people on other pensions, notwithstanding that they may be providing equal amounts of care. This bill creates the anomaly that the many carers who receive income support payment other than carer payments from Centrelink will miss out on the $1,000 bonus. The carers who miss out on the bonus of $1,000 are the ones who can least afford to not receive it. It is simply not fair that to qualify for the $1,000 carer bonus, a carer has to receive carer payment; nor are we satisfied that this group can be guaranteed to be encompassed under the administrative scheme in schedule 3 of the bill by discretion of the minister.

The Democrat amendment before us gives people in receipt of income support payment until 30 June 2004 to claim carer payment in lieu of their current income support from Centrelink. Provided their claim is lodged before 30 June and they satisfy the caring requirements, they can be granted carer payment, with qualification backdated to the date of the claim, and be entitled to receive the bonus. They will not be double dipping and will not receive two payments, but they will rightly qualify for the bonus. It will be open to them to revert to their original income support payment at any later time.

We regret that this will cause significant impost on carers in having to go through the claim process and also that it will cause an administrative impost on Centrelink; however the blame for that rests solely with the government in not thinking the consequences of this bill through, together with the speed with which they have insisted it proceed through the parliament. Put simply, our amendments will ensure that all people with the same caring obligations and whose act of caring significantly relieves the government from funding institutionalised care equally receive the $1,000 bonus.

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity to add my own comments to the consideration of this bill. I had anticipated doing this in the second reading debate but I will take the opportunity to speak at the committee stage of this bill. Really it goes to the heart of the inequity of the proposals before us—the fact that anyone earning under $52,000 a year effectively misses out. I noted with great interest, as I am sure every Australian woman did this morning, that the Prime Minister had been using the wrong figures with respect to the average weekly earnings of women working full time, saying that the figure was $49,000. That in fact is not the case; that is the average figure for all working people. The average full-time figure for women in Australia is $43,550. That is a long way from $52,000, and the fact that it is so far from $52,000 destroys completely the implication by the Prime Minister and others in the coalition that somehow more women would access the benefits of some of these packages than actually will be the case.

speech.para: What it does do and what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Jenny Macklin, has been very quick and smart to point out is that this just underlines the fundamental inequity. If we go further and look at the average weekly earnings of all working women, the figure is down to $30,305 per annum—a very long way from $52,000. So what we have here is not only a budget designed specifically to put some money in the mail in the lead-up to the next election—as far from a plan for the future as you could possibly imagine—but also the government trying very hard to give the misleading impression that this budget will support women in a way that it actually will not.

One of the most offensive parts of this is that, whilst promoting this budget as a budget for families, it is a budget that promotes greater inequity in our society. It has been the Labor Party that has put families back on the agenda, after months and even years of shallow rhetoric from the coalition government and a thin promise of focus on family to come. We have ended up at this point in time, in the lead-up to the next election, with nothing more than a big bribe, a throwing of money that will not solve the fundamental problems that the Labor Party knows exist in our communities. These problems relate to access to Medicare, to bulk-billing and to those weekly bills that come in every time you have a sick child or are sick yourself. It is about public education and the need for greater investment in public education and putting a priority back on public education in Australia. That is what parents are looking for. They are looking for community and government services that really address their day-to-day lives.

I know my own portfolio areas of sport, arts and culture provide that social glue that people look for. Was there anything in the budget to do with community development in these areas? No. What about the rhetoric associated with participation in physical activity and the focus on childhood obesity? We have heard a lot from the government about that, and the Sports Commission has stuck their head above the parapet finally and said a few words about the issue. Was there anything in the budget about that? No. There is nothing about the social infrastructure of Australia. What we have are inequities that will be further entrenched. I will leave my comments there because I am conscious of the time. Obviously I will have a lot more to say about these issues as the other budget bills proceed through the Senate at a later time.

talk.start.para: —We are sympathetic to the intention behind the Democrat amendment. Clearly, there are long-term carers who are still caring but who are on other payments, such as the age pension, who will miss out on the $1,000. However, we think that the government should offer these families this payment. They should not recognise only some carers and not others. But they could do this administratively—indeed, if the government were prepared to support this amendment, we would not have an issue. However, we think that the Democrat amendment is not the best way to achieve this, despite its noble aim.

speech.para: On that point, I would also highlight that this is not the only issue of people missing out that has been raised with me. It is not only a carer allowance issue. I have correspondence in relation to maternity allowance and adopted children highlighting some of the problems there as well. There are probably a whole series of these issues that could be addressed and fit more into the gamut of my earlier contribution about why we were supporting the cut-off. We will not be supporting this amendment because, whilst it is worthy in itself, it addresses one issue and there are probably thousands. We think that in future the government might be convinced to act on them, as they can, administratively.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I want to thank Senator Collins for her contribution to the debate about maternity leave and the maternity payment. I want to add that the maternity payment is non-taxable and it is not included in income for social security purposes. That should be on the record. The amendment that the Democrats have put forward has the effect of extending the opportunity for anybody to apply for carer payment who may not have previously been in receipt of carer payment. If the Democrat amendment is intended to cover those people who have lodged a claim prior to the budget announcement of 11 May or who have advised Centrelink of their intention to claim, then they are covered by the existing legislation and therefore would be eligible for the budget measures.

speech.para: If the intention of the Democrat amendment is to allow people to think about their eligibility after the budget night, then this sets a precedent that is not really desirable for any legislation where we have a set start date. There will always be the issue of cut-off points—it has been the case with other bonuses. Not to have it because there are problems and not to share with carers the dividends of having run the economy well would be unfair. Whenever you have a payment of any sort where you have a cut-off point, whether phased or not, there will always be some people who are on one side of the cut-off point or on the other. We will not be supporting the Democrat amendment. I would, however, like to say that I know that there are a lot of people who would have liked to speak and also people who would have liked to speak for longer. I know Senator Lundy cut her speech short and Senator Hutchins did not speak. I want to put on the record my appreciation as minister for the cooperation of the chamber in facilitating the passage of the legislation.

talk.start.para: —The minister in an earlier contribution said, I think, that those who miss out on the $1,000 bonus on this occasion will nonetheless be eligible for respite. I want to check with the minister that, while that is true, it is only quarantined to those people who are aged 70 or more and who are caring for someone with a disability. While it would apply to some people, it is by no means equitable and comprehensive.

—Senator Greig may be waiting for a response from the minister but I am going to quickly add to that. Firstly, I thank the minister for answering my earlier question from my second reading contribution. My understanding is that it is policy that the payment goes to the woman but it is not law. Secondly—and I accept that this may become a question on notice, given the timing—has the government done any investigative work on or looked into the issue of casual workers who may be forced to return to work: that is, women who are casual workers who, as you know, would not have access to unpaid leave in relation to the birth of a child? Has the government looked at the implications for those casual workers who are forced to return to work? That is an issue that I ask the government to take on notice. Thirdly and lastly, my understanding is that the payment can be split between parents. My understanding is that that is up to the secretary. There are no guidelines in the legislation for dealing with the circumstances in which that occurs. Is that the case?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —With regard to the carer respite, that is for people who are caring for a profoundly disabled son or daughter, irrespective of the benefit they are on. It is about working with the states to give those people over 70 the guarantee of four weeks respite. I would like to see the states—because we are giving them such a huge injection—taking on their responsibility. I was quite disturbed when I went to Western Australia and saw a 76-year-old woman caring for her daughter at home and also caring for a person who was in accommodation but still seeing the daughter on a very regular basis.

speech.para: We made a decision with the Commonwealth-state agreement that the states would look after accommodation and we would look after employment services. We injected $131 million into employment services in the last budget and we have injected about $99 million in this budget and now, I think, another $73 million in an area where we do not take responsibility. We are saying to the states, `We'll give you a leg-up; now give these carers a break.' They will be eligible. It is about older carers with profoundly disabled young people whom they have looked after for a long time. We need to put pressure on the states. As Senator Greig is a senator from Western Australia, he could hopefully make a bit of noise over there about what Western Australia needs to do about the accommodation of older disabled people who are currently being cared for by older carers. They are eligible for that respite.

With respect to the other question about casual work and whether women are being forced back into casual work, I do not have that information to hand. I do not know whether the department has. If it has, I will make sure that Senator Stott Despoja has it. The only thing I would say is that Senator Collins made the point that to require people to have leave could equally be a disincentive to give people jobs. I will find out whether we have any research on that area.

I think I have answered the questions I was asked. With regard to the issue about the secretary, the secretary has the discretion now. One of the problems is that, if you start defining the situations in which the secretary can use that discretion, you cannot always imagine the various things that could happen. Sometimes what can happen to families and babies is beyond our comprehension. I think this would occur very rarely, but I think it is appropriate to give the discretion to the secretary to use their judgment—secretaries are usually very objective people; I have never found one who was not—when there is a situation which we might not have even forecast. Sometimes you can be too prescriptive. I know Senator Stott Despoja is concerned about people being manipulated or being in a situation where they feel they have to share their benefit—

talk.start.para: —This is slightly different, this one.
—Don't shout across the chamber. I will sit down, and if you can say it in a minute we might be finished by a quarter to one.

—I was actually facilitating the minister. I was just going to say that, except in this circumstance, it is a slightly different part of the legislation, where the payment is split between parents. My concern related to the earlier provision, as to who it was paid for. I had a very simple question: are there guidelines on whether that payment could be split? I am conscious of what has happened with the maternity payment, and I understand the basis on which that has been done before. I just wanted to know if there was any decision to have specific guidelines, and you have answered my question.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —There were no guidelines in the legislation, of course, but I have not had any complaints about the way the maternity payment has been dealt with. If there have been any decisions, I would think they were very rare. One of the questions we could ask in estimates committee hearings, after a 12-month period, is how many decisions the secretary has made. That would be a legitimate question to ask—most probably not under the circumstances, because there might be too few, but if it was thought there were only two or three or 10. If they became excessive, one might have to look at it again.

speech.para: Question negatived.
Bill agreed to.

para.inline: FAMILY ASSISTANCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MORE HELP FOR FAMILIES—INCREASED PAYMENTS) BILL 2004

speech.para: Bill—by leave—taken as whole.
Bill agreed to.

Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004 and Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 reported without amendment; report adopted.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That these bills be now read a third time.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I wish to take the opportunity, at the conclusion of this debate, to emphasise a few key points on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—Increased Payments) Bill 2004 and the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (More Help for Families—One-off Payments) Bill 2004. It has to be said again that this is a massive amount of public money that is being rushed through both houses of parliament in absolutely record time, and that is not something the Democrats support. Yesterday this legislation was gagged through the House of Representatives, with no debate. The Senate does not gag bills, thankfully. On very rare occasions we guillotine bills: senators have only a set amount of time, and when the clock is stopped the vote has to be put. I guess you could call this process a civilised guillotine. We do not actually move a motion; we just have people frowning at us a lot and generally muttering and being very unhappy if we do not have the bill passed in the time frame that the government desires.

speech.para: It is clearly the will of the majority of the Senate that this legislation pass today. Everybody here knows that it would be quite simple for me to just keep speaking for another three minutes, and we would not have a vote on it. I trust that there is an acknowledgment of our cooperation in our not requiring this to be put to guillotine. I would not want that to be interpreted as anything other than our being very cooperative, but it should not disguise the fact that we are extremely dissatisfied and unhappy that this is happening.

The one amendment the Democrats moved went to a core issue of one of these bills—a one-off payment to people on carer payments. Although obviously welcome and obviously supported, it is not a payment that goes to all people who provide care at the level that would qualify them for a carer payment. Many people who provide the same level of care as carers are on other payments. Indeed, they are encouraged to be on other payments, such as age or disability pensions. They provide just as much care, and they have exactly the same social and personal needs and financial pressures, yet currently they only get the same payment. They miss out. It is not just a matter of saying, `We can't share the dividend with everybody.' There is a qualifying criterion. It is being said that people who provide this level of care get the one-off payment, but that is not accurate. Our amendment was an attempt to address that inaccuracy, that dishonesty. It was obviously not supported and barely acknowledged.

That is one anomaly and, as Senator Collins said, there are probably thousands. The Senate is engaged in a dereliction of duty by allowing this legislation to go through without proper scrutiny. I do not know if there would be thousands of anomalies, but there certainly would be a lot more than one. There is gross dishonesty in how the various components of these bills are being represented to the public. That is not satisfactory. It is the Senate falling short of what we were elected to do. It is of concern that, because there is an election possibly coming up and people are looking to clear the decks, a whole range of legislation could be ignored as the government goes back to a small target strategy. It can pick its electoral strategy, but we have to do the job in the Senate that we were elected to do. We have not done it in this case, and the Democrats are very dissatisfied with that.
Question agreed to.
Bills read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Senator PATTERSON (Victoria—Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women) (12.45 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the intervening business be postponed until after consideration of government business order of the day no. 5 (Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 2004).

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 is an essentially non-controversial bill which makes minor amendments to some 22 different pieces of legislation. The Democrats do not oppose these amendments. However, there is one amendment which I would like to comment briefly on this afternoon, and that is the proposed amendment to the Evidence Act. The Evidence Act currently provides that evidence may be given outside of Australia by an Australian diplomatic officer. The bill extends this to include locally engaged consular officers. While this amendment is not contentious in itself, it reminds me of a recent issue involving an Australian citizen who is currently imprisoned in the United States, namely Mr Kirk Pinner. I have spoken about this case previously in this place. In fact, in the course of a debate on a previous bill, I asked the Minister for Justice and Customs a series of questions about that particular case. Although he undertook to provide answers to my questions, the minister has not yet responded.

speech.para: Mr Pinner's case involved an issue about Australian consular personnel providing evidence regarding Australian citizens. Mr Pinner was charged with a criminal offence, a charge which he denied. He remained in the United States on bail for a considerable time after being charged. Mr Pinner claims he was subsequently advised by Australian consular personnel that he would not receive a fair trial within the US justice system and that he should return to Australia. That allegation is denied by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. However, an Australian consular office in the US did issue a new passport to Mr Pinner and he returned home to Tasmania, breaching his bail. The minister for justice subsequently authorised Mr Pinner's extradition to the US to face trial. The Attorney-General's Department informs me that more Australians are extradited to the United States each year than to any other nation in the world. In the lead-up to Mr Pinner's case, the prosecution indicated that it wished to subpoena a consular officer, Mr Brian Brook, to testify against Mr Pinner during the trial. The Democrats expressed our concern that this would be contrary to the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, which protects consular officers from being compelled to provide evidence.

Quite apart from the legalities of the issue, the Democrats' primary concern relates to the interests of Australians travelling abroad. The whole purpose of Australian consular offices in other countries is to provide assistance and to protect the interests of Australian citizens. If Australian consular officers are permitted to provide evidence against Australian citizens, how can that purpose be properly fulfilled? How can Australian citizens have any confidence that, when they seek assistance from an Australian consular office, their interests will not subsequently be compromised by the very people who are supposed to assist them? We Democrats believe this is an issue of some serious concern and one that needs to be clarified and, if necessary, addressed for the benefit of all Australians who travel overseas.

I note that Mr Pinner, following his recent trial in the US, has been convicted and sentenced to a period of imprisonment. We Democrats understand that there is some uncertainty as to whether Mr Pinner will be transferred back to Australia to serve out that prison sentence here and, indeed, whether his sentence of imprisonment will take into account the time he spent in custody in Tasmania prior to his extradition to the United States. I take this opportunity on behalf of the Democrats to call on the government to ensure that Mr Pinner is brought home to Australia to serve out his sentence close to his family—including his parents; his partner, Tracey; and his son—in Tasmania.

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I thank senators for their comments on the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. The bill is an important piece of legislation that will amend 22 acts and thereby neaten the statute books considerably. The bill amends legislation to improve the efficiencies of a variety of court, tribunal and diplomatic and consular functions and to align their procedures with standard practices. The bill also removes typographical errors and makes minor consequential amendments that were not made on previous occasions. It clarifies the operation of certain provisions and removes references to legislation and organisations that are no longer in operation or have been renamed. I commend the bill to the Senate.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debateinfo.title: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004 makes two changes to Australia's classification regime. Firstly, it will require computer games to be classified in the same way as films according to the same classification categories that apply to films. The Democrats welcome this change but we do not believe it goes quite far enough. We support the move towards a more uniform classification regime. It makes sense to have the same classification names for different genres. This will simplify the classification regime and make it more easily understood by the general public.

speech.para: While there are some mandatory age restrictions that apply to classifications such as MA, R and X, the other classifications are advisory only. The whole purpose of those classifications is to enable people to make informed choices about what they or their children watch, so it is vital that the community is familiar with the names of each of the classifications and what they mean. I believe that the Australian community is now fairly familiar with the classifications which apply to film and television. But why restrict these classifications to film and television only? This bill goes some way to addressing this issue by extending film classifications to computer games. The Democrats support this extension of the classification regime.

The constant advances in computer technology mean that we now have games that are essentially interactive films. It makes sense to subject this genre to the same classification as television and film. When choosing computer games people should be able to take the classification of those games into account. This is, of course, particularly important for parents and guardians concerned about their young children.

But the point that the Democrats would particularly like to make is this: why stop at computer games? Why hasn't this extension of the classification regime been applied to publications as well? If people can make informed decisions about what films or television programs they choose to watch or what computer games they choose to buy and play, why shouldn't they also be given the opportunity to make informed choices about what books they choose to read? Perhaps the minister or the parliamentary secretary can indicate whether the government has perhaps considered moving towards a uniform classification regime for all genres including books and, if not, why not? Why is this bill restricted to computer games only?

The second aspect of this bill is to make some minor amendments to the names of classification types. These changes are intended to highlight the distinction between advisory classifications which are advisory and those such as MA, R and X which incorporate mandatory age restrictions. The bill seeks to change the names of these mandatory classifications to MA 15+, R 18+ and X 18+ respectively. Other classifications, namely, G, PG and M, will remain unchanged. The Democrats do not oppose this change. We note that it does not involve any change to the scope of these classifications. The classifications which will have their names changed already involved mandatory age restrictions and they will continue to have them after the enactment of this bill. What the bill does is simply change the names of those classifications so that they reflect these age restrictions. Again, this change will help individuals make informed decisions about what they choose to watch. Notwithstanding our concerns, as indicated by the questions I have raised with the secretary, the Democrats will support this legislation.

talk.start.para: —I note that the main effect of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004 will be to ensure common classification types for films and computer games to assist people to have a deeper and more understandable system of classification. This will be achieved by adopting the film classifications. On the surface that seems to be a good idea and pretty well accepted round the traps. There have been questions asked about these matters of the department over a period of time. But, upon examination, it turns out to be a turn for the worse if certain things do not occur. This would be both because the film classification system is flawed and because the nature of computer games is such that they allow repetitive and reinforcing actions. The repetitive nature of computer games can reinforce violent images and actions. There is enough violence in the place without more. This means that computer games should have stronger classification standards and not weaker ones. There cannot be such a thing as an R+ computer game, and as for the other classifications I will deal with those at the committee stage.

speech.para: Senators may be aware that late last year state, territory and Commonwealth ministers changed the 1996 film classification guidelines to what the Attorney-General told me, as a result of estimates questions, is `simplified and streamlined' so they can be `more workable and transparent' about the tests the board must apply. In short, there is a plain English set of guidelines, which I have in my hand. I first started to worry about the new guidelines last year when my plain English reading of them told me that the substance and meaning of the guidelines had in fact changed. But I was told that if I interpreted these supposedly plain English guidelines correctly that was not the case.

Later in November of last year the state, territory and Commonwealth censorship ministers issued a communique in which they stated their agreement to change classification laws to `better inform the community about strong material in films and computer games'. Unfortunately, that commitment has already been brought into question. Rather than better informing the community about film content, changes in classification laws have led to a liberalisation in the censorship and a great deal of confusion about what the standards are.
Early last year the Attorney-General's Department informed me that the R classification, amongst others, had recently been changed to the new streamlined format. I was assured:

quote.para: The general rule will ensure that there is no change in classification standards in the R category.

speech.para: In explanation of one of the `more workable and transparent' tests the department told me:

quote.para: Sexual activity may be realistically simulated. The general rule is: simulated, yes; the real thing, no.

speech.para: You would think that that would be a fairly easy test to apply. The 1996 guidelines state:

quote.para: Sexual violence may only be implied and should not be detailed.

speech.para: The new streamlined 2003 guidelines state:

quote.para: Sexual violence may be implied, if justified by context.

speech.para: A significant change, I would have thought, in allowing violent content, but I was assured that there was no practical change. Last year the Classification Board approved the screening of a film called Irreversible. The Classification Board notes:

quote.para: This film includes a brief depiction of actual fellatio.

speech.para: But the rule `simulation, yes; the real thing, no' was not applied and the film was allowed a classification of R. The Classification Board also noted the impact of an anal rape scene in the film, stating:

quote.para: The impact of this anal rape scene is high due to the lengthy real-time depiction, with a considerable amount of verbal and visual detail.

speech.para: Again, an effective change has been made to the classification guidelines, despite the assurances of the department, to allow a film with a horribly violent, lengthy and detailed scene into the R classification. Sexual violence depicted in the film was indeed detailed and went beyond being implied. This is very disconcerting when we are faced time and time again with violent sexual crimes. The type of material that can be allowed—given the experience with the film Irreversible—is material containing a substantial degree of sexual violence. The Attorney-General has assured community organisations that he was `confident that the combined guidelines do not change the classification standards that were applied under the previous film guidelines'. We now know that that is not the case.

I acknowledge that computer games will not be allowed if they have a classification higher than MA, but the value of the exercise has to be called into question when the film classification system is so discredited. Computer games are by their very nature different from films. Playing computer games is an interactive activity, while watching a film is a passive activity. Computer games can reinforce a violent message, as the player can undertake a simulated violent act multiple times in order to perfect it and succeed in the game or simply because there is the opportunity.

Computer games are constantly being made more realistic in their depiction of the virtual world. It is quite natural that undertaking repetitive simulated violence has the effect of dulling the revulsion we naturally feel towards violence. It can help to create and then to reinforce an attitude more accepting of violence. That is why computer games are very different from films and should be treated as such. I know that there are provisions in the code which talk about certain things to be taken into consideration, but this is a subjective judgment. I believe that the system is such that material which was disallowed under the 1996 guidelines in certain circumstances is obviously allowed now, even though there is great concern in the community about the level of violence in the community.

I was very interested in what some of my colleagues in the House of Representatives said. I understand their statements, and I hope that their confidence in what is occurring with this legislation and what is occurring in general is seen to be worth while. My colleagues in the House of Representatives saw fit to deal with this legislation, which is designed to ensure common classification types for films and computer games to assist people in recognising the particular classification. That is fine, and I understand why they praised the legislation, but once they see some of the problems that are emerging as a result of the decisions that have been made by the Classification Board they should take a look at them. They should look particularly at the example that I gave and ask these questions: why did this take place? Why does it appear, on the face of it, that this film would not have got through with the classification that it got under the previous guidelines? Those questions have not been answered. There are a number of other things that I want to raise, but I do not want to keep the chamber. I would require a committee stage debate to deal with those matters.

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 2004. I will deal with Senator Greig's comments in a moment, and I am happy to attempt to answer the questions that Senator Harradine has raised. This bill makes a number of amendments to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. The bill merely renames the existing classification types and does not affect the criteria used to classify films and computer games.

speech.para: The bill will improve the operation of the national classification scheme in two ways. First, the amendments will implement common classification types for films and computer games. Research indicates a low level of awareness of computer games classifications, at 43 per cent; and a high level of awareness of film classifications, at 97 per cent. By using the same classifications for films and computer games we will substantially increase the ability of parents in particular to chose computer games for their children. Second, the bill will create a more effective distinction between the advisory and legally restricted classifications. There is substantial difference in the material permissible between the advisory and restricted classifications. The bill creates a clear distinction between these classifications through the inclusion of age references in the names of the restricted classifications only.

The amendments will be of great assistance to consumers, particularly parents, in making informed choices about the appropriateness of film and computer games for themselves and their families. The omission of the schedule to the act does not affect the legal status of the National Classification Code, which under section 6 of the act is the code approved by ministers and published in the Gazette. The version of the code in the act is obsolete. The removal of the schedule which contains the obsolete version of the code will enhance the readability of the legislation and remove the risk of confusion caused by the current situation. Amendments to state and territory classification enforcement legislation will closely follow the passage of this bill. Consequential changes to the National Classification Code have been agreed in principle by censorship ministers and will be formalised prior to the bill's commencement.

I will briefly deal with the matters raised by Senator Greig. His first point was that this bill does not go far enough. Under the national classification scheme all substantive policy matters are agreed by Commonwealth, state and territory censorship ministers and, in the case of legislation, by relevant parliaments. Ministers have not considered the application of the film classifications to publications, although Senator Greig's suggestion is worthy of further consideration and the government will seek to raise this issue with ministers. If ministers agree to pursue this matter, appropriate consultation will need to precede any legislative amendment.

I will move to some of the matters raised by Senator Harradine. The bill does not affect the content of the classifications in the guidelines for the classification of film and computer games. The guidelines will be reprinted prior to the commencement of the bill, as the reference to old classification categories will need to be removed. With regard to interactivity and computer games, issues of interactivity are dealt with in the guidelines themselves and include such matters as repetition. The longstanding direction from censorship ministers that computer games are to be assessed more strictly due to their interactivity is unchanged and is given effect through the guidelines. Pages 4 and 5 of the guidelines discuss the assessment of impact. Page 5 specifically states: `Impact may be higher where a scene ... encourages interactivity.' This part of the guidelines has the effect that, in classifying a computer game, the board must take into account interactivity. Because in practice interactivity most frequently arises in the context of computer games, the outcome is that games are classified more strictly.

The notion that films and computer games should have different classifications because of interactivity is misguided. Interactivity is not of itself a sufficient reason for distinguishing between the two products. Parents want a simple and more easily understood classification system. Common classifications for films and computer games address this issue. As I have already said, research indicates a low level of awareness of the computer games classification scheme and a high level of awareness of the film classification scheme. By using the same classifications for films and computer games we will substantially increase the ability of parents in particular to choose computer games for their children. We believe this greater understanding by consumers of the classifications for computer games, combined with the specific references to interactivity in the guidelines and the provision of appropriate information and protection, will enable them to make informed choices about computer games for themselves and their families.

Senator Harradine also made some specific comments about the film Irreversible. The Classification Board and the Classification Review Board are independent statutory bodies that classify films, computer games and certain publications under the national classification scheme. The boards are selected to be broadly representative, as far as possible, of the Australian community. When classifying films or computer games, the Classification Board uses the criteria in the National Classification Code and in the Guidelines for the Classification of Films and Computer Games.

The Classification Review Board was established under the Classification Act to provide an independent and transparent mechanism for merits based review of decisions of the classification board. In making its decision to classify Irreversible,the board considered the criteria in the Classification Act, the National Classification Code and the Guidelines for the Classification of Films and Computer Games. As I said, the act requires the board to be broadly representative of the Australian community. The board noted that `the themes of rape, revenge and violence are portrayed and dealt with in such a way that they may be offensive to some sections of the adult community but were not offensive to the extent that the film warrants refused classification'.
I understand that Senator Harradine wants to take the bill to the committee stage, but at this stage I will commend the bill to the Senate.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I have a question in relation to the last matter of the board being the authority and everything being transparent. As I understand it, a request is made to the federal AttorneyGeneral by a state attorneygeneral about the classification of a film. What is the role of the federal AttorneyGeneral? For example, I understand that the South Australian AttorneyGeneral has, in respect of the film Irreversible,made a request to the federal AttorneyGeneral. Could the parliamentary secretary advise the committee as to what stage that has reached and what is happening to that request?

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —Yes, you are quite right, Senator Harradine, the AttorneyGeneral from South Australia did write to the federal AttorneyGeneral. The statement on this matter and the classification of the review board was that they would not have made a different decision. The AttorneyGeneral at the Australian government level has written back to the South Australian AttorneyGeneral asking him whether he wishes to proceed further with the matter, and as yet we have not received a response.

—What is the attitude of the Commonwealth AttorneyGeneral with respect to this matter? Here is a matter that has been raised by a number of people concerned with not only the fact that this has occurred but the precedent that it sets. We have all been concerned about sexual violence, for example. How can it be explained away that the guidelines in 1996 stated `Sexual violence may only be implied and should not be detailed' whereas the new guidelines state that `sexual violence may be implied, if justified by the context'. That is a significant change, which has allowed for rather lengthy depictions of sexual violence in the film Irreversible. Surely the AttorneyGeneral must have a view of the matter. I do not know whether this change occurred under the previous AttorneyGeneral or the current one—presumably it was the previous AttorneyGeneral. What is the current AttorneyGeneral's view of the matter?

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —As I indicated to Senator Harradine, we are at present awaiting a response from the South Australian AttorneyGeneral. If the AttorneyGeneral in South Australia wishes to have a review, the review will proceed. The Attorney has considered his own power to have a review. At this stage he does not intend to have a review of his own volition; he will await the response from the South Australian AttorneyGeneral.

—I cannot take the matter any further than that. I go to another question, which I think the parliamentary secretary answered in her second reading speech, concerning item 15 of the schedule. The explanatory memorandum states:

quote.para: This item repeals the Schedule to the Act which contains an out-of-date version of the National Classification Code.

speech.para: I have a couple of questions: if it contains an outdated version of the National Classification Code, an up-to-date version of the Classification Code could be incorporated in this legislation. Why not do it that way so that the National Classification Code is included in the legislation? Furthermore, if this legislation goes through unamended—and I understand that you cannot have an outdated classification code remaining in the legislation; the simple way to do it would be to put the up-to-date code in there—and there are amendments to the National Classification Code, what is the legal effect of the National Classification Code not being in this legislation? How will amendments to the National Classification Code be dealt with? Will they be dealt with by gazettal or by amendment to the legislation? Could we have some clarification on that before we vote for the excision of the National Classification Code from the legislation?

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —As I have already indicated to Senator Harradine, the code is the code that is approved by ministers. It is changed by ministers, it is published in the Gazette and it can change at any time.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Senator TROETH (Victoria—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry) (1.24 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.25 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Coonan, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Why do all the cameos in the budget document More help for families show an individual or couple on zero private income per annum as receiving an increased assistance of $500 per year in the form of a government superannuation co-contribution? How can a person on a private income of zero per annum find $1,000 per annum to pay into superannuation so that they can receive the government's superannuation co-contribution? Isn't this an example of budget paper deception?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sherry for the question. I would vouch for the correct position in the budget papers. What Senator Sherry's question has asked me to address is the entitlement of those people to the new superannuation co-contribution measure that the government announced as part of the budget. In Tuesday's budget the government announced a very significant expansion of the current super co-contribution scheme. The government will in fact provide a boost to retirement savings of $2.1 billion to the co-contribution for low- to middle-income earners over four years to enhance the already creative and imaginative co-contribution scheme that was introduced in the previous budget. The government will now contribute $1.50 for every $1 of voluntary personal contributions to a maximum of $1,500 for those on incomes up to $28,000. It does not have to be $1,000. This seems to be something that is being peddled around by the Labor Party—that, in order to get the maximum contribution, you have to put in $1,000. That is not the case. In fact, you can put in any amount that could be managed, up to $1,000—$5, if you like, spare change from the shopping. Any amount that someone can manage will be matched by $1.50 from the government—up from $1.

answer.para: So it is a contribution that has been extended. The superannuation co-contribution tapers for those on incomes from $28,000 up to an income level of $58,000, so it has also been extended, from $40,000 to $58,000. It is fairly and squarely targeted at low- to middle-income earners who will have an opportunity to get a very generous co-contribution for any voluntary amount that they can save. It is a significant expansion of the contribution, which will ensure that many more people are eligible. Of course, it depends on attitude and it depends on take-up. All of those things are subject to people seeing our wonderful ads on co-contribution which encourage people to save whatever they can for their retirement. It will provide further incentives for those on low and middle incomes to contribute to super, and it is a very real way to boost retirement savings.

There are some very interesting examples of just how successful the co-contribution could be. There is a very interesting example under the expanded super co-contribution. A young person entering the work force who earns $25,000 and makes an additional personal contribution of $1,000 will receive a maximum co-contribution of $1,500 and, whether it is $5 a week or change from the weekly shopping, someone on $25,000 will receive $1.50 from the government for every $1 they personally contribute up to the $1,500 limit. This will actually mean that if an individual continues to make the maximum personal contributions over their working life, their retirement balance is projected to increase by $106,000—that is, an 86 per cent improvement. It is very interesting because, if you look at what Labor have suggested they might do for people in this category and reduce the contributions tax, the benefit to them would be only $3,000. So it is a pretty significant difference. Labor's policy will cost over $1 billion a year and not deliver the same benefits. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the minister's attention to my question, which related to the budget document which shows that individuals or couples with zero income are assuming assistance of $500. How can a person with zero income contribute $1,000 if they do not have any income? If it is not a deception, what are the assumptions made about the take-up rate by people on a zero income that are contained in those costings that she has referred to? How many Australians on a zero income will be able to contribute $1,000 to attract the $500 benefit that the government has illustrated in its own budget document?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —What Senator Sherry overlooks is the fact that people can have very sporadic incomes. They can go in and out of the work force. At some point, they might have a zero income and at some other point they might actually have some income. As long as they have some employment at some stage, they can make a contribution. They might have savings from some other purpose. That is not to say that you have to have any additional voluntary contribution that you have earned. You might have savings from some other purpose. The actual budget papers I would vouch for, Senator Sherry. They are correct.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Will the minister inform the Senate of the importance of meeting priority expenditure and still maintaining budget surpluses? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches to funding new policies that would affect these outcomes?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for that question. I think the success of our budget released on Tuesday has been our ability to produce significant tax cuts and other benefits for Australian families and keep the budget in surplus, something Labor just failed to do. The benefits we are providing are responsible and they are fully funded. We welcome the opposition's support for the family package in the Senate. That means that it will become law and the benefits can start flowing to Australian families.

answer.para: I do note with some scepticism that Labor will not only support our full tax cuts and family payments but say that they are going to deliver even more tax cuts aimed at those on incomes of less than $50,000 who, of course, received tax cuts from us in the year 2000 despite the opposition of the Labor Party. So we do look forward to the opposition leader's budget reply tonight when he can tell us how big these additional tax cuts he proposes are and how he is going to pay for them. The problem for Mr Latham and the Labor Party is that they have already made a large number of unfunded spending promises before they come to explain how now they are going to pay for even more tax cuts.

As I said on Tuesday, the spending commitments already made by the Labor Party, before tonight's reply, amount to over $11 billion. As I mentioned on Tuesday also, there are conflicting and contradictory claims from Labor spokesmen on how they are going to find the savings to offset this spending which they say they will fully offset. We have had figures of $6 billion from Mr Latham, $7 billion from Mr McMullan and $8 billion from Mr Crean. They cannot agree on what the savings are, so we have had a bit of a look at what the savings are that they are claiming.

Their health policy is meant to be funded in part by opposing the reform of international tax arrangements, saving $270 million. Those savings have disappeared, because the reforms are implemented. Labor now say they are going to support our policy on that, so the saving is gone. They said they were going to fund their superannuation policy by opposing the first stage of our surcharge reduction. That policy has been implemented. Labor now say they are going to support that as well, so another $700 million has been lost from their list of savings.

They said they would oppose our policy of providing choice of superannuation to public servants, saving $780 million. In the face of opposition from the Senate, we have now abandoned that policy and taken those savings out of the forward estimates. So, again, those savings have been lost to the Labor Party. They said they would fund $160 million of their higher education policy by opposing tax concessions for foreign workers. Again, we have had to abandon that policy in the face of opposition from the Senate, so the money is no longer in the forward estimates and that saving is simply not available to the opposition to claim. They said they would save $75 million by merging the ABA and the Australian Communications Authority. We have announced that merger, and the merger does not save any money, not least because the ACA works on a cost recovery basis. So there is no saving there.

It is no wonder the Labor Party cannot agree on the level of their own savings—their costings are riddled with illusory savings and double-counting errors, as I have highlighted. The list that I have just listed today and other false savings we have identified amount to at least $2.7 billion of claimed ALP savings that simply do not exist. So before the opposition leader gets up tonight and announces even more new spending and tax-cutting policies, he does need to come clean on what the real ALP savings are and how they are going to pay for this enormous list of unfunded commitments already made.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to Senator Coonan, Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Why do all the cameos in the budget document More Help for Families show an individual or couple who will receive the full increased assistance of $500 per year in the form of a government superannuation co-contribution without making an offsetting adjustment for the resulting reduction in the disposable income of $1,000 per year which must be paid to qualify for the $500? Isn't this yet another deception?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —What I would say, Senator Sherry, because I do not actually have the Treasury figures in front of me, is that I would vouch for them that they would be correct. I would think, quite frankly, that Senator Sherry should be the last person to be questioning figures, given his $8 billion super blooper and his inability to even understand which index to use in Labor's announcement of super policy. However, having said that, what in fact it does show is that the government's policy in relation to superannuation is one that is going to deliver significant benefits to Australians, a further $2.7 billion over the forward estimates to not only deal with co-contribution and low- to middle-income earners but also reduce the surcharge—which is an important initiative of this government—over the forward estimates so that those who can perhaps save more for their retirement will be encouraged to do so. It is a much more targeted policy than any other policy that will not allow and encourage people to take up some of these benefits that the government wants to offer to them. The co-contribution, which is particularly exercising Senator Sherry, shows some very interesting things, if you look at the cameos.
—You've got them there. Answer the question.

—I have got them in a brief. An eligible person on $25,000 will receive a maximum government co-contribution of $1,500 if they contribute $1,000. Over 30 years, the member's real accumulation balance is projected to increase by $106,000. That is an improvement of 86 per cent. It is $103,000 more than such a contributor would receive if the contributions tax were reduced by two per cent, which seems to be about the best that Labor offers—we will see what they do tonight. Similarly, an eligible person on $36,000 will receive a maximum government co-contribution of $1,100 if they contribute $733. Over 30 years, the member's real accumulation balance is projected to increase by $51,000. That is an improvement of 28 per cent. It is $46,500 more than they would receive under Labor's proposed two per cent reduction of contributions tax, which only delivers a $4,500 improvement.

answer.para: An eligible baby boomer earning $40,000, with existing super of $50,000, will receive a maximum co-contribution of $900 if they contribute $600. Over 15 years to retirement, the member's real accumulation balance is projected to increase by $18,000. That is an improvement of 11 per cent. It is $16,300 more than they would receive under Labor's proposed two per cent reduction in contributions tax, which delivers a measly $1,700 improvement. So I am delighted, so long as Senator Sherry wants to draw my attention and the Senate's attention to cameos, to repeat that this government's co-contribution measure will deliver overwhelming benefits for Australians, particularly targeted at low- to middle-income families.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has failed to address the question I asked in relation to cameos which illustrate an increase in a benefit of $500 per year and include this in higher annual and weekly additional benefit without deducting the cost of the co-contribution to the individual of $1,000 a year, or $19.23 per week. Perhaps they could pay the $1,000 by deferring their land tax bill. Minister, I again ask: isn't this just another outright deception?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The only outright deception that we have seen in the Senate is an $8 billion blooper perpetrated by super blooper—a promise to the Australian people that would cost $8 billion that Labor did not bother to mention when they announced their policy.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Abetz. Will the minister advise the Senate of budget measures designed to help small business, which is the engine of jobs growth? Are these benefits to small business an example of proper management of taxpayers' money by the Howard government? Is the minister aware of any examples where governments have not used taxpayers' money wisely?

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Senator Brandis is right to identify small business as the backbone of this country and the engine room for employment growth. That is why the Howard government is so unapologetically pro small business. This budget delivers yet again for small business. Seven hundred and forty thousand small businesses with an annual turnover of less than $50,000 will now be able to choose to pay and report GST annually instead of quarterly. This will reduce compliance and provide a cash flow benefit. Let us not forget that, like the rest of the community, small business owners will benefit from the significant tax cuts and the increased family tax benefits. This will be an important boost, particularly to sole traders and partnerships, and reaffirms our commitment to providing better opportunities for families in small businesses. I am also pleased to inform the Senate about changes we have introduced to the wine equalisation tax—
—Order, Senator Faulkner! There is too much noise on my left.

—which will benefit some 90 per cent of winemakers across Australia. Mr President, in our own home state of Tasmania this will include 165 out of the 168 wineries like Freycinet and Meadowbank. Senator Brandis also asked me if I was aware of poor use of taxpayers' funds. One example springs to mind. Labor's Centenary House rental rort rip-off will cost Australian taxpayers more than $4 million over the next financial year and $36 million over the life of the lease. Mr Latham talks about a ladder of opportunity. Centenary House looks more like a larder of opportunism.

answer.para: Opposition senators—Ho ho ho!

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will come to order.

—For those who might not remember, in 1993 the Labor government agreed to a 15-year lease of Labor owned Centenary House with an unprecedented annual nine per cent ratchet clause. Over the life of the lease, taxpayers will be forced to pay Labor $36 million above market rates. That is not just $36 million in total; that is $36 million above market rates. It cannot be forgotten that the lease has a clause that allows it to be extended and that Mr Latham has refused to give an assurance that the lease would not be renewed if Labor were to win office.

answer.para: Tonight Mr Latham has the opportunity to give that assurance in his budget response. Tonight he has the opportunity to apologise for Labor's rental rort and unequivocally state that a future Labor government would not renew the Centenary House lease. Tonight he can state that Labor will immediately renegotiate the existing lease to fair and proper market rates. Tonight he can state that Labor will repay the $18 million it has already ripped out of taxpayers' pockets. On the back of that, Mr Latham could tonight announce an extra 2,880 hip replacements or 2,600 new nursing home beds. Remember, Centenary House is 100 per cent owned by Labor and Mr Latham is the Labor leader. So this problem could be fixed by one simple phone call. But that would require integrity, leadership and backbone. As Labor delivers its budget response tonight, Australians should take note of what Labor does in office, not what it promises from opposition.

talk.start.para: —Wise decision not to have a supplementary, George.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order relating to standing order 203 about infringement of order. Is it, in your opinion, a breach of the standing orders for Senator Faulkner to lie back in his chair and scream abuse nonstop at senators and ministers on this side? According to standing order 203(1)(b), (d) and (e)—I say this for the benefit of your not necessarily having memorised all of the standing orders—an infringement of order is if a senator `is guilty of disorderly conduct', `persistently and wilfully refuses to conform to the standing orders' and `persistently and wilfully disregards the authority of the chair'. I submit to you, Mr President, that Senator Faulkner is persistently in breach of this standing order.

—Order! If I could have the opportunity to reply to the point of order raised by Senator Knowles. Yes, Senator Knowles, I am aware of those standing orders and I am aware that there have been continuous interjections today from both sides of the chamber. I take your point: both leaders in this place do have a habit of turning their backs on the chair, which is in breach of standing orders. But I would also ask senators to remember that continual interjections across the chamber are disorderly, that this is question time and that the people of Australia are watching this. It is about time most of you remembered who you are representing and how you should behave.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer to the minister's budget press release and the budget statement of risk, which for the first time contains no reference to the adequacy of Telstra's regional service levels with respect to the sale of Telstra. Can the minister confirm that the government has now abandoned its previous commitment to regional Australia not to sell Telstra before services are up to scratch?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —We do strongly believe that Telstra should be sold. It is ridiculous for the Australian government to continue to own 51 per cent of the shares in Australia's biggest company. The government do have an inherent and untenable conflict of interest in being the owner of and the biggest shareholder in that company as well as the regulator of some 70 telecommunications companies, and we look forward to the day that we are able to get legislative authority to sell that company. We have said there are preconditions to that sale. The first and foremost is that telecommunications services in regional and rural Australia do meet satisfactory standards, and we have had two or three inquiries to that effect. The last one showed that standards were meeting requisite levels subject to the investment of appropriate funds by the government, funds which have been committed.

answer.para: We therefore take the view, given that investment as a result of that last inquiry, that rural and regional standards are on track to meet the government's bare minimum acceptable condition precedent to us being able to sell the company. We have also said, of course, that it requires legislative authority and we have also said that we would not sell except under circumstances where the return to Australian taxpayers was appropriate, and we have got to meet all three conditions. I do not think anything at all should be read into the observation that was made by the opposition in relation to that, simply because we have stated that, as a result of the very substantial investment which this government has made from both consolidated revenue and the proceeds of the sale of the 49 per cent of Telstra, we have made a very substantial investment in telecommunications in rural and regional Australia, so those telecommunications standards are, we believe, on track to meet the preconditions of Telstra's sale, a sale which should proceed.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I also refer the minister to Deputy Prime Minister Anderson's comments on 24 March this year that the government's commitment to delivering decent regional services before any sale of Telstra had `not yet been fully delivered'. Minister, given that Deputy Prime Minister Anderson admitted less than two months ago that regional telecommunications are not yet up to scratch, why is the government planning to sell Telstra without any requirement that regional services be up to scratch? Isn't it the case that the Howard-Costello-Anderson government is now completely abandoning regional Australia to get its hands on the Telstra bucket of money?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —That is an absolutely absurd proposition. Minister Anderson did observe the other day that rural and regional Australians now are supportive of the further sale of Telstra. They do understand the enormous investment that we have made in improving regional and rural telecommunications in this country, and the observation is fair—and was made by Estens—that rural and regional telecommunications in this country are as good as those in any other country of a similar kind in the world. The observation made, I think, last year that has been noted by the opposition was in relation to the implementation of the outcomes of the Estens inquiry—into which we poured some hundreds of millions of dollars—that are being rolled out. Upon the roll-out of all those improvements, the preconditions which we have set for adequate rural and regional telecommunications will have been met. We have noted in the budget that our expectation in relation to the commencement of receipt of proceeds is not until 2006-07 so that the sale will not occur—(Time expired)
—Order! I draw the attention of senators to the presence in the gallery of distinguished former Democrats senator Sid Spindler. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome him.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. I refer the minister to the budget fact sheet detailing plans to build further so-called residential housing projects for some of the women and children who are in immigration detention. This fact sheet describes this housing detention as `a family friendly environment'. Minister, how can you possibly describe this housing as `family friendly' when it requires the mother and children to live separately from the father if they wish to use the housing?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Senator, as I am sure you understand and presumably agree—and I believe I have heard you indicate that you agree—placement in residential housing projects is a preferable placement for children to having them in immigration detention centres and, by having agreed that, you yourself confirm that it is obviously a more friendly environment for children and women. You raise the point: how can we say `family friendly' if adult men are not permitted to move out of the detention centres into those residential housing projects? But I just seek, first of all, to put on the record your endorsement of residential housing projects as being a better place for children to be in than detention centres, which is certainly the government's view. That is why we have worked so hard to reduce the number of children who are in detention centres. I think the number is now down to less than 12—it might be 11—and of those 11 I understand quite a number could move out but have refused.

answer.para: One of the reasons their parents may have refused is the very point that you raise about housing projects, namely that adult males are not permitted in them. There are two reasons for this. One, I am advised that when negotiations were undertaken with relevant communities about placing housing projects there—because they are in what would appear to be normal streets; if you look down the street you would not know necessarily that it was a residential housing project—the particular community, and I am thinking of Port Augusta here, was adamant that it would only be a reasonable proposition if the houses were available to only women and children.

The second reason is that most of the people who have come here illegally and who have been designated not to be refugees and are therefore in detention centres—as you know, Senator, the refugees are out in the community with visas—are single adult men. I ask you to consider the position of some of the women. If you are one of the few females, and even fewer females with children, you may very well prefer—and I am advised that a number do—to have a place you can go where adult men are not allowed to be. If you were, for example, the mother of a fourteen-year-old female you may well welcome being in a residential housing project where boys over 18 and other adult men would not be. I am advised that those two reasons are why we keep, for example, the Port Augusta residential housing facility as one that is only available to women and children.

I do understand that there are some children who may still be in detention centres because their mothers have refused to move out and leave the partner behind. The partner has an extensive capacity to visit. Sometimes families have provision for two forms of accommodation because they move back into a detention centre for a week or whatever to be with their partner. I am considering whether there is a capacity to modify that in one of the detention centres and have one, possibly Woomera for example, where you did allow adult males. You would still have to take into account the views of the local community and the views of women and children who were going to be in the housing project. There are good reasons for this. It is more friendly than being in a detention centre—much more family friendly.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. In relation to these new housing projects that are proposed, including one in Perth, will the government allow families to stay together rather than be required to live apart? Alongside that, given that the housing projects are described as being family friendly domestic environments, will the government allow the children in particular to receive visitors in that domestic environment, namely in the house, rather than them having to go up to the main detention centre just to receive visitors?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I hope you will agree; I suppose in one sense it is immaterial whether you do or not—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is, because I am about to make the claim that I am very proud of what this government has done in trying to make facilities better for children. I hope you will agree with that but you may not. Yes, obviously, we will be considering what can be done. I understand the view you take with respect to visitors but I also ask you to understand that there are some lobby groups—generally not service providers—who may seek to take advantage of such arrangements and, unfortunately, it is those who do not play by the rules and may seek to take advantage of such arrangements that make it worse for others. That is always the case. It is the negative people in the community who put limits on the rest of us who are happy to do the right thing. I take you back, for example, to some children who, with the assistance of some of the community, broke out of a detention centre and stayed out. You would not want to allow that sort of thing to happen. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Patterson as Minister for Family and Community Services.
