4.6 The median time taken to finalise a case also reduced last financial year compared to the 2001/02 financial year; from 54 weeks from lodgement to finalisation down to 49 weeks, for community cases, while detention cases remained the same as the previous financial year, at 10 weeks from lodgement to finalisation.

4.7 The improved performance was the result of increases in the numbers of tribunal members following several new member recruitment rounds in which the Government added 10 new members to the Tribunal in October 2001, and a further 7 new members in July 2002. A further 18 new members were appointed to the RRT in July 2003. There were 81 tribunal members at October 2003, compared to 63 as at 1 July 2002, and 55 as at 1 July 2001.
5.1 A dissenting report was tabled by Senator Andrew Bartlett. Senator Bartlett recommended that Regulation 4.31B cease to operate after 1 July 2003.
5.2 This report commented that:
most submissions to the review opposed the fee;
there is not convincing evidence that the fee has discouraged non bona fide asylum seekers from seeking RRT review;

it is not appropriate to hold the threat of a fee (or fine) over some of our most vulnerable potential immigrants, particularly when there is doubt that it is achieving its purpose of deterring spurious appeals; and
removing the fee would send a positive message to the Australian community that the Australian Government is committed to helping refugees and people who face serious abuses of their human rights.
5.3 The dissenting report concluded:

In 1999 and in 2001 no clear evidence was presented to this committee, which proved that the introduction of a fee for access to review contributed to a reduction of abuse of the PV process. Once again the overwhelming evidence is that the fee does not counter abuse of the system and imposes unnecessary strain on applicants. While I agree with recommendation No 3, that the Refugee Review Tribunal be given additional resources to carry out their duties expeditiously, I don't agree with the primary recommendations of the committee.

5.4 The Government acknowledges the contribution of Senator Bartlett and accepts that his intentions are similar to those of the Government, in seeking to ensure that Australia continues to fulfil its international refugee and humanitarian obligations to a high standard, and to reduce the levels of abuse of the system.
5.5 However, the Government considers that the dissenting report's recommendation would have a significant negative effect on the outcomes for the protection visa system.

5.6 The review has clearly shown that there is still evidence of abuse of the PV process. An indicator of the level of abuse is that 34% of all RRT decisions are affirmed without the applicant availing themselves of an opportunity to attend a hearing to present their case. While the Department's submission to the Committee advanced reasons for this, no other submissions or evidence to the Committee were able to provide a plausible alternative explanation why this occurs.

5.7 The Government does not accept the conclusion in the dissenting report that the expected positive effects of the fee have not occurred. Evidence submitted to the Committee showed the fee has been a deterrent to prospective RRT applicants of `low refugee producing' nationalities, the group in which more non-genuine applications are found.

5.8 While some submissions argued that the fee had a negative effect on some applicants, the Government does not accept that any perceived adverse effect outweighs the actual positive effect the fee has had as a deterrent and a partial cost recovery measure. The analysis and research on review applications and success rates provided to the Committee in the DIMIA submission indicates that the disincentive effect of the fee focussed on those applicants who are not refugees. The Government also notes that no concrete evidence was provided to the Committee to show that the fee dissuaded any genuine applicant from applying to the RRT for review of their primary decision.

para.inline: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON TREATIES INQUIRY INTO AUSTRALIA'S EXTRADITION LAW AND POLICY

speech.para: While acknowledging the practical difficulties associated with changing the basis of Australia's extradition arrangements, we do not favour the continuation of the default `no evidence' model in relation to requests for extradition from Australia.

We recommend that the Attorney-General refer for inquiry and report by the Australian Law Reform Commission matters relating to the appropriate evidentiary standard for extradition requests to Australia. The terms of reference for this inquiry should be sufficiently broad to allow the Commission to consider:
the merits and consequences of adopting the `record of the case' model used by Canada
the merits and consequences of adopting the `probable cause' model used by the United States of America
other approaches to raising the evidentiary standard for extradition requests to Australia
international practice in relation to extradition arrangements, including the availability of appropriate safeguards for those persons subject to a request for extradition, and
the impact of any changes on Australia's existing and future network of extradition arrangements.

The evidentiary standard under which Australia conducts its extradition relations is a matter of policy, to be determined taking into account a wide range of considerations outside the legal sphere. These matters are not appropriate for reference to the ALRC, a body whose focus is on reform of the law.

The “no evidence” standard has allowed Australia to enter into extradition relations with 31 countries on this basis. Many of these countries are European or Latin American countries which use the “civil law” system. Because of differences between the “civil law” and “common law” systems (which Australia and most of the Commonwealth use), these countries are effectively unable to conduct extradition relations on any basis other than the “no evidence” standard. These countries remain significant partners in international criminal justice arrangements.

This expansion of Australia's extradition network has allowed Australia to participate more effectively in international efforts to combat serious and transnational crime. It allows Australia to bring to justice persons accused of committing serious crimes who have fled Australia. The Government cannot agree to adopt an evidentiary standard for extradition which would jeopardise this achievement.
We recommend that the Australian Law Reform Commission inquiry recommended above also examine:
the extent of the court's role in considering extradition requests, specifically:
- in scrutinising the evidence presented in support of an extradition request
- in considering objections to extradition
- in considering evidence that may be led by persons whose extradition is sought, and
- in determining whether a person is an extraditable person.

whether the current presumption against bail unless there are special circumstances should be modified in light of the onerous consequences to persons who might be considered to be at low risk of absconding
whether the threshold for extraditable offences should be increased, and
who should pay the costs of return to Australia of a person who has been surrendered to a foreign country to face trial.

The Government does not accept the recommendation to refer the appropriate evidentiary standard for extradition to the ALRC. The Government does not consider that the matters identified by the Committee in recommendation 2 warrant reference to the ALRC for inquiry in their own right.

The Government does recognise that some of the issues identified by the Committee in this recommendation should be investigated and considered further. The Government is grateful to the Committee for identifying these issues. The Government will review the Extradition Act 1988 and Australia's extradition practice and will include these points in this review.

para.inline: JCPAA Report 396: Review of Auditor-General's Reports, 2002-2003, First, Second and Third Quarters
Government Response to Recommendation 6 of the report

speech.para: The Commonwealth should adopt procedures for notifying the Parliament of the issuing of indemnities based on the procedures used by the United Kingdom Parliament.
The Government does not agree with the recommendation. The Government will, however, enhance the level of disclosure of indemnities in agency financial statements.

In the United Kingdom the process for entering and reporting indemnities involves a requirement that certain classes of indemnities be advised to the Parliament by the tabling of a minute in the House of Commons, generally for a period of 14 days before they are issued. This minute is for information purposes and does not provide Parliament with a role in approving these instruments. Minutes can be tabled after the event should circumstances dictate.

While the Australian system does not replicate this requirement, it has a more broadly based approach to managing proposals for indemnities and their reporting to Parliament. Prior to approving a proposal to enter into an indemnity, Australian Government officials are required, by regulations under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, to consider the available appropriation to meet the costs of the indemnity. Should there not be sufficient appropriation, the official must seek the authorisation of the Minister for Finance and Administration or his or her delegate. We understand that similar statutory requirements do not exist in the United Kingdom. Further, in Australia, material indemnities and other contingent liabilities are reported in agencies' financial statements, and the Consolidated Financial Statements. Those contingent liabilities that are material to the budget are required, under the Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998, to be advised to Parliament twice a year in the Budget Papers and the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook.

However, the Government recognises the need to continually review the processes for issuing and managing indemnities, and reporting these instruments to Parliament. The Department of Finance and Administration released the `Guidelines for Issuing and Managing Indemnities, Guarantees, Warranties and Letters of Comfort' in September 2003. In terms of reporting, it is intended that the Finance Minister's Orders (FMOs) for 2003-04 will include considerably enhanced requirements to ensure that agencies' financial statements distinguish between quantifiable indemnities, and other contingencies, that have been issued during the financial year, those which have crystallised, and those that remain in force from previous financial years.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate

talk.start.para: —On 1 April 2004 the government tabled a number of documents related to ethanol that had been sought through a return to order in October 2002. The government undertook to table further documents during this parliamentary session. I now table documents released under the Freedom of Information Act by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Treasury, Industry, Tourism and Resources, and Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.
—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the documents.

speech.para: The tabling of these documents relates to the Senate order for the production of documents which detail the government's grubby deal to give import protection and pay a massive subsidy to the Manildra group. That deal was made behind closed doors at a secret meeting between the Prime Minister and the chairman of the Manildra group in August 2002. In October 2002 the Senate sought full details of the government's deal through the production of relevant documents even though, at the time, we did not know about the secret meeting. Despite repeated promises for delivery of the documents to this chamber by the Manager of Government Business, Senator Ian Campbell, the government refused to comply with the order. I then initiated a complex freedom of information process to get access to some—I repeat, some—of the documents that established the truth of the government's dealings. In return, I got a range of documents, many almost completely masked, and a large schedule of documents showing which had been withheld.

One of those documents—the famous meeting minutes—revealed the Prime Minister's meeting with Mr Dick Honan, a meeting the Prime Minister denied three times in the other place as having occurred. It was a meeting at which questions at the heart of the government's subsequently announced Manildra-friendly ethanol policy were discussed. On 1 April, as outlined by Senator Hill in his comments just now, and almost 18 months after the Senate demanded the ethanol documents, a small number of documents were tabled in response to the order. And what were they? According to the unfortunate minister who was required to do the tabling, Senator Ian Macdonald, the documents were the same ones already released to me by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet under FOI 12 months earlier. He announced at that time that documents already released to me by other departments would be tabled at a later time—and I take it that that is what is now being tabled, if I understand Senator Hill's comments correctly and the undertaking given by Senator Ian Macdonald.

Frankly, the government's actions in terms of this return to order, ignoring it and simply tabling documents already released under the limited terms of the Freedom of Information Act, do not constitute compliance with the original Senate return to order. The Senate did take a stand in respect of this matter by previously deferring debate on two ethanol bills until the government complied with the order. Unfortunately, that stand was fatally undermined by yet another deal between the Howard government and none other than the Democrats, this time under Senator Bartlett's leadership. That inadequate compliance resulted in the passage of the bills. Today is the final act in that ethanol return to order, because the Democrats lack the will to join Labor in demanding accountability from this government for its private dealings with its powerful mates behind closed doors. It is an act which we will be reminding both the government and the Democrats about in the future, and I trust that we will not hear too many pious comments about returns to order from Senator Bartlett again.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I table a report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission entitled A last resort? The report of the national inquiry into children in immigration detention.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I wish to take note of the report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission A last resort? The report of the national inquiry into children in immigration detention which, as senators in the chamber can see, is a very sizeable document. I do not know the number of pages but it is in the hundreds, so I am not going to pretend that I have absorbed its full contents and can elaborate on it at length now. It is appropriate that it be kept on the Notice Paper for speaking to at a later date. But it is also appropriate to acknowledge, firstly, that it is an historic report. It is certainly not the first report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission into detention, but it is one of the most significant and it is the first one focusing specifically on children. It is the end product of a very extensive investigation over more than two years—getting closer to three years—and I think we should acknowledge the amount of work that has gone into this and congratulate the commission for it.

The report has been with the government for some time. It is unfortunate that it is being tabled at a time when a vast amount of media and public attention is being focused on the budget and on early election speculation. I certainly hope, and the Democrats will do everything we can to ensure, that it does not sink into obscurity and not get the attention it deserves as a result of other activities that are happening.

What I would like to say at this initial stage, before fully absorbing the report, is that even from some of the leaks and such that I have been able to see I have no doubt that the report reflects the basic fact that having children in detention is extremely damaging for their immediate wellbeing and, even more importantly, for their long-term wellbeing. We should not have a policy or a law that enables—in fact, almost requires—the damaging of children and the harming of their development.

I understand this report has involved commission officers going to every detention centre in Australia, interviewing some of the detainees and other people, hearing from departmental staff and from all sorts of people. But I want to emphasise that this report does not include the many children who have been detained on Nauru, because that is outside the jurisdiction of the commission. However, that is still detention that has occurred as a direct consequence of Australian laws and Australian government policy and, of course, it continues to occur.

There are still 70 children detained on Nauru. They have been there for over two years, apart from one or two who have been born there and are obviously younger. I was in Baxter detention centre just a couple of weeks ago and spoke with families and detainees, including the young children. One family that I saw there I had also seen there over a year ago when the wife was pregnant. This time around they had a particularly attractive 10-month-old baby who was walking around. I think all of us would acknowledge that that is far from the ideal situation for children to be brought up in.

There is a wider debate, obviously, about refugee policy, immigration policy and detention policy that this issue is contained within. I would seek not to broaden out the debate on this report but to focus on the simple fact that, regardless of what people think about the broader policy parameters, this component of it means that children are kept in detention for prolonged periods of time and that does not have a good outcome. In my view, any policy, any law, that has as one component of its functioning such damage being done to children is flawed and we need to change it.

That applies even more so to the children who are on Nauru, because they are outside any form of scrutiny, any form of accountability and any form of judicial oversight. I have met with some of the children who are on Nauru. I have seen the difference in those children between meeting them in the Nauru detention centre, separated from their fathers, in July last year and then meeting those same children living free in New Zealand six months later with the family reunited. The difference was extraordinary. It is fairly self-evident to think about it and to talk about it, but it is extraordinary to actually see those children in person, to see the difference between children in despair, separated from their father for two or three years, not knowing what their future holds, not knowing why they are in this situation. Six months later, living with the family like any other family in the community that is free to choose their own future, one six-year-old girl was just about to go to school, able to play with her friends like anybody else. To actually see that distinction, you can see how much damage is done by doing this to children. I have no doubt that there are specific incidents detailed in the report that the government will have responded to and to which they will have said, `We have done things and acted on these concerns.' That is all positive, but none of it addresses the fundamental problem, the fundamental flaw that is continuing as we speak, which is that children are in detention.

I also had the opportunity, with the cooperation of the minister's office and the department—for which I thank them—to visit the housing project in Port Augusta just a couple of weeks ago which was referred to today in question time by the minister. It is the so-called housing project where women and children are able to live in housing in the Port Augusta community. There is no doubt that it is a more pleasant physical environment for those children to be in. It is rather similar to a suburban street, as the minister said, with the fairly significant distinction that it is surrounded by a fence and nobody is allowed out and nobody is allowed in. So it is a fenced-off suburban street, and that is a very significant distinction.

The other significant distinction is that the fathers and husbands are not allowed to live with the rest of their family. They are kept in the main security detention centre at Baxter. Nobody is allowed to visit—or very few people are allowed to visit—the children in the housing. Appointments have to be made with the Baxter detention centre, and arrangements have to be made for the children to be bussed to Baxter to meet their fathers behind the wire of the detention centre. The fathers are usually allowed to go to the houses about twice a week for around four hours each time. Otherwise, the family have to make an appointment—with about a day's notice, I was told—to go to Baxter detention centre just to interact with the father or husband. So there is still a very significant flaw there, despite the undoubtedly far more pleasant living environment that the children are in—there is that lack of hope for their future, that separation from husband and father, that separation from friends.

The children are allowed out to go to school. That is great, that is welcomed, but after school they have to come back. They cannot have their friends come back to their house with them and they cannot go to their friend's house after school. They might sound like simple things, but they are very significant things. I think anyone who thinks that that is acceptable and appropriate and says that that is like living in a community is clearly not acknowledging or understanding, firstly, what a simple concept freedom is, but also what an absolutely fundamental and crucial concept freedom is and how damaging it is to deny it to anybody but particularly to children.

That is the fundamental underpinning of this report. It is a very important report. It is obviously a politically contentious issue, but I do hope that all of us here seek to engage with it constructively and attempt to alleviate the core problem that is at the centre of the community concern that generated this report—that is, that children do not belong in detention. Whilst we need to act on individual incidents and individual situations where things are wrong, the fundamental thing we need to do is get them out of detention altogether. I understand others might want to speak to this report but might not be doing so now, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —The President has received letters from party leaders seeking variations to the membership of certain committees.

interjection.para: Senator VANSTONE (South Australia—Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation) (3.44 p.m.)—by leave—I move:
That senators be discharged from and appointed to committees as follows:

quote.para: Appointed—Substitute member: Senator Fifield to replace Senator Chapman for the consideration of the 2004-05 Budget estimates from 31 May to 4 June 2004

para.inline: Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee--

quote.para: Appointed—Substitute member: Senator Johnston to replace Senator Tierney for the committee's inquiry into the Office of the Chief Scientist

para.inline: Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee--

quote.para: Appointed—Substitute member: Senator Scullion to replace Senator Tchen for the consideration of the 2004-05 Budget estimates on 25 May 2004 from 7.30 pm

para.inline: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee--

quote.para: Appointed—
Participating members:
Senator Faulkner for the committee's inquiry into the provisions of the Parliamentary Superannuation Bill 2004 and a related bill
Senator Ludwig

Substitute members: Senators Sherry and Cherry to replace Senators Faulkner and Murray for the committee's inquiry into the provisions of the Parliamentary Superannuation Bill 2004 and a related bill.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes with concern the adverse effects of the Government's botched implementation of the current Cooperative Research Centre (CRC) selection round;
(b) calls on the Government to restore public interest research as a key selection criteria for future CRCs; and

(c) calls on the Minister for Science (Mr McGauran) to take responsibility for the denial of funding to nationally-significant CRCs such as the reef, rainforest and photonics CRCs, and to use his powers under the current CRC guidelines to hear appeals from such CRCs against their exclusion from the current selection round.

speech.para: In the week before the budget, researchers and scientists were astounded to hear not only that the budget for the Cooperative Research Centres Program, because indexation arrangements had not properly been made, had been cut by an aggregate figure of $200 million but also that 19 of the 52 applications for the current CRC Program selection round had been rejected. These included some of the most successful and important of the existing CRCs. The casualties included the world renowned, leading edge centres for rainforest, reef and coastal research, as well as the highly regarded, commercially successful CRCs for photonics and satellites. The Minister for Science has abandoned them completely, arguing that they did not offer good value for money.

How was that possible? It was possible only because the minister himself introduced new guidelines last December, even though it is now apparent that he does not understand them. When some of the trashed CRCs sought to appeal against him he rejected those appeals out of hand, and he has done so publicly in the press. He claimed that he had no direct responsibility and he flick passed the decisions to the CRC advisory committee. He was not only wrong but also inept in these actions, because he has compounded the problems that are faced by these CRCs. Section 1.4 of his own guidelines says under the heading `Role of the minister':

quote.para: The Minister—

speech.para: I emphasise that—

quote.para: decides which CRCs will be funded ...

speech.para: It says that in making those decisions:

quote.para: ... the Minister may have regard to the advice of the CRC committee ...

speech.para: I emphasise `advice'. In other words, the minister has laid down the rails and released the trains, and the wreck that is on the line now is directly his responsibility.

I am sure some senators will ask why this is important. By common consent, CRCs are recognised as one of the most effective means of mobilising our research effort and promoting collaboration between the public and private sectors. CRCs were established with the twin aims of changing the research culture within this country and addressing market failure in key areas of national concern. This is particularly important in environmental and agricultural research, for they are case studies in effective public investment in research. The minister continues to have problems with CRC selection, and I think this is mainly because he has not understood the CRC Program itself. He is incorrect when he claims that the program has always been an industry support program. Industry has always been part of the equation, but within a program really designed to increase the commercial and social effectiveness of already committed research activities.

The new guidelines stem from a further review of the CRC Program undertaken by the Sydney University based engineer and consultant John (Hamilton) Howard—and I emphasise `Hamilton'. Howard Partners, which produced the report, acknowledged the original impulses that led to the creation of the CRC Program and also acknowledged the tremendous success of this program. Howard points out that one of the two outstanding areas of success has been social outcomes—that is, public benefit research, which has been an essential part of the program from the beginning—and that the CRC Program was introduced in part to address the problems of market failure and the absence of private sector engagement with major social and environmental research issues. Both of those areas are extraordinary success stories. The minister has sought to eradicate the first while ignoring the implications of the second of these great success stories.
John Howard of Howard Partners, apparently touting for customers, observed in an email in January:

quote.para: The CRC evaluation ... recommended that the program be more sharply focussed on economic/industry outcomes, that CRCs be industry driven and that pure “public good” related research not be part of the program in the future.

speech.para: In a single move—a mad move, in my judgment—Minister McGauran's insistence on the recommendations undermined one of the key strengths of the program: the fact that the selection criteria encouraged proposals from the widest range of possible CRCs. It was its very flexibility that proved its strength. The other issue that Mr John Howard referred to was market failure. In this respect it is interesting to briefly consider the sources of funding of the CRC Program. In the past 12 years, participants have contributed more than $7 billion in cash and in kind to the CRCs. Of this figure, industry has contributed about $1.3 billion. The federal government through various sources, including universities and the CSIRO, has contributed more than $4.6 billion, or about 66 per cent. It is ironic in the light of these figures that the minister now turns to industry—to the market—to rectify a program which was designed to address the question of market failure.

The Howard report has not only brought about a fundamental change but it has also highlighted a fundamental policy position of this government—that is, a very narrow and unbalanced view of commercialisation. If we accepted this government's notions of commercialisation and if this was the policy operating in the 1950s, for instance, we would be looking at ways to improve the iron lung rather than ways to invent a vaccine for polio. It is an extraordinary attitude that the government has about the concept of commercialisation—an extraordinarily narrow view of commercialisation. Of course it is not surprising that Minister McGauran accepted the recommendation that this so-called public benefit research be excluded from the CRC Program, because that was a precondition of the review. I understand that it was actually a decision of cabinet. Frankly, as the process was introduced by way of changing the guidelines for a committee selected by the minister which has little discretion in the implementation of those guidelines, it is not surprising that the results have been produced in the way they have.

Mr John (Hamilton) Howard has told us, those who have received his `open for business' email, that `the change in the nature of the program has not been well publicised'. That is a direct quote from the person that was organising these changes. The guidelines and instructions issued at the commencement of the selection process were in fact unclear. Take, for example, the issue that tipped over the photonics CRC: the apparent lack of business partners. It sounds somewhat silly to reject an application from a CRC with a track record of such successful spin-off companies producing revenues of over $500 million, but that is what this government has done. It is silly of course because photonics is one of the CRCs that this hapless minister has singled out. He has cut them to the bone; he has in fact finished them off. As for his argument about this CRC, we see there is little evaluation and no examination of the evidence. In view of the extraordinary attitude towards the guidelines, he is quite clearly wrong in the application of those guidelines. He is wrong in terms of the commercial support, but he is wrong in the way in which the guidelines have actually been applied in regard to that. That was the position of the consultant, Mr John (Hamilton) Howard—who, in addition to writing the report, has now been retained by the department as an adviser to applicants for this program—when he said in his email on 22 January this year:

quote.para: ... a preliminary `business case' is required by 30 March. It would not be necessary at this stage to nominate all participants ...

speech.para: Yet that was the basis on which these CRCs were knocked over! A question has been asked about the role of the Chief Scientist with regard to the rejection of a solar CRC bid from the ANU. I would be interested to know whether or not the Chief Scientist stood down from examination of this bid. In the Senate inquiry that has been established that will be one of the questions that I will ask. If in fact he did participate, it would be inappropriate in the circumstances where he is involved with a coal company.

It strikes me that these problems boil down to one thing: the presumption on behalf of this government that if it is any good it has to be able to make a quick quid. We see that is not the position that has been taken, for instance, with regard to the fishing industry when it has raised questions about the destruction of the CRCs for rainforest, coastals and the Great Barrier Reef—the three great success stories which underpin the management of the World Heritage area. Only a stupid government would take such a short-sighted approach to undermine organisations such as these. You see that even the member for Herbert, who makes a rather mealy-mouthed defence of the government in Canberra while at the same time grandstanding in North Queensland, says:

quote.para: I will not stand by and see one of the best working models of a user-driven, user pays CRC dismantled at a time when it is ramping up levels of user support over a broad area and fulfilling the Government's R&D agenda in tropical Australia.

speech.para: The tragedy is that it is not just two important CRCs that are at risk. There are others affected including the coastal zone estuary and waterway management CRC and other proposed CRCs, such as the groundwater resource management CRC, which have been knocked over by this government's decision.

I think the distressed photonics and satellite CRCs highlight one of the great flaws in the way the government has been pursuing these matters, and it is with some justification that a former Liberal minister and former national president of the Liberal Party, Mr Tony Staley, who happens to be president of both the photonics and satellite CRCs, has described the photonics CRC as `the kings of commercialisation'. In the process he has managed to slap down Minister McGauran. He has described the defunding of the photonics CRC as `indefensible'. That is a position I would agree with. The minister's actions in this regard are indefensible. If the commercial track record of the photonics CRC, combined with its current support, is inadequate, exactly what business model does the minister believe represents value for money?

The photonics bid has appealed to the minister for a review of the decision. As I say, he has already publicly rejected that appeal. He is saying it is beyond his powers. It is quite clear that he has not read his own guidelines. He does not seem to understand his own guidelines. I again point to section 1.4 of the guidelines, published under his name, that deal with the `Role of the minister'. Is it the case that the minister is bound by the `decisions' of an independent committee, as he claims? I say that the minister is not bound by a so-called independent committee. I quote the guidelines:

quote.para: The Minister for Science has overall responsibility for the CRC Programme. The Minister decides which CRCs will be funded and the conditions of any funding offer. The final decision by the Minister will take into account the requirements of the section guidelines—

speech.para: and obviously the decision has to be fully documented. Guideline 1.4.2 goes on to say this:

quote.para: In deciding which CRCs get funded and what terms and conditions, if any, are attached to the funding offer, the Minister may have regard to—

speech.para: `may have regard to'—

quote.para: the advice of the CRC Committee arising from the assessment process and may take into account consideration of other matters including the application and related documentation.

speech.para: So it is quite apparent from the guidelines that the minister does have discretion, and it is distorting the truth, to say the very least, to claim that he is bound to the decisions of some sort of committee—a committee he has established operating on his guidelines and putting advice to him. It is a complete nonsense for that defence to be presented by the government. His actions are indefensible. I ask the coalition senators who will speak after me on this to address that point. Read the guidelines and answer the question: why can't the minister fix this? There is clearly no reason why he cannot fix this.

I take the view that there is an opportunity here for these things to be fixed. The minister has denied this. He has put out press releases misrepresenting my colleague in the House of Representatives Mr Kelvin Thomson, suggesting that the Labor Party favours mates. He is quite clearly rattled. He has put out another press release today attacking me on this same question. He is under intense pressure from within the government to change his position and fix his mistakes. The minister, of course, does not have absolute powers—we know that—but he does have the capacity to address his own errors.

I take the view that there are questions of probity in the guidelines that must be observed. But what eludes the minister is not the question of picking winners; rather, it is the very guidelines that he invokes and then ignores. The photonics CRC have appealed on the grounds that the guidelines have been misapplied and, therefore, the grounds for dismissing their submission are flawed. At the very least, it should be considered rather than rejected out of hand by the minister, and that is clearly not what is happening. The crisis within the CRC movement has of course been initiated by the minister's own mistakes. He is not up to the job and, frankly, the Prime Minister ought to be intervening to fix up this mess. It is quite apparent to me that the minister's misunderstandings and misrepresentations make him unfit for the job. He is not capable of fulfilling his functions in this ministry.

The minister argues that the decisions cannot be overruled by an independent selection committee, but that did not stop him last year intervening to provide another CRC—the forestry CRC—with additional funding that had not been recommended through any selection process. This is a matter that ought to be attended to within the government itself. National investment and national research interests of this country are at risk, national icons are at risk, the selection process is in a shambles, and we can now see that there is an attempt behind the scenes to put in a political fix.

The opposition say that there is an opportunity to attend to this. A Labor government would attend to this. A Labor government would take the view that the process has been flawed, the guidelines should be rewritten, we should restore public benefit research and the whole current selection process should start again under a transparent process, applying criteria, including public benefit research.

CRCs stand as one of Australia's notable contributions to research infrastructure. A successful research effort is the driver of productivity and, through productivity, of economic growth. Research means more than just treating these things as the production of new gimmicks and new products. We are seeking to establish an opportunity to address major social problems, and the CRC Program is very much a part of that. We cannot afford to let the CRC Program become hostage to the ideological whims of the government or the science minister. Australia's gross expenditure on research, as a percentage of GDP, is falling at a time when our international competitors are spending more on research and development. We are falling behind in the race to improve productivity, on which our prosperity as a nation depends. A Labor government will squarely face up to this responsibility.

It strikes me that, when we are faced with a minister who is not able to do his job, senior ministers ought to intervene. The Prime Minister, in my view, ought to have a good look at this. At the very least, the cabinet minister responsible, Brendan Nelson, ought to be reviewing these decisions. As I said, a Labor government would review them. The government has an opportunity to fix these problems. If it fails to do so, it will be letting down hundreds of thousands of Australians who are enjoying the work of the CRCs. It will be letting down major industries in this country that directly benefit from assistance.

I say to anyone who tells me that support for the Great Barrier Reef, the rainforests of this country or the tropical coastal areas are not of immense national significance that they are wrong. Again, if the government were to tell me that an institution like the photonics CRC, which does cutting-edge research with regard to laser technology, data management and a whole range of areas—on which we are very dependent in the longer term—is not of immense importance, then frankly I think they are mistaken.

Equally, the opposition take the view that the government's failure with regard to our space program, in knocking over the satellite CRC, is extraordinarily short-sighted. We take the view that we should start again with this round, we should have another look at it, we should restore public benefit research to the criteria and this incompetent, foolish minister ought to go.

talk.start.para: —I think that the CRC Program has been one of Australia's great success stories. To give credit where credit is due, the Cooperative Research Centres Program was first established in 1990 by the then Labor government, with the aim of improving research and development in Australia. The CRC Program brings together researchers from universities, CSIRO, other government agencies and private industry to collaborate on R&D and education and it has been a great success. While the quest for knowledge is important in itself, if it is going to improve our lives and enhance our national prosperity, it is important that it be utilised and commercialised in the interests of the people of Australia. This is a central objective of cooperative research centres. There are links with small to medium business enterprises, which are encouraged. CRCs can establish companies themselves to commercialise their intellectual property.

speech.para: There are 71 CRCs across six sectors in Australia. These cover manufacturing technology, information and communications technology, mining and energy, agriculture and rural based manufacturing, the environment and medical science and technology. There are in fact more CRCs in the environmental sector than in any other sector—that is, there are 17 environmental CRCs out of a total of 71. Over the life of the CRC Program, participants have committed more than $7 billion in cash and in kind to CRCs. This includes around $2 billion from the Australian government, and industry has contributed over $1.3 billion, with more than 400 companies involved in the CRC Program. CRCs generally have at least 30 full-time researchers and an average budget of around $7 million annually.

As I said, the CRC Program has been a great Australian success story. I think it is important to understand that CRC funding is provided for an initial period of seven years, with no guarantee of further funding beyond that time; although CRCs may apply for further funding, they are judged competitively at that time against other applicants. In the initial period of seven years, CRCs are generally expected to plan to obtain funding from alternative sources for their ongoing needs. The initial funding for the first seven years is designed to enable these research centres to establish themselves and to demonstrate that their programs do have commercial viability and can attract commercial investment. The Labor Party does not seem to understand the fundamental point that the initial funding is provided to establish the CRCs, to establish their programs and to enable them to establish and make the point that they do have commercial viability.

Australian industry has been very supportive of the CRC Program. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, quoted in a July 2003 paper entitled `Evaluation of the Cooperative Research Centres Programme', concluded that `the program is an extremely effective policy instrument which has been recognised around the world for fostering collaboration between industry and researchers'. Likewise, the global and Australasian editions of the renowned New Scientist magazine on 16 August 2003 described CRCs as `the role model for collaboration between business, academia and government the world over'. I think it is important to emphasise that this magazine made the point that it is a collaboration between business, academia and government. The evaluation found that the CRC Program has made substantial progress in meeting its objectives. It said:

quote.para: CRCs have performed a vitally important role in transforming publicly funded discoveries and inventions into products and businesses that are “investment ready”.

speech.para: So that commercial dimension has always been there, although it seems to be something that Senator Carr does not seem to have appreciated. The evaluation report said that CRCs had 114 Australian patents and 549 overseas patents, with more being processed. CRC start-up companies had revenue from sales of $30.4 million in 2001-02, with projected sales of almost $1 billion. There is no doubt that the CRC Program has contributed to economic growth, social wellbeing and good environmental outcomes for Australia.

The evaluation found that the main contribution of the CRC Program has been to improve the capacity to carry out partnership work in the overall science and innovation system. It noted that the Australian petroleum CRC had commissioned an independent economic analysis that demonstrated that the CRC had generated value in excess of $300 million from an investment of just $8 million. The evaluation identified the potential benefits across a range of CRCs and quotes, for example, that the CRC for sustainable production in forestry had reported a potential payoff of $194 million from research leading to the improvement of genetic potential for eucalyptus from hardwood plantations. Another example is the CRC for eye research and technology, which has developed a new type of contact lens that can be worn continuously for up to 30 days and is now worn by more than 400,000 people around the word. It reports an enormous potential market among the 95 million people around the world who wear contact lenses. The evaluation also found:

quote.para: ... the CRC Programme has made a major contribution to the development of Australia's public sector research capacity in areas of national need and global opportunity.

speech.para: The report notes that environmental CRCs, for example, have carried out `important and useful research on the environmental challenges facing Australia'.

It is understandable that those applicants who were unsuccessful at the last cooperative research centre funding round are disappointed. CRC funding is highly sought after, and there is a very competitive process to obtain it. In a lot of ways we should be pleased that the funding is so hotly contested. It is a testament to the strength of ingenuity and the quest for knowledge and research and development that we have in this nation. There were 52 applications received for the 2004 selection round of the program, and 19 of these applications were unsuccessful.

Senator Carr would have the parliament believe that the selection process was botched and that it was just plain wrong. There is no way that the selection process has been botched. Just because Senator Carr believes that three of the existing CRCs who were unsuccessful in this round should have had their funding extended in no way means that this process was botched. The fact is that applications are individually assessed by an independent selection committee. The Cooperative Research Centres Committee makes its selections on the basis of merit. The committee is appointed by the Minister for Science, and its membership consists of senior representatives of industry and representatives of Australian government agencies involved in research and research funding. So this is not some mickey mouse committee; it is a committee of highly distinguished Australians who make, as I said, their decisions based on the merit of the applications and seek to ensure that the very best proposals obtain the funding on offer.

The fact that 19 applicants were unsuccessful does not necessarily mean that they were not worthy of funding or that they lacked merit. What it means is that the other applications were more meritorious, more innovative and offered greater potential in terms of benefit to the Australian community. The independent selection panel made its decision on that basis alone. Senator Carr seems to be suggesting that the government should overrule the determination of the independent selection committee. In short, it seems to me that Senator Carr wants to politicise the selection process.

One could be forgiven for thinking that Senator Carr would like to go back to the dim days of the former Labor government, when we had the somewhat unedifying spectacle of then minister for sport, Ros Kelly, writing on a whiteboard in her office and distributing grants to various areas according to where it was perceived the most political benefit would be gained. All that the Minister for Science has done in this instance—just as previous Labor ministers have done since the establishment of the program in 1990—is to accept the decision of the independent selection committee. This process is fair, transparent and merit based, and in my opinion it is fundamentally important to the integrity of the selection process that the minister not be involved.

It is crucial to note that the five unsuccessful applicants that are existing CRCs have secure funding for more than two years to come. The reef CRC will receive a total of $5.5 million in the next two financial years, and the rainforest CRC will receive $5.6 million. Since 1993-94, more than $30 million of CRC Program funding has been committed to the reef CRC. Equally, almost $30 million has gone to the rainforest CRC. CRCs typically receive funding over a period of seven years, and after this period it is not unreasonable to expect them to be self-sustaining. In fact, it is expected that they will seek to establish their own independent funding base over this time, based on their commercial viability. Senator Carr is well aware of this.

Senator Carr has particularly focused on the loss of funding by the reef, rainforest and photonics CRCs. At least one of these, the photonics CRC, has the potential to commercialise its research. Photonics uses light to increase capacity. Demand for increased bandwidth means that there is a need to increase the capacity of optical fibre networks. The implication of this is that photonics has a clear application to the telecommunications industry. Accordingly, perhaps telecommunications companies might like to step in and take up the funding of the photonics CRC. One must wonder how actively such funding has been sought. Senator Carr has proposed to allocate more than $150 million of funding to support the reef, rainforest and photonics CRCs. That begs the question: which CRCs would Senator Carr strip funding from in order to fulfil this commitment? And more to the point: why does he think that his opinion about which CRCs should receive funding is more valid than that of the independent selection committee?

Senator Carr also neglects to acknowledge that the Howard government is providing a high level of funding to other environmental projects. There are numerous sources of government funding for research other than those available under the CRC Program. If one runs through the list of environmental programs which are funded by the Howard government, one sees that it is very impressive. Research on the Great Barrier Reef is funded through the Australian Institute of Marine Science, CSIRO, the Australian Research Council and several universities. For the current financial year expenditure for research on the Great Barrier Reef is estimated to be $37.7 million.

The government is strongly committed to renewable energy, and there are a variety of government programs supporting the development of renewable energy in this country outside the CRC process. For example, there is more than $300 million for grant, equity and rebate programs to boost the uptake of renewable energy in Australia. The Howard government has also implemented the world's first mandatory renewable energy target, which will leverage an extra $2 billion in additional investment in renewable energy programs in Australia by 2010.

In conclusion, the CRC Program has been a great Australian success story in promoting innovative scientific research. The latest funding round has again resulted in the selection of the best proposals, and it is hard to believe that Senator Carr's criticisms of the outcome are sincere. The only conclusion one can draw about Senator Carr's views is that he and the ALP object to the independent nature of the CRC funding structure and would replace the independent board with a politicised alternative, where the whims of amateurs would replace the considered recommendations of a board of experts. I hardly think that is something the Senate would wish to endorse.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I would like to thank the ALP for bringing forward this item of general business. It has picked up on a press release that the Democrats put out in February this year on the issue, so of course we will be supporting the ALP's motion. The situation we are discussing today started with the federal government's changes to the funding guidelines for cooperative research centres. Picking up on the comments that have just been made about whether we would want to return to a different system, or a system whereby the funding structures of the CRC process would be changed, I point out that that is not the problem; the problem is actually the criteria being used for guidelines for funding of CRCs.

speech.para: Back in February the Democrats warned about the dangers to collaborative applied research into environmental health and social issues that would result from changes to the funding guidelines for CRCs, which now favour research that could be rapidly commercialised for economic gain. Science minister Peter McGauran's comments at the time indicated that the CRC Program would be focused on research that could be rapidly converted into commercial and economic gains, and that these changes would be made at the expense of research with less market-driven objectives. At that time my colleague Senator Stott Despoja expressed grave fears over the possibility of a number of CRCs, which have done excellent research over the past few years, having their funding cut if their research did not result in short-term economic benefits. Recently we have seen those predictions come true. Five existing CRCs—researching the Great Barrier Reef, rainforests, coastal zones, satellites and photonics—will not be gaining further funding after failing to pass stage 1 of the CRC selection process.

The Democrats support the role of research in economic growth, and note that Australia's business investment in research and development as a percentage of GDP is still way below the OECD average and has historically been the weak link of our national research effort. We also support the role of research in raising living standards, improving health and solving the major environmental challenges facing Australia—in other words, research for the public good. The government appears to have ignored the fact that many Australians have serious concerns that are other than short-term economic performance of industry. I would like to read from some correspondence that was sent to us by a researcher from a CRC in response to the press release we put out in February:

quote.para: This government doesn't seem to fundamentally understand the role of research and the jobs of researchers.

I'm working as a senior researcher in a CRC that is currently going through a re-bid process. We're stuck in that we have to play the game that's been prescribed for us by the minister, yet I know I'm not alone within my organisation in being puzzled and frustrated by the conditions that have been placed on bids.

Much of what constitutes good research is not directly oriented towards generating short-term profit. Public good research outcomes are geared towards the kinds of longer-term benefits that make for a better and more prosperous country.

Researchers in CRCs like doing applied research and we like to see our work commercialised, but we also have a deep understanding of the value and benefit of our work and we find public good to be a clear and deeply motivating goal. We work better and produce better research outcomes when we know we are supported in making our country better.

speech.para: I am sure this is not an isolated case. The Australian Academy of Humanities called the axing of funding for 19 public good CRCs:

quote.para: ... bad news for Australians and bad news for the Humanities.

speech.para: They continued by saying:

quote.para: This latest policy turn is a clear signal that public money is being diverted away from the public interest towards private benefit. The Government's argument that public good research is adequately funded through other means is utterly mistaken, particularly in the Humanities.

speech.para: The government has claimed that the Australian Research Council grants scheme will pick up some of the public good research, but that is very misleading. The ARC program has a totally different focus than that of the CRCs. It funds strategic research, while the CRCs are directed towards practical and applied research.

talk.start.para: —Senator Tierney, I am sure you will have your go shortly. The changes to the CRC funding guidelines will leave a hole in Australia's research that jeopardises the future of collaborative applied research into important environmental and social issues such as climate change. The Democrats support the role of research in economic growth, but also its role in raising living standards and solving major health and environmental challenges facing Australia.

speech.para: On 30 March the rainforest CRC released a report showing that climate change would wipe out the vast majority of our rainforest species and increase the prevalence of drought and the risks of bushfires and tropical diseases. Obviously the government believes there is no value in any of that knowledge because the rainforest CRC is not going to get funding. The previous withdrawal of funding to the renewable energy CRC shows the government's lack of commitment to the environment and is just part of a list of government failures on renewable energy, which include the failure to ratify the Kyoto protocol, the failure to introduce an emissions trading scheme—indeed not only not introducing it but also going so far as to dismantle the emissions trading research section of the Australian Greenhouse Office—the failure to introduce a greenhouse trigger into the EPBC Act, despite assurances that this would happen, and the failure to introduce mandatory emissions reduction targets for coal-fired power stations—just to name a few.

Senator Eggleston points to the mandated renewable energy target. That target was promised to be two per cent and it has turned out to be less than one per cent because we have used very conservative estimates of the level of consumption of electricity by 2010. Research positions in renewable energy across the board have ceased to get funding and researchers in those establishments have been made redundant. Contrast that with the fact that there are now four CRCs devoted to fossil fuel technologies—the CRC for Australian Petroleum, the CRC for Greenhouse Gas Technologies, the CRC for Coal in Sustainable Development and the CRC for Clean Power from Lignite.

While the Australian Research Council grants are provided for pure research on renewables, the grant sizes are paltry and nowhere near what is needed to provide an adequate basis for effective research and, as I have already said, they are not directed to the developmental phase. With no renewable energy CRC, we have a gaping hole in the renewable energy research strategy, which is leading to the collapse of our renewable energy research sector. We desperately need a solar energy foundation, which could be similar to the CRC structure, to encourage research, development and commercialisation of renewable energy technologies. We could do that with a mere $50 million over five years. That could be very effective and the cost would be nothing compared with the annual subsidies, mounting up to billions of dollars, that are currently provided for the fossil fuel industries. On 2 February this year the science minister said:

quote.para: First and foremost we want CRCs to be operating in a commercial environment and producing commercial outcomes.

speech.para: Does that mean the minister believes that the photonics CRC has not been operating in a commercial environment and producing commercial outcomes? The CRC's president and former federal Liberal Party president, Mr Tony Staley, certainly thinks so. The Australian Photonics CRC Chief Executive Officer, Mr Mark Sceats, said the photonics centre was `extremely commercially viable'. He said:

quote.para: [Our] companies have paid corporate taxes that exceed the government investment in our CRC ...

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: If you look purely at this commercial focus, our CRC is one of the most commercially relevant in terms of outcomes.

speech.para: The Australian reported that the centre has spawned 12 start-up companies, one of which, RBN, has already turned a profit of $55 million—a figure that exceeded the total investment in the centre. It has just signed a five-year export deal, potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The agreement is with the Marconi Corporation, one of the world's largest communications technology suppliers, to resell the Australian developed technology for expanding the capacity of existing communications networks. This CRC has also developed a powerful new mobile radar system that runs on light and has a wide range of applications.

If these sorts of commercial outcomes do not satisfy the criteria, what is required of a CRC to meet the minister's demands? Under the CRC guidelines, the Minister for Science's responsibilities include overall responsibility for the CRC Program. The guidelines state:

quote.para: The Minister decides which CRCs will be funded and the conditions of any funding offer—.

speech.para: and—

quote.para: In deciding which CRCs get funded and what terms and conditions, if any, are attached to the funding offer, the Minister may have regard to the advice of the CRC Committee arising from the assessment process and may take into consideration other matters including the application and related documentation.

speech.para: That makes a nonsense of Senator Eggleston's remarks that we might go back to a whiteboard approach. We already have a whiteboard approach in that the minister has so much discretion over this funding. These guidelines clearly place responsibility for funding decisions with the science minister. The minister is still trying to distance himself from the fiasco that even members of his own party can see is a disaster. In a press release of 3 May, the minister said:

quote.para: Every Science Minister, Labor or Coalition, since the inception of the programme, has accepted the Selection Committee's decisions in the same way that I have. To do otherwise is to reduce the CRC programme to one of political influence and intervention.

speech.para: Does the minister expect us to believe that there was no political influence or intervention in the establishment of these guidelines? I do not think so. The minister made a bad decision on the direction of CRCs, and the government's own funding guidelines for CRCs do not achieve their desired goal. It is true that this government do not seem to fundamentally understand the role of research and the job of researchers.

talk.start.para: —I support the motion and condemn the government for its failure to ensure that matters of enormous public benefit and enormous public value to the future are adequately funded and based on the merit of the research centres involved as put before the government. I might say at the outset that this is not just a matter of the Howard government's refusal to fund—and, in some cases, its decision to defund—cooperative research centres, which have produced or would produce enormously important research for the Australian and world communities. It is also a matter of the government's failure and neglect, since it came to power, of science and research funding in general. This has to be deplored and condemned. Since the Howard government has been in office Australia has dropped to the back of the field in funding compared with other countries. In the run-up to the election, the government is making, as on so many other fronts, a belated injection of funds, which in no way makes up for the neglect of the last eight years.

speech.para: One of the first things the government did when it came to office was to abolish the Energy Research and Development Corporation. In the field of energy, it then went on to serially move funding from the sunrise energy alternatives of the future—whether based on wind power or wave power, renewable energy or direct solar power, such as solar hot water heating and heating—to the coal industry. It did this because it is enormously influenced by the coal industry, and it is indeed well funded directly by the coal industry.

I find that in itself a corrupting component. It is antidemocratic and it infests many governments and many democratic systems around the world. This is a matter that we have to take very seriously. The reality is that for every lobbyist for renewable energy, solar energy or energy saving who comes into this place, there are 10 lobbyists from the coal industry and its satellites like the aluminium industry with far greater access to the prime ministerial offices and the offices of the various ministers. So we have an entirely distorted system, which is extraordinarily unfortunate for the nation. The outcomes from new energy and in particular clean, green and efficient industries across the board are going to be those that are most lucrative for this nation in the future and most enhancing of its lifestyle, its reputation and its contribution to future generations.

I will confine myself to mining energy. You will see how much it has been skewed by the impact that the coal industry has on ministers—including the Prime Minister—who simply do not have the scientific background and the knowledge to make decisions for the long-term benefit of this country and are much more easily swayed by the powerful representatives of these industries at the dinners that ministers serially have with them. On 8 May, Mr McGauran told the ABC radio program Earthbeat:

quote.para: I freely concede that, where more CRC environmental applications would have been successful under old guidelines—

speech.para: that is, previous government guidelines—

quote.para: and not the current guidelines—

speech.para: that is, this government's guidelines—

quote.para: we will have to guard against that, fair enough. But I do not accept the argument that the decisions of the panel should be overturned, that is special treatment ...

speech.para: So here the Minister for Science is saying, `Well, it's fair enough that there should be complaints, and that the government should have guarded against environmental applications which were more oriented to restoring or giving public benefit,' as would have happened under the old guidelines. The complaints about that are `fair enough', but he is not going to do anything about it even though, as Senator Carr explained just a while ago, he has an enormous and final say in the matter.

I believe the minister will not have anything to say about it because he is not competent to make such decisions, let alone to understand the basis of the complaints about the decisions that have been coming out of the government's guidelines. Ultimately they are the minister's guidelines. But he is saying, `I understand that there is valid complaint about them, but I do not know what to do about it.' The Minister for Science, Mr McGauran has said, `I am not competent to know how to get myself out of this bind that I've got government policy into.' On Earthbeat he said:

quote.para: I do not accept that the government is ignoring investment in research and development in renewable energy.

speech.para: The government closed down the most august body for determining that matter in its first year of office, in 1996-97. With respect to renewable energy and energy efficiency, the CRC funding that was there in the past has gone to zero, but the minister says, `I don't accept that the government is ignoring investment.' He has cut it to ribbons; he has cut it to nothing.

The government will argue that they can get funding through other avenues, but so can anybody—the church choirs and the sports teams. They can look at other avenues in both government funding and private investment. But we are not talking about that; we are talking about these cooperative research centres and the money allocated for them. The Minister for Science, against world's best practice in comparable countries everywhere, is saying, `No, I'm going to give it to dirty coal to see if I can't clean that up, because I don't understand that coal is the problem, and I don't see that renewable energy coming from the sun—and, better still, recycled energy or efficiently used energy—are the answers.' What Mr McGauran is saying, inter alia, is, `I don't understand that the future of the economy in this country and around the world this century is going to depend on clean, green science, research and application, and that there are massive export dollars as well as hundreds of thousands of jobs to come out of Australia, being the sunshine country and being a leader in this field.'

This appalling inability to stand above the pressure of the coal industry is exemplified by the government and by the minister. I suppose in one way you cannot blame him, because these people have direct entree to Prime Minister Howard's office. Will the minister buck that? I think not; certainly not this minister. On Earthbeat on 8 May, Minister McGauran said:

quote.para: Coal or fossil fuels produce 95 per cent or more of Australia's energy needs.

speech.para: There is an indictment. He then said:

quote.para: We obviously, given our greenhouse gas concerns, want to apply low emission technology so of course it goes without saying that the majority of research would go towards the energy source for 95 per cent of our energy needs.

speech.para: Wrong, Minister McGauran—the 95 per cent should be going to replacing the use of coal, not to trying some untested technology to see whether you can make the coal and the burning of it clean. We have this phenomenal, world's best technology and we have magnificent researchers in this country—from Perth, to Hobart, to Canberra to Brisbane, all over the place—tapping into the sun's power and converting it into energy and heating, and this government is saying, `No, we want to give it to coal,' which produces 95 per cent of the energy needs of this country and is very close to 100 per cent of the greenhouse gas problem as far as energy production is concerned.

Mr McGauran is saying, `But it is quite sensible that fossil fuel research would be heavily supported but not to the exclusion of renewable energy.' But the minister has excluded renewable energy, so what is he about? He cannot explain his own policies. He has no analysis. He fundamentally cannot see what he, at his own hand, is doing by squeezing to death the cooperative research centres, which we should be proud of in this country and we should be promoting to the world.

Let us look at those figures again. Ten or 20 years ago, Japan, which is a much colder and less sunny country than this one, was producing one-fifth of the solar panels that we were producing. Now it is producing five times as many. I guess that Minister McGauran does not understand that that means Australia is slipping behind under his ministry. We are losing out, and with that we are losing enormous economic and employment benefits into the future. What could you expect, I guess, of a minister and a government that blocked in this chamber the Greens' Sun Fund Bill of a few years back? The bill would have allowed the diesel fuel rebate to be taken up by farmers and others in the bush and used not to burn diesel but to apply solar technology—including wind and photovoltaic power and hot water heating—to their isolated places in the bush to produce no greenhouse gases. It would have produced 50,000 jobs in the bush as well. And it was cost neutral; there was no extra cost to the taxpayers. This government blocked that in this house.
Mr McGauran tries to stagger on with patently wrong statements like:

quote.para: ... it's quite sensible that fossil fuel research would be heavily supported—

speech.para: I would put `by the government' in parentheses there—

quote.para: but not to the exclusion of renewable energy.

speech.para: What is to be done? I think all that we can do is continue to publish the process by which this muddle-headed thinking has come about. One of the problems here, of course, is that the advice going to the Prime Minister and to the minister is not good advice. I do not think the minister and the Prime Minister are making these things up off their own bat because I do not think they are competent to do so. The advice is coming from, amongst others, the Chief Scientist, Dr Robin Batterham. Of course, he has two hats. One is as chief technologist for one of Australia's biggest coal companies, and the other is as chief adviser, on the public purse, to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Science. It is a compromise position which is simply not acceptable. Whatever the Chief Scientist might say about having a firewall in his brain, it is not acceptable that he has these two conflicting positions. It is not acceptable that he sits on the board which determines the funding for cooperative research centres as far as energy and mining are concerned. There is an absolute conflict of interest there. It is quite remarkable that not only can the minister and the Prime Minister not see that but the Chief Scientist himself cannot see that. When you go to university, you may get high distinctions for all manner of things, including science, and a mortarboard and a certificate. You can get them for almost anything but commonsense. They do not issue them for commonsense.

talk.start.para: —They don't recognise it.

—They do not recognise it, Senator Campbell—you are right—and it is manifestly failing here. What we need is a board determining crucial matters like the research for the future of this country, what is in the public interest and the values that go with it. Senator Carr is quite right: how could they defund the rainforest research? To take the utilitarian, market fundamentalist point of view that this government espouses, does it know that half the pharmaceuticals in the world are coming out of rainforests? I do not think so. I think Mr McGauran would believe that they are somehow mixed up out of some magic ingredients left in the back of chemist shops and that that is where it all starts. He does not understand that they come from nature and that many of them come from rainforests and indeed from the ocean. This brings me to the next thing.

speech.para: Here is the remarkable Great Barrier Reef—the internationally celebrated World Heritage area, the greatest barrier reef and the greatest coral reef, in extent, in the world—which is beset by enormous problems, not least global warming coming from the coal stacks of the industry which the Prime Minister promotes, which causes bleaching and death of the coral reef, and also pollution, both land borne and coming from the oceans themselves. It is an enormously important economic asset for not just the region and Queensland but this nation. It is a hugely important natural asset for the whole world. But the government is defunding the research that is so essential to understanding it and to benefiting not just us but the coming generations.

The priorities here are absolutely unfathomable and insupportable. No argument that I have heard from the government speaker changes that, because there was no cogent argument as to why this should be happening. The Greens do support this motion. We are calling on the minister to take responsibility for the mess there is here and to use his powers and get better advice—some independent, alternative advice—to that which he is taking at the moment, because it is bad advice. We call on the minister to use his powers under the current CRC guidelines to hear appeals from those CRCs which have been cut out, where they apply for them. This is now becoming a matter of major public interest.

I also ask the government members who are here, and I put on the record a direct request to the Minister for Science, to produce the documents relating to the requests for funding of CRCs in this country—those that have been accepted and those that have been rejected and the appeal documents. Let us see them in the light of day. Let us test whether this motion is right or the minister is right.
