Let us have the fundamental information—in camera if there is commercial-in-confidence involved—upon which these maladroit decisions have been made. It is an appalling situation. It has to be rectified. There is every indication that it is simply going to get worse. The decisions this year are stonkering. They are absolutely against the national interest—the wider public interest—and action is required from the government to rectify the situation. That is why we support this motion.

talk.start.para: —Like other senators in this place have done today, I rise to condemn the Minister for Science and the Howard government for their mishandling of the Cooperative Research Centre Program. In light of the disastrous impact of recent decisions on North Queensland as a result of the government's failure to fund the reef and rainforest CRCs, I also call on the government for the immediate restoration of public interest research as a key criterion for CRC selection. It is my belief that the current selection process put in place as a result of the recent review by John Hamilton Howard should be abandoned. Labor will start again in office by using a fully transparent process which applies criteria—including public interest research—and applies them fairly.

speech.para: My colleague Senator Carr has given a detailed explanation of how things have come to this. I do not intend to go over that ground again in detail but let me say how appalled I am to see an aggregate of $200 million axed from the CRC Program. This decision completely flies in the face of the national interest when it comes to science. Australia's expenditure on R&D as a percentage of GDP has fallen dramatically under the Howard government at a time when our international competitors are ramping theirs up.

I was equally shocked to learn that 19 of the 52 applications in the current round of CRC selection had been rejected by the minister. The science community has been understandably critical of the handling of both the review and this round of the selection process—and quite rightly so. However, criticisms have not been limited to the science community. The former Liberal minister and national president Tony Staley, who is also president of the photonics CRC, has had a thing or two to say. I should point out that Mr Staley is also President of the CRC Association, which represents the interests of all of Australia's CRCs. He has labelled the minister's actions as `indefensible' and clearly he is a man with some clout around the place. I understand that when the photonics CRC next discuss the matter with the government they will be doing it with Dr Nelson rather than the Minister for Science.

Other criticisms of the CRC fiasco have come from within the government's own ranks. I turn to my local community of North Queensland and consider what the Herbert MP, Mr Peter Lindsay, had to say on this issue earlier this week in the other place. On the reef CRC's commercial focus he said:

quote.para: Its external earnings have doubled each year since it initiated a commercialisation strategy in 2001 ... CRC Reef is strongly supported by the marine tourism industry. With 47,000 people on the Queensland east coast working in reef based tourism, CRC Reef is seen by the public and me—

speech.para: that is Mr Lindsay—

quote.para: as the knowledge provider for GBRMPA, which protects the reef. CRC Reef has been successful in getting industry involved in research and it has industry support.

speech.para: Mr Lindsay is right. Mr Lindsay went on to say that the significant research, education and environmental consequences of this decision were dreadful. He said:

quote.para: CRC Reef currently supports 17 per cent of all graduate students at JCU. It is the largest single contract for JCU in its research earnings list, about $2.5 million a year. Any threat to the ongoing work of the reef CRC would bring a major loss of external earnings for JCU and the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Each year the CRC spends more with JCU than the whole of the AIMS@JCU budget. Finally, a major reduction in spending on research on Great Barrier Reef issues, including reduced support for the Prime Minister's reef protection plan and a large reduction in research support for GBRMPA at a time when its needs are increasing, cannot be seriously contemplated. I think there is universal agreement in the parliament in relation to that.
CRC Reef is creating a new generation of researchers who are accountable and respond to end user priorities.

speech.para: I do not often find myself agreeing with Mr Lindsay but I have to say he has hit the nail on the head. His bravery in speaking out on this issue is in stark contrast to his colleague the member for Leichhardt, Mr Warren Entsch, whose only contribution to the debate on Tuesday's MPI in the other place was to overstate his role in supporting the rainforest CRC. In the chamber on 11 May, his sole contribution to this important debate for our region, North Queensland, was to interject in Mr Lindsay's speech to say:

quote.para: We have been working closely with them.

speech.para: That is what Mr Entsch had to say during a debate on a matter of public importance about the retention of the rainforest and reef CRCs. That is the representation the people of Leichhardt have got from their member on the central matter of education and future scientific research in our region.

It is stretching the truth to say that Mr Entsch made a contribution because it is in contrast to what he said in Cairns. Mr Entsch was briefed by the rainforest CRC some three weeks before the decision and yet, when the decision was made public on 1 May, he waited until the middle of the following week to do anything. Then, despite waiting all that time, he had the temerity to write a letter to the editor of the local paper that was published on 5 May, which misrepresented the minister's capacity to be involved in the funding decision and slammed the Cairns Post for reporting the facts. In that letter, Mr Entsch claimed that the federal government values both reef and rainforest CRCs and that they stand a good chance for successful rebids in 2006.

That is a fabulous suggestion, Mr Entsch! That would leave them without any funding at all for important and ongoing research for a full 12 months—if they were to be refunded. That is not how science works. Scientists do not say: `I'll just take a bit of a holiday. I'll just put my feet up for 12 months. We'll just put the Petri dishes in the back cupboard. We'll let the rainforest crane rust for a little while and we'll come back in 12 months and maybe they'll give us the money.' That is not the way business operates and it is certainly not the way that science based CRCs operate.

Mr Entsch's claim that they will get funding under the new program is hollow indeed, because on the day after his letter was published the Prime Minister's new science package was announced. The package specifies that funding will only be provided for CRCs which will `have a stronger commercial focus'—the very reason that we are not being given funding for the reef and the rainforest CRCs. It is a hollow promise indeed. He is saying we will possibly get the funding under the new round, but the reason we did not get the funding under this round is that, ostensibly, our two CRCs are not commercial enough.

I can assure senators that Mr Entsch's insensitivity has gone down like a ton of bricks in our community, especially among those hardworking researchers and scientists, and their families, who are facing unemployment or the prospect of becoming suitcase scientists, unable to work in North Queensland as the Howard government's indefensible denial of funding is actualised.

The rainforest CRC conducts research which benefits the community and the environment. For example, it has done considerable work on feral pigs and climate change, and the reef CRC contributes greatly to the control of crown-of-thorns starfish and coral bleaching. The value of this world renowned research simply cannot be quantified commercially. The reef and the rainforest are not only important environmental assets to our region; they form the basis of our enormous tourism industry. Further, the opportunity for our young scientists to stay in the north is now greatly diminished. In fact, no new CRC will be based further north than Brisbane.

The brain drain from North Queensland is outrageous when you consider the comments made by Queensland's Chief Scientist, Professor Peter Andrews, on 19 April this year, in launching North Queensland's Innovation and Technology Week. Professor Andrews said:

quote.para: North Queensland has some unique advantages, its biodiversity and tropical location for example ...

speech.para: He went on that it has:

quote.para: ... great potential to use its research and development strengths to make major contributions to achieve lasting competitiveness for the State's new industries like biotechnology, but also our existing industries like agriculture, mining and tourism.

speech.para: He understands the importance of science in developing technology based and innovative companies and in encouraging careers in knowledge based industries and organisations; the Howard government clearly does not.

Not one government MP or senator has had the decency to stand up and explain what this means for the research effort of James Cook University. It has been put to me that two-thirds of James Cook University's research effort is associated with these two CRCs. No-one has explained what will happen to the fabulous research facility of the rainforest crane, which has been completely funded by the rainforest CRC. With that asset, scientists are undertaking groundbreaking research—completely new and novel research, research that has never been contemplated before. The crane can traverse everywhere from the ground to the top of the canopy, which is impossible to do without that sort of structure. The crane is completely funded by the Rainforest CRC and it stands to be closed down if the funding to the organisation does not continue.

No-one has explained what it will mean for the establishment of the Australian Tropical Forest Institute, which was to operate, in the main, as the commercial arm of the rainforest CRC. The Queensland government has committed $7 million to this project, and I now share the anger of those members of our business, education and science communities who have worked so hard to see this institute come to fruition and have developed this innovative concept and who must now feel as though they are watching a marvellous opportunity at grave risk of going to waste.

I must point out that this is not the only recent attack on science in the north by the Howard government. CSIRO has publicly announced that it intends to relocate the National Herbarium from Atherton, on the Atherton Tablelands, to Canberra—a course of action which is completely unacceptable to me and to the great majority of people in North Queensland. For us, the decision to deny funding to our internationally significant CRCs is just one more nail in the north's knowledge coffin. I, therefore, ask senators to join me in supporting Senator Carr's motion.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on Senator Carr's motion on the implementation of the current cooperative research centres selection round. It is interesting that out of the entire budget and area of education Senator Carr has chosen this topic. This shows how bereft the Labor Party are in finding targets for attack in what has been an absolutely outstanding budget. In my observation of politics over a period of 40 years, it is the best budget that has ever been delivered.

speech.para: The reason this government can deliver such a budget is our track record of economic success over the last eight years. The fact that we have delivered low inflation and high growth has meant that the tax revenues have boomed, and that has meant that this government can return that dividend to the people to help families, help businesses and develop innovative policies in aged care. We have the room to do it because this government produce surpluses. Let us contrast that with the last government. At my last count, the worst budget of the Keating government delivered a deficit of over $20 billion. Indeed, over his four-year term, he racked up government debt of $90 billion.

talk.start.para: —Like Mark Latham did at Liverpool council.

—You are quite right, Senator Abetz. The economic mismanagement of the Keating government was only exceeded by the economic mismanagement at the same time of Mark Latham at the Liverpool City Council. That was a little cameo perhaps: what he did for Liverpool he will do for the whole country. This would return us to the dark days of the Keating regime where there were massive deficits, there was no room for governments to move, programs were being cut and the role of government in assisting society was greatly hampered.

speech.para: That brings me back to the area of education being attacked, which is the CRCs. It is remarkable that Senator Carr has picked this particular target. It shows his lack of targets because, over the last two years, under the visionary leadership of Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, this country has had a revolution in the area of universities and research. The Crossroads review has delivered a change to education in the university sector that has set up this area of education in an excellent way for the 21st century. We now have universities that will be properly funded with a mix of private and public expenditure, again giving universities room to move as they develop their mission. Part of that mission is in the area of research.

Following the university review last year, and its implementation at the start of this year, the Howard government has moved on the agenda further by reform in the area of research and delivered another $5 billion into this area. This is point that Senator Carr does not make. Where are his comments about the visionary leadership of Geoff Garrett at the CSIRO and the flagship program that he inspired, which has been funded by this government? Where are Senator Carr's comments in relation to the ARC program, which they grossly underfunded? Under Backing Australia's Ability I, we doubled the funding of that program.

This government is a great supporter of research. We realise that research will return to the economy three- to five-fold the initial investment. It is not an expense for government. It is an investment in the future of Australia, because research quite often becomes applied and has outcomes that help benefit the economy. The only Labor minister who had any vision for this was Barry Jones, who was the minister for science in the early eighties under the Hawke government. He even wrote a book about it called Sleepers, Wake, which was about the way in which this country should develop research and use that as a driver of economic activity. The sleepers in the Hawke-Keating government stayed asleep. Whereas Barry Jones had a vision 20 years down the track for research, his cabinet colleagues had a vision of 20 months down the track to the next election and they did not back research. The tragedy for the Jones leadership in that area at that time was that, as a percentage of GDP, research actually declined. Under the Hawke-Keating government, research got a very bad deal. But they did come up with one good reform: the CRC Program. That has been rolled over into this government. It has been expanded and developed and it is the subject of the debate this afternoon.

I chaired a Senate committee at the end of that Keating government into where research was up to. That was where we identified that the CRC Program was so good and worthy of continued funding. The sad thing we found as we looked at research at the end of the Keating era was that there were many good programs in research in the universities and in the public institutions but they were not being particularly well funded. As a matter of fact, we found that you could double the funding in most of these areas and you would still get outstanding outcomes. One example was the Australian Research Council. We found in 1995 that only 17 per cent of the projects put up were funded and that 33 per cent of the projects were absolutely outstanding. What a waste and loss to Australian research and the Australian economy that those programs were lost. They were not funded because the last Labor government did not put enough money into research.

The CRC Program that was started by Mr Dawkins was one area that they did put adequate funding into. This program started in 1990. The idea was to fill a major hole in the research landscape in Australia, particularly in research and development and partnerships between research institutions and companies that might apply that research and produce commercial outcomes. I would like to remind Senator Brown and Senator Allison particularly that that was the purpose of the CRCs. They were meant to have a commercial outcome, mainly because that is where the big gap was in the research and development landscape in Australia. We had an excellent record in agricultural research and development. We had an excellent record in the area of mining. But when it came to the secondary and tertiary industries it was extremely patchy. Many of the big companies, particularly multinationals, preferred to do their research in other countries. To a large extent this was due to economies of scale, and they took a commercial decision and did a lot of this research elsewhere. I was heartened to learn that there are a lot of SMEs, small to medium enterprises, that do not ask for government grants because they do not want to be bothered with a lot of paperwork and they do the research anyway. So probably our research effort in the industrial area is a little bit understated in terms of its reporting.

Despite that, we still have a major gap in the area of research and development in secondary industry, and the CRCs have filled that void to some extent. But the whole idea was to have a commercial outcome. I want to illustrate that with one example that Senator Carr alluded to—and in doing so showed his total misunderstanding of the whole nature and process of CRCs—that is, the photonics cooperative research centre. The photonics centre for research in Sydney was basically aimed at developing high-performance optic fibre. I went to observe the centre first in 1994. It was located in a basement under the old medical school, which was leaking. The researchers were developing the high-performance optic fibre in a little lab, and they had some minor commercial applications at the time. The next time I went back was in 1997, and by that stage they had moved to the research and development centre in Redfern. They had a very large research and development organisation, and a number of spin-off companies were starting to develop. A lot of the academics at the university became product developers and commercial appliers of research, and a lot of them went on to create successful companies and made quite a bit of money.

The next time I saw them was at a dinner here in Canberra in 1999. They reported on the success of what they were developing, and the whole thing was continuing on its commercial orientation. That is what Senator Carr does not understand. That is what the CRCs were supposed to do. They were not supposed to stay on the public teat forever. The whole idea of a CRC is that you take your research, you move it through the development phase and the product phase and then you commercialise the product. That creates room for the development of other CRCs, and that means we can keep moving research through over a whole range of areas. That is the whole objective of this very robust CRC model. It is so robust that other advanced research countries, like France and Germany, are taking a hard look at our CRC model; they think it is a template for how you should do research.

That brings me to the question that Senator Carr raised in his criticisms this afternoon. He said that the current round of cooperative research centre selection has been `botched', to use his term. To say that funding has been denied to the reef, rainforest and photonics CRCs is untrue. Government figures on CRC funding reveal the following. The reef CRC has previously been successful in three selection rounds, most recently winning $3 million in supplementary funding in the 2002 selection round. The total CRC Program funding committed to the reef CRC since 1993 has been $30.355 million, and its existing funding agreement runs until June 2006. That sounds to me like another 2½ years and another two budget cycles.

talk.start.para: —Pretty strong commitment, isn't it?

—I think it is a very strong commitment. I acknowledge the contribution of Senator Santo Santoro from Queensland. We are discussing the reef CRC, which is in Queensland. The other CRC mentioned by Senator Carr was the CRC for tropical rainforest ecology and management, which has also been successful in the past three budget rounds. Its total CRC Program funding since 1993 has been $29.7 million. The current funding runs to 2006, yet again through another two budget cycles. The CRC for coastal zone, estuary and waterway management has also been successful in the past two selection rounds. Its total funding since 1998 has been $17.7 million. The contract of that CRC with the Commonwealth runs, yet again, to June 2006. Let us look more broadly at the current round of applications, rather than at just the three or four CRCs we have been focusing on this afternoon in this debate. For the 2004 CRC Program, 52 applications were received and individually assessed by an independent selection panel. From listening to Senator Carr, one would have thought he wanted to go away from that process. Maybe he would like a Ros Kelly style whiteboard approach!
—He doesn't respect the independent umpire.

—Senator Santoro is correct. We have an independent umpire system. We have an arm's length system. There has been criticism of the minister this afternoon, but he has set up an arm's length process for the determination of the applications. The applications were determined by that panel based on the criteria for the selection of CRCs. The panel deemed 19 applications to be unsuccessful because they were not competitive against the selection criteria. Labor has said it would fund three of these unsuccessful programs but has given no reason why it would fund those and not the other 16. We are yet to hear the rationale behind its approach or what criteria it would use—but presumably it would use the whiteboard approach and fund the programs of mates, which of course is a long-held tradition within the ALP.

speech.para: Under the current program, the success stories are from primary research areas as well as from cutting edge sectors such as vision technology, advanced composite structures, cochlear implants and molecular plant breeding. A focus on technology CRCs in this round is necessary, as environmental CRCs were the most successful in the 2002 round. This is something that Senator Allison and Senator Brown seemed to miss in their contributions. They just saw the CRCs as another way of funding environmental research. It does not matter how you do it or what the outcomes are; you are just funding environmental research. That is not the idea of the CRCs. The idea of the CRCs is the commercialisation of research. They must meet that criteria.

There are other avenues of research and there are other avenues of funding. There should be environmental research and there should be environmental funding. Indeed, under this government there is, but a lot of this is done through other programs. That is where Senator Brown and Senator Allison completely miss the point. This government is the most supportive government of research in the last century. We have seen its importance in terms of the development of the Australian economy. The CRC Program in the past has been a linchpin and will continue to be a linchpin of this type of research into the future.

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr moved a motion in the Senate this afternoon relating to CRCs, cooperative research centres, noting with concern the adverse effects of the government's botched implementation of the current cooperative research centre selection round and calling on the government to restore public interest research as a key selection criteria for future CRCs. There is a third section of his motion, which I will get to as I go through my contribution this evening.

speech.para: Cooperative research centres were established in 1991 under a Labor government. You have to rely on Labor governments to come up with new and innovative ideas, particularly when it comes to education and research and development. Nothing happens under this government. That section of portfolio development under this federal government has stagnated. Fifteen CRCs were established in 1991. There are now over 100. When CRCs were established in 1991 the minister for science said:

quote.para: Australia must match the technology push provided by its strong research base with the demand pull of industry and other research users.

speech.para: Despite Senator Tierney's contribution that CRCs are about the commercialisation of research, that was not in fact their purpose or reason for being established back in 1991. As the minister for science said at the time, it was to meet the demand of industry but also to provide research and work with other research users.

We know that research and development is used to stimulate economic growth. In this country it has been at the forefront and at the cutting edge of development, industry and science. In fact, it has been used to break through the mysteries and phenomena of different sciences. CRCs are about new ideas and solving problems. We have a number that are world class and recognised internationally. Research in our country has been front and centre of the world stage and has led new frontiers in all areas of science. Commitment to other research essentially means public interest research. When CRCs were established, as the minister, whom I have quoted, said at the time, they were to match the technology with other research users. Generally that has been meant to involve public research for public good. Commitment to other research has generally meant research that is in the public interest.

What does that mean? It means research that is currently being undertaken in relation to groundwater resource management, solar power and energy, biodiversity and hydrogen energy. It means world renowned centres that are unique to this country and the world, such as the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area CRC, the tropical rainforest ecology CRC and the coastal zone estuary and waterways management CRC. In Darwin we have the CRC for indigenous and tropical health and a CRC that has been established in Alice Springs, known as the desert knowledge CRC. These are CRCs that go to creating new ideas. They go to protecting our environment and managing our natural resources. They go to providing long-term sustainability. In the area of health and wellbeing they go to providing cures and preventative measures. They are for research in collaboration with other research users. They are for research in the public interest and for the good of the community.

But this government has walked away from the public interest research test and deserted the CRCs that provide that. We have seen that just in the last few weeks in the latest funding round. We have the farcical policy switch of the government that has left world renowned research centres out in the cold. How did this come to be? How did this happen? John Howard—an academic from New South Wales, not the actor or the Prime Minister—conducted a review and evaluation of the CRC Program in 2003 to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the CRC Program. I will provide some comments about some of the outcomes of that review. The document from that review says:

quote.para: The arguments for public involvement in industrial research are well rehearsed and it is not proposed to restate them in this Evaluation.

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: The point is that publicly supported collaborative research can deliver substantial benefits to the economy, industry, and the community over the longer term through the creation and application of knowledge that enhances international competitiveness ...

speech.para: It also goes on to say:

quote.para: There has been a profound change in Australia's research and innovation culture since the Programme was introduced. There has been, for example:
A widespread recognition of the role of public-private research ...
In the context of the “knowledge economy”, an acceptance of a role for the public sector in supporting new business development ...
A greater understanding of the contribution of science to the design and implementation of public programmes ...

speech.para: But, as you read through this document, you gradually come to the conclusion that this document is nothing more than a set-up. This document is nothing more than a number of pages that have been predetermined and cobbled together to provide this government with the platform on which it now justifies its funding of CRCs. Let me give you a perfect example. In this evaluation, it says:

quote.para: Given the changes in the industrial research and innovation culture referred to earlier, there would, however, be a strong expectation that more resources would be directed towards CRCs based on new business development involving the commercialisation of university and publicly funded research. Such re-direction would necessarily have regard to the quality of the “investment” proposals submitted.

speech.para: Therefore, one ought not be surprised to find that in fact the recommendation is:

quote.para: The CRC Program should continue, but with design modifications to reflect changes in the environment for public-private sector research collaboration and the creation of new business models for the commercialisation of publicly funded research, as identified and canvassed in this Report.

speech.para: What does that really mean? It means that, unless your research is going to drive the dollar, unless the research is going to benefit industry, forget it; this government will not look at it and will not fund it. So the evaluation that was conducted last year had a predetermined outcome. It was a set-up in order to allow the minister to have an excuse to change the guidelines of December. The evaluation was a reason to take a knife to these CRCs, which have a public interest research base, and to not fund them and put them, as we now find, on the list of casualties.

You cannot blame the committee for the recent announcements which the minister sought to make. He deliberately made changes to the focus and the guidelines so that he could pretend there was a legitimate excuse to take the funding away from the CRCs. So we have a predetermined scenario: we decide we want to change the focus from a public interest research base to a commercial base only, we set up an evaluation where the outcome is predetermined, we use that as a reason to change the guidelines and the funding outcomes—and there you go. The deckchairs are arranged in relation to research funding, and it all looks as though it is the fault of the evaluation and the committee that made the decisions. But it has been a set-up by this government from the very beginning.

Scientists now have to turn projects and their research into money-spinners. Research for the public good will no longer be funded as part of the CRC Program, which is worth $220 million. Researchers must now show that they can contribute substantially to this country's industrial, commercial and economic growth. So the government has narrowed the guidelines for CRC funding to ensure that there is a tighter commercial focus and that the focus of research in this country is entirely generated for a commercial outcome and is industry driven.

I believe that the decisions have been controversial and, in fact, are against the public interest and the public good test. What does that mean for the CRCs that are left—the CRCs in Aboriginal health, asthma research or research into bushfires? Will they in fact be next in the line of CRCs to be popped onto the casualty list? I add that those CRCs that have already made it onto the list are: the Australian Photonics CRC in Sydney, the CRC for satellite 2 systems, the aquifer CRC which looks at ground water resource management, the CRC solar biodiscovery, as I have said, and of course the fairly good and internationally renowned CRCs. But the CRCs for which the defunding has caused some controversy are those in Queensland related to the Great Barrier Reef, the rainforests and the coastal zones.

This government has not had a good and proud record of research funding under Prime Minister Howard-. Research funding in this country fails to maintain the government's spending, as a percentage of GDP. Since 1996 Australian expenditure on research and development has been well below the OECD average of 2.3 per cent of GDP, and Australia's share has declined while the OECD average and expectation in research funding has been rising. An example is that over the period between 2004--05 and 2010--11, Backing Australia's Ability 2 will in fact deliver $5.3 billion. Some people would believe that that is a quite extraordinary amount and it is. But if you were going to keep up with the percentage of funding on research compared to the amount that is spent according to the share of GDP, you would have to spend $5.9 billion. So the money that has gone into research under this government has not kept up with the 2.3 per cent share of GDP that has been expected internationally. Government-projected funding over the period is not likely to be sufficient to even cover the expected inflation rate and, therefore, it constitutes a real cut in government expenditure on the original research package. This simply means that this is a government that is treading water when it comes to the allocation of research funds in this country, rather than including additional funds that are needed to meet the challenges of the future and to maintain our position on the international research stage.

But wait, there is more. There has been a little bit of a hiccup in the minister's attempt to manipulate the funding outcomes of the CRC Program and its funding range. What he failed to remember was that he took the knife to the CRC that, in fact, is supported by his mates. The former federal Liberal Party President and former Fraser government minister Tony Staley went on the attack over the Howard government's termination of the world renowned photonics cooperative research centre. It is interesting to note that, on 27 May 2003 at a CRC Association dinner here at Parliament House, the Prime Minister had this to say:

quote.para: The CRCs success stories include ... the first all-Australian satellite in 30 years.

speech.para: He also said, back in 2001:

quote.para: An industry—

speech.para: that is, photonics—

quote.para: very much of the future as well as of the present and I know an industry that is going to bring employment and hope and excitement to the people of Australia into the future.

speech.para: So in 2001 and 2003 the Prime Minister understood the value of the satellite and photonics CRCs—in the recent past—but it seems that his memory has now gone a bit blank. We have even seen this government take a knife to a CRC that is supported by its mates. The current president of the photonics CRC, Mr Staley, described the defunding of the CRC as `indefensible'. An appeal has been lodged with the Minister for Science, Mr McGauran. Mr Staley said that the photonics CRC involved researchers from five states and territories and a $60 million contribution from universities and TAFEs, and he foreshadowed that more than $60 million would come from the private sector. But that is going to go; it will be gone. This government has rewritten the funding guidelines, and it has decided that this is one of the CRCs that is up for the chop and will not exist, if the government has its way. Of course, Minister McGauran said that the decision had been made by the Cooperative Research Centres Committee, and he said that he would stand by its decision. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 May Mr McGauran said:

quote.para: Arrangements have been made to meet with the CRC for Photonics as soon as possible. Until then I have no comment to make, except there is no provision for appeal in the program's guidelines, and that should be known by all applicants.

speech.para: But the minister is very wrong, and this is an issue that members of the government have failed to understand today. We are talking about a number of CRCs that are affected. The guidelines, which I have in front of me, specifically outline the role of the minister, and they say:

quote.para: The Minister for Science has overall responsibility for the CRC Programme.

speech.para: So it is within his power to not support the recommendations of the committee and to actually fund the CRCs. The guidelines state:

quote.para: The Minister decides which CRCs will be funded and the conditions of any funding offer. The final decision by the Minister will take account of the requirements of these selection guidelines and will be fully documented, including reasons for the decision.

speech.para: The guidelines also state:

quote.para: In deciding which CRCs get funded and what terms and conditions, if any, are attached to the funding offer, the Minister—

speech.para: again, all of the responsibility for this lies at the feet of the minister—

quote.para: may have regard to the advice of the CRC Committee arising from the assessment process and may take into consideration other matters including the application and related documentation.

speech.para: So the minister does not have to take the advice of the committee at all. He can actually decide to fund those CRCs that have currently made it onto the short list, those CRCs that are likely to get the chop—and at this stage we know that there are at least 11 of them. He can decide to ignore the wishes of the committee and to go ahead and fund them, but because this government specifically orchestrated a review of CRCs, then deliberately changed the guidelines—a farcical exercise in order to skew research in this country towards commercial, industry-driven outcomes rather than towards the public interest and the public good—he is not likely to do it. He should just come clean and say that the whole process has been totally manipulated.

The third part of Senator Carr's motion today, therefore, calls on the Minister for Science to take responsibility for the denial of funding to nationally significant CRCs such as the reef, the rainforest and the photonics CRCs, and to use his powers under the current guidelines—which he has and which I have just read into the Hansard for the benefit of people in the government and for the benefit of the minister in particular—to hear appeals from the CRCs against their exclusion from the current selection round.

This process has been manipulated by this government from go to whoa. This is a minister trying to blame everyone else—blame the committee; blame Mr Howard, who conducted the review—but he is not willing to take responsibility himself for the outrageous decision made in relation to defunding world-class cooperative research centres, particularly in Queensland and in Sydney, that are undertaking vital and important research in relation to our environment, alternative energies and maintenance of the community and in relation to the provision of diverse means through which we can look at water resource management, solar energy, satellite systems and maintaining the environment, particularly in the Great Barrier Reef and the tropical rainforests. Because these things are not commercially driven, because there is no commercial outcome to this and because there are no dollars attached to this that industry can hang its hat on, this minister is going to step away and not take any responsibility for this.

These are CRCs that have put in an appeal to the minister. He is denying he has responsibility under the guidelines to take any action. The guidelines clearly specify that there is a role for the minister, and the role of the minister is front and centre not only in advocating the funding but also in saving the CRCs by turning this decision around and saying, `We've made a mistake. We will re-fund those CRCs. We will give them the funding they deserve and put them back on the stage of the international research arena so that the efforts that we contribute globally and internationally can be maintained, recognised and appreciated not just by people in Queensland, Sydney and around this country but also by scientists and environmentalists right around the world.'

talk.start.para: —Listening to Senator Crossin, I have again become convinced that the Labor Party just cannot help itself. It lives by crying wolf over all manner of imagined ills and then it whinges when other people point out the flaws in the logic of its arguments—as speakers on this side of the Senate have done throughout this debate. Such is the case with the motion moved by Senator Carr that we are debating today and, indeed, the contributions of senators opposite.

speech.para: Senator Carr's motion proposes that the Minister for Science overrule the decisions made by an independent selection committee on the current round of funding for cooperative research centres. It asserts that the government has botched the implementation of the current round and calls on us to note this with concern. It also calls on the government to `restore public interest research as a key selection criteria'—I think it means criterion, Madam Acting Deputy President Kirk; and I am putting the whole thing in quotes, as befits fiction—`for future CRCs'.

Labor calls on the Minister for Science to take responsibility for the denial of funding to nationally significant CRCs such as the reef, rainforest and photonics CRCs and to use his powers under the current CRC guidelines to hear appeals from such CRCs against their exclusion from the current selection round. In short—and as other speakers and the minister have pointed out—Labor is seeking to politicise an independent process. Labor thinks it knows better than the experts—in fact, that has always been a particular and peculiar problem of the Labor Party—and because it thinks this is so it would like to trample on the independent decision making process that CRCs rely on.

In all, 52 applications were received for the 2004 selection round of the CRC Program, and the committee decided that 19 of these applications were not competitive enough against the selection criteria. This is a game of Labor bluff—political blindman's bluff, in fact, or perhaps it is another attempt by the Labor Party to pin the tail on the donkey. It missed. As I said yesterday—in the context of another Labor bluff: its policy for workplaces in this enterprising country wherein it wishes to hand them over to its preferred regulators, the unions—the sky does not fall or the earth reverse its orbit around the sun just because the Labor Party says it will if someone does something that is not to its taste.

According to Labor, the community is already bearing the brunt of the cuts in funding to cooperative research centres. Senator Carr would like us to believe that, right across the Great Barrier Reef, millions of coral polyps are ready to rise in revolt, egged on by the green lobby and Labor's obtuse political me-too-ism, because they will not be visited as often, they fear, by scientists being paid to research them. As Senator Tierney has said, that is absolute nonsense, because funding for that particular CRC does not run out until 2006.

We know this is all just politics on the part of the Labor Party. We know that this is a product of the ALP's `quick, find a platform' department. That is why Labor has done a rain dance over the minister's proper and sensible position that it is the job of the selection committee to select CRCs for funding from competing and competitive applications. That is why it has announced that it would fund three of the CRCs that were excluded by the selection process from the current round. That is why it will never say which of the successful CRC applicants in this round would be axed or how much money would be taken from the successful applicants to fund the three CRCs in the `Labor Choice' awards. I listened very carefully to the contributions from senators opposite, and not once did they display the courage to say which of the successful CRCs in the latest round they would deprive of funding. Until they start putting their money where their mouth is, honourable senators opposite cannot come into this place and insult the intelligence of senators—particularly those who are prepared to listen to them.

It is important for everyone to recognise that Australia needs more research that will lead to new and improved goods and services and additional economic activity. There are other funding opportunities—many of them—for research that is not directed towards new and improved goods and services and additional economic activity. The best public interest research is precisely that research whose objective is to produce economic gain and improve economic and social capabilities. That is in no way to decry or seek to diminish respect for the more esoteric varieties of research that Senator Carr, in his artistic motion today, apparently favours—along with his colleagues and attendant lobbyists.

But it is a question of priority. In budget week one would have thought that even the Labor Party would connect with reality—imperfectly perhaps, but nonetheless they would try—and with the fact that dollars are finite. We all know that `son of Whitlam' is playing with dodgy dollars today in the other place—no doubt his disciples in this place will be doing so, too, after the dinner break—but most sensible people are very well aware that dodgy dollars simply do not work. Those Australians who remember the first Whitlam and his three-year crash-and-burn collision with fiscal reality and responsibility have good reason to fear a prodigal return by the member for Werriwa.

In relation to the shred of reality that Senator Carr's motion attempts to cling to in this debate, it must be remembered that the majority of the 19 unsuccessful applications in this CRC round were new operations rather than CRCs that already exist. As we know, the unsuccessful solar CRC bid was in this category. The five unsuccessful applicants for 2004 round funding that were existing CRCs have secure funding for more than two years to come. Listening to Labor and others and their siren songs of distress, you would think that everyone involved had been instantly deprived of funding. That is not the case. If Labor valued honesty, it would stop seeking a shrieking headline and come back down from orbit.

I turn to the Queensland context. Obviously, as a senator for Queensland this is vitally important to me. It needs to be underlined here—again, as others have already done; in particular, Senator Tierney—that the CRC for the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area will receive $5.5 million in the next two years, taking the total it has received from the Commonwealth to $19.4 million. It is important to re-emphasise—and I do so very emphatically—that the CRC for Tropical Rainforest Ecology and Management will receive $5.6 million over the next two years, which will mean a total of $18.95 million over the seven-year life of the centre. It is important to again re-emphasise—and I do so emphatically—that the CRC for Coastal Zone, Estuary and Waterway Management will receive $6.6 million this year, taking its total from the taxpayer to $17.72 million.

While we are talking about important things to remember in this artificial debate that the Labor Party for political reasons has kicked along, let us remember these things, too. Great Barrier Reef research is also funded through the Australian Institute of Marine Science; CSIRO; the Australian Research Council; and several universities, including James Cook University. The Howard government is committed to supporting renewable energy research. As well as funding provided through the existing CRC Program, the funding commitments of the education, science and training portfolio to renewable energy research include Australian Research Council funding for renewable energy related research of $26.3 million over 2002-04 and government funding for CSIRO renewable energy research of $14.1 million between July 1998 and November last year. The R&D Start program administered by AusIndustry had funding commitments to renewable energy projects over the past two years of about $9 million. R&D tax concessions relevant to renewable energy totalled about $23 million in 2002-03. Let us remember those things during this debate.

In short, the government is very well aware of the continuing importance of research work into sources and technologies of renewable energy, and of the critical importance of the Great Barrier Reef as a unique living organism of which all Australians are the custodians. There is no monopoly on any side of politics on reasonable and reasoned environmentalism. So let us have no more of the sort of desperate and cynical hand wringing that we see from those opposite when in pursuit of a vote.

Queensland is also the home of a lot of world-leading medical research. The Howard government supports that and will continue to support it. As honourable senators will be aware, Queensland leads the world in many aspects of tropical medicine, among other disciplines in the world of medical science. This leadership has been enhanced by the Howard government's strong commitment to both excellence and independence in research. We on this side of the chamber simply do not believe in guided research any more than we believe in guided democracy of the sort that Labor invariably tries on whenever it is in power.

We believe in the power of the human mind, unfettered by the constraints on freedom imposed by Labor picking winners—or not, as is generally the case—and free to go where it will in pursuit of excellence or answers or the genius of great research. That is why, for example, the Howard government is always ready to be innovative in its own policy research and development and implementation. I hear lots of feedback from the research community in Queensland, and I have to tell senators opposite I do not hear many cries of anguish from the people who run productive and, I stress, results-oriented research funded by government money.

In fact, the reverse is the case: the Howard government listens very carefully and acts accordingly. That is why, for example, the new science and innovation package—which was belittled by Senator Crossin a few minutes ago—called Backing Australia's Ability: Building Our Future through Science and Innovation, which is worth $5.35 billion over seven years, is such a great program. That package was announced by the Prime Minister last week and, like much else that comes from the Prime Minister and our government, it is a carefully coordinated multiportfolio operation that builds on past success. That is what government is about: delivery; sound policy; and sensible, properly funded outcomes. It is not about running around in circles like headless chooks shouting, `We'll all be rooned'. Senators opposite might like to note that.

I respectfully suggest to Senator Carr, and I note that he is in the chamber, that his motion is a disgrace. It does not adorn the Notice Paper, it stains it. It is simply not acquainted with fact. It derives from the poisoned well of underachievement in policy development. Labor has no ideas, so instead it makes a lot of noise. The new Backing Australia's Ability package builds on the original $3 billion policy announced by the Prime Minister in 2001. And in the context of Labor's sad little exercise here today, it is worth repeating what the package also provides in funding for important new initiatives. These are only examples; senators opposite might like to inform themselves by studying the full package.

There has been $305 million provided for CSIRO on top of its base funding in order to support large-scale collaborative research projects in areas of national importance such as preventive health, food and agriculture, water and the environment, light metals production, new energy technologies and Australia's oceans. Infrastructure support to Australia's medical research institutes—including the Queensland Institute of Medical Research—has been allocated $200 million. I pay a particular tribute to that magnificent research institute based in Queensland, and I see the Special Minister of State, Senator Abetz, nodding because I have often explained to him the value of supporting that particular institute. This funding will assist institutes to underpin research conducted with National Health and Medical Research Council grants.

There has been $38.8 million designated for new initiatives connecting schools with local industry groups and universities in order to inspire school students about science and mathematics. And $7.2 million is being provided for a new unit in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to coordinate and focus R&D to support Australia's counter-terrorism needs. These are practical, forward-looking and innovative elements that support practical science and new technologies. Against that record of solid achievement, Labor's sorry effort with this motion today stands exposed for the sham and fraud that it and its authors represent.

In conclusion, I cannot let part of the contribution by Senator Crossin go by without passing further comment on it. She suggested that this government is somehow prepared or able to interfere and that somehow the program of selection of CRCs is flawed. She comes into this place and says that the CRC that is associated with Tony Staley—a very distinguished Australian and a former member of this parliament—has somehow not received funding, that the government should intervene and that even Tony Staley is criticising it.

talk.start.para: —That is what he says; he says it's indefensible!

—That proves the point that this government does not interfere with the independent umpire. We have respect for the independent selection committee, and for you to come in here and try to coax us into doing the sort of thing that you would do in government—
—It's a fiasco!

—as previous ministers have done with a whiteboard—is a disgrace. It is the epitome of outrage when you come in here and you openly encourage us to favour our mates, our friends and former Liberal ministers.
—You have no trouble with anyone else!

—In a barefaced manner, you come in here—God help this country if you ever have the chance and the opportunity to interfere and meddle in the way that you are suggesting that we do. I could not let that particular point that was made by Senator Crossin—
—I'll send you a copy of the speech.

—I have heard the interjections by members opposite, and I do not need the speech because I have actually listened to it. Unless you wrote it, Senator Carr, you were not listening to it. I actually listened to it, and the point that I am making is that the sentiment behind Senator Crossin's speech is encouraging us to overrule the independent umpire. We are not in that sort of business. We have mechanisms that help run a government that is accountable, that is honest and that is wise. That is the reason why this debate in the Senate tonight will be viewed with great amusement by the people that you are seeking to represent, who know that credibility in the debate does not belong to your side of the argument.

—In the 30 seconds that I have available in this debate, I simply want to say this: last week we saw the biggest research and innovation package announced in Australia's history. Backing Australia's Ability was the biggest step this nation has taken towards a sound future in research and development. The mob opposite tonight are trying to distract attention from that major and appropriate step in the right direction by starting a fire fight on the fringes, pretending that they have got backing for these important issues in Australia's future. They have not. Nobody is fooled; we know what they are doing and so do Australia's researchers and developers. (Time expired)

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.00 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Minchin:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to incorporate my response to the budget speech.

speech.para: Leave granted.

For the past five months Mark Latham has been travelling around this great country of ours as Labor Leader, talking to the Australian people about their concerns. Mark says it's been the experience of a lifetime.
Mark Latham has been holding community forums: old-town-hall style meetings, open to all comers.
Thousands have come along to have their say—community leaders, school teachers, small businesspeople, mums, dads and students.
Mark Latham calls these meetings “democracy in the raw”—a chance to listen and learn, a chance to talk to people face-to-face.
It's an important process, because as parliamentarians we need to be honest with ourselves. The Australian people have become disillusioned with the political process.
We have lost their trust and confidence. And we need to regain it.
Listening to people and addressing their concerns. Staying in-touch with the real-life circumstances of the Australian people.
Tonight Mark Latham is bringing those concerns and circumstances to Canberra. This is what the people have been telling him.

On the Central Coast of New South Wales they told him about the need to create new training and employment opportunities for the youth of the district. Plus put them in contact with mentors—role models who can point troubled teenagers in the right direction.
At Gladstone in Central Queensland they told him about the need for more apprenticeships and group training opportunities—workforce skills for the next generation.
In Brisbane, Mark heard about the need for bulk-billing doctors and a national dental program—something positive to help our senior citizens get their teeth fixed up.
In Adelaide, he heard about the problems in the social security system: family debts and disincentives for people who want to move from welfare to work.
In the La Trobe Valley and Gippsland, they told him about the loss of basic services, particularly in higher education and Medicare.
At the community forum in Bairnsdale, one man summarised what Mark had been hearing all over the country. He said that people were coming forward with “cries for help”.
Cries for increased social investment and better services.
Cries for stronger communities and more lasting relationships.
Cries for a fairer society—where by working hard and pulling together, we can give all Australians a fair go.
Australia needs a government that answers this cry for help—a government that invests in its people and builds the services of a civilised society.
After 20 years of economic reform—some of it Labor, some of it Liberal—our wealth and prosperity have grown.
But surely as a nation, we can make better use of our wealth. We can give it a stronger social purpose.
We can use it to restore our services and rebuild our communities. We can answer the cry for help.
This is what the Australian people are saying: it must be prosperity with a purpose.
Surely in a prosperous nation we shouldn't have 370,000 Australians on unemployment benefits for more than 12 months many of them young people, without hope and direction in their lives.
Surely in a prosperous nation we shouldn't be losing bulk-billing doctors and Medicare services—the universality of our health system.
Surely in a country like Australia we shouldn't have children failing ill with serious diseases because their parents can't afford the vaccines.
Surely in a prosperous nation we shouldn't have 500,000 Australians, most of them elderly, waiting to get their teeth fixed.
That's the problem with the current government. It's a waiting list government that's turned us into a waiting list nation.
It's got the wrong set of priorities. It's wasting our prosperity instead of turning it into opportunity for all Australians.
Just look at Tuesday's budget. It's a political patch-up job, a short term fix for the next election. It doesn't look to the long term, the sort of future we want for our nation a decade from now.

The Government always spends up big before an election. But then it claws the money back in the years that follow-through higher taxes and family debts, higher Telstra line charges and user pays in education and health. It gives and then it takes. It never lasts.
Tonight I want to outline Labor's alternative approach—the policies and priorities we believe are important for our country—the things we didn't hear about in the Budget.
Labor has been listening to the Australian people, absolutely. But not just listening. We have been responding to their concerns with a new plan for the nation, a new program of social investment.
Investing in early childhood development, in our schools, universities and TAFE colleges. Investing in our doctors and dental services. Investing in families and newborn babies.

And not just social investment. Labor believes in investing in the environment, passing on our natural assets and heritage to the next generation. Taking climate change seriously—ratifying the Kyoto Protocol and establishing an emissions trading system. New national policies to save the Murray/Darling, to protect our native forests, our beaches, our coastline.

And when it comes to national security, Labor will never, neglect the homefront. Always, Australia first we'll establish a Department of Homeland Security, upgrade our port and regional airport security and create an Australian Coastguard—maritime policing for our 37,000kms of coastline.
This is the future for our nation: services, conservation, security. Opening up new opportunities—not just now, but for the next 10 years.

When Mark Latham became Leader of the Opposition, he said that he wanted to be positive. He said that he didn't believe in Opposition for Opposition's sake. So let me outline Labor's positive alternative, our plan for Australia's future.

Our starting point is better Budget management. The Howard-Costello Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. There is no shortage of funds pouring into Canberra. Our task is to make better use of this money: to cut waste and mismanagement, to reorder priorities.

While the Government has gone on a spending spree, Labor has taken a different approach. For every dollar of extra social investment, we've been making a dollar of budget savings—cutting back on government waste. So far, we have identified more than $8 billion in savings, with more to come.
In this Budget, the Government is spending more than 100 million on taxpayer-funded political advertising—spending for the Liberal Party, not the Australian people.

It also plans to sell Telstra, wasting $650 million on consultants and financial advisers. Under Labor, we'll be saving the taxpayer money. We'll be keeping Telstra where it belongs: in majority public ownership.
A Labor Government will reduce bureaucracy, abolishing seven government agencies and cutting a further 13 government programs. And as we examine this Budget, more cuts will be made.
Not all of these decisions will be popular. Some interest groups will inevitably complain.
But the decisions need to be made. Budgets are about choices. And Labor's choice is to cut bureaucracy and wasteful spending to make way for our investments in education and health.
This is also responsible economic policy. A Labor Government will produce budget surpluses in each year of the next Parliament—cutting net debt and holding down interest rates.

We also believe in limiting the size of government. Too much spending, too much bureaucracy is bad for the Australian economy. This is why we will reduce Commonwealth expenditure and Commonwealth taxation as a proportion of GDP.
This is our Budget Pledge to the Australian people. Social investment, Yes, but also an attack on waste and mismanagement.
We also want to grow the Australian economy through more assistance for small business—backing their hard work and enterprise.

We need to reduce red-tape and paperwork, starting with the Business Activity Statement. This involves huge compliance costs—small businesspeople filling out forms for the government, instead of spending time with their families or actually running their businesses.

This is why Labor will simplify the Business Activity Statement. Our Simpler BAS Option will allow small businesses to use a Tax Office ratio to calculate their quarterly GST payments, with no annual or quarterly reconciliations.
This method couldn't be simpler, with just one calculation and just two boxes on the BAS form. It is estimated that our policy will reduce compliance costs by 80 to 90 percent.

Labor will also ensure that small businesses are not smothered by the market power of big business. We want a fair trading environment—strengthening the Trade Practices Act and the ACCC to protect small business against anti competitive practices.

Labor will outlaw predatory pricing and introduce gaol terms and divestiture powers to deal with hard-core cartels. The ACCC will be authorised to issue “cease and desist” orders to provide immediate relief against market abuse. It will also be given new powers to deal with creeping acquisitions and the exploitation of franchisees.

The Trade Practices Act is now 30 years old. It urgently needs an overhaul—new powers to protect small business against the anti-competitive conduct of big business. It's time to give the small business sector a fair go in the Australian marketplace.

Mark Latham has always believed in governments helping people providing opportunity for all Australians. But he also knows that people should be willing to help themselves—to work hard, to exercise responsibility. There is no way out of poverty and disadvantage without having a go, without effort.
This is what Mark Latham calls the ladder of opportunity the importance of hard work, strong communities and the civilising role of government.

Mark Latham wants all Australians climbing the ladder—getting stuck in and working hard, supported by decent community services. The Howard-Costello Government has been irking the rungs out of the ladder. Mark wants to put them back in.

The first rung is education—investing the skills and ability of the Australian people. Under the current Government, this has been an area of big budget cuts. Under Labor, it will be our most important area of social investment.
Our national reading program will help parents give their infant children the greatest gift of all: reading books aloud, building literacy in the early years.
The parents of each newborn child will receive a series of storybooks. And for parents who lack the skills to read them, Labor will provide new adult literacy services to overcome this problem.
We want to invest early in education. Learning doesn't start the first day of school. It starts the first day of life.
And when our children go to school—with a love of reading and the ability to recognise numbers—their schools must be high-achieving schools.
It doesn't matter whether they are government or non-government schools. That's a tired, old debate. We want quality and opportunity for all our students.
Under Labor's new funding system, all schools will be funded on the basis of need. We will bring every school up to a high national standard of resources and achievement.

The overall funding level for non-government schools will be maintained, but with a different pattern of funding distribution. Under-resourced Catholic, Christian and Independent schools will receive more, at the expense of wealthy schools like Kings and Geelong Grammar.

We will also provide additional funds for government schools—lifting them up to our national standard of resources and results. For the most disadvantaged parts of our society, they have one great hope in life: the neighbourhood government school at the end of their street. It's their passport out of poverty.
As Prime Minister, Mark Latham won't rest until that hope is fulfilled. Until every school in this country is a good school.
A Labor Government will provide incentives for the best teachers to teach in our struggling schools.

We will also improve school discipline through mentoring, community justice and `time out' programs. Parents have got the right to have their children taught in an orderly school environment. Discipline isn't an optional extra. It's an essential part of a good education.

And at the end of the school years, we don't want any talented child who has worked hard and studied hard to have to pause for a moment to consider whether they can afford a higher education. It goes against the great Australian principle that rewards in life should flow from talent and hard work, not your bank balance.

That's why we'll implement Labor's $2.3 billion Aim Higher policy: 20,000 extra university places and 20,000 extra TAFE places, without the need for slugging students. We'll reverse the Government's 25 per cent HECS hike and abolish its full fee system.
We don't want $100,000 university degrees. We want opportunity for all—a pathway to excellence in education.
But still, not every young Australian will take advantage of these opportunities. We need to reduce the school drop-out rate and tackle the crisis in youth unemployment.

Each year in Australia we waste the skills of 45,000 young people who leave school early and don't go on to full-time work or study. They're at risk of becoming a lost generation—dropping out of the system, dropping out of society.
In some communities, the problem is critical: youth unemployment rates of more than 30 per cent in places like Wollongong, the northern suburbs of Adelaide and Wide Bay in Queensland.
As a society, we cannot afford to waste the potential of so many young Australians. We must give them new opportunities to work and to develop their skills.
But so too, we need to demand from them a new level responsibility—making good use of the education and employment services of government. Working hard and having a go.
Tonight we can announce that a Labor Government will create a Youth Guarantee: young Australians either in employment or education and training.
Under our policy, young people will have just two options: they can be either learning or earning. No third option of sitting around doing nothing.

We'll provide additional work and training opportunities. And young people will be obliged to participate, to do something good for themselves, their families and the community. Learning or earning—no third option.

A Labor Government will abolish TAFE fees for all secondary school students—a financial benefit for these students and their families. This policy will also encourage an extra 15,000 students to stay on and undertake vocational education and training while still at school.
We'll also create 7,500 new apprenticeships. Plus 7,500 TAFE places for 15 to 18 year old students.
For those who want to move into work, we'll create a Jobs Gateway—wage and training subsidies to give 10,000 early school leavers opportunities in the workforce.
And we'll also support 5,000 homeless and disadvantaged youth, with life skills and training opportunities.

So we say to young Australians: if you fall, we will pick you up. We will help you, but we also expect you to help yourself: to respond to our Youth Guarantee, to be hungry for new skills and employment.

The Youth Guarantee is a $700 million investment in solving one of our most pressing social problems the youth problem. It's a long term investment in Australia's future, a chance to give our prosperity a true social purpose.
Our policy involves the employment of 1,100 Training Mentors, working directly with young people at risk of dropping out. The mentors will help with education and employment, but also social skills.

We should never forget this social dimension in helping young Australians—giving them a sense of belonging and purpose in their lives. We need mentors right across the community—role models who can teach troubled teenagers the difference between right and wrong.

This is why a Labor Government will establish a National Mentoring Foundation, providing training support and other resources for 10,000 new mentors. We will also bring thousands of extra men into our schools—male teachers and community leaders to assist with the development of boys.

Another rung on the ladder of opportunity is health care. Medicare must be a universal system, with good public hospitals and bulk-billing doctors available across the country. If it's not universal, it's not Medicare.
The Government talks about a safety net. But you don't need a safety net unless you've turned the health system into a highwire act and families are in danger of failing off.
Labor doesn't believe in a safety net. We believe in Medicare. And we'll never give up on increasing the rate of bulk-billing. We want it at 80 per cent:
Increasing the patient rebate by $5 for every bulk-billed consultation.
Providing incentive payments of up to $22,500 for doctors who reach bulk-billing targets;
And making more doctors and nurses available in regional Australia.
In areas where bulk-billing has collapsed, a Labor Government will provide Medicare Teams—salaried doctors and nurses to deliver bulk-billing through public hospitals and community health services.

There's another responsibility we'll meet in the health system: the provision of dental services. It's not just a moral responsibility it's part of the Australian Constitution. If the current government won't carry out its duty to the Australian people, Labor will.

We'll create a national dental program: a $300 million investment with an extra 1.3 million dental procedures for aged pensioners and health card holders. This will clear away the existing backlog and give our senior citizens what they deserve: the care of a civilised society in getting their teeth fixed up.
The Government says this is a Budget for families, But without a decent health system, what guarantees do we have for the future of our families?
Every year in Australia 1,800 children contract the deadly pneumococcal disease. Today Mark Latham met one of the affected families—the Brooks family from Canberra.

On Anzac Day, their 15-month-old daughter, Bella, was diagnosed with pneumococcal, and began a fortnight-long battle for her life. Fortunately, young Bella is now out of danger and recovering well. But that's not always the case. Every year in Australia 50 babies don't survive this disease.

In an attempt to save lives, the Government's expert advisory group has recommended that a new vaccine against pneumococcal be made available to every baby free of charge. Yet this Government, in all its meanness, has refused.

Why can't it see the compassion and commonsense of this policy—saving the lives of children like Bella Brooks? The vaccine costs $500 and many families simply can't afford it. They're having to make a choice between their limited finances and the health of their children.
Nothing could better illustrate why our health system must never become a two-tiered system. Why Medicare has to be saved. A universal system, not a welfare system.

Nothing could be more important in the creation of a good society than funding this essential vaccine. That's what Labor will do in government, making it available to every Australian child free of charge. Our babies can't afford to wait any longer.
Another rung on the ladder of opportunity is the balance between work and family—spending decent time with our children, nurturing the next generation of young Australians.
Let me congratulate the Government on introducing a new Baby Care Payment—$3,000 for working and non-working mothers to help ease the financial pressures of a new bub in the home.

Labor announced this policy two months ago, so we're glad to see it in the Budget. And I hope the Government also adopts Labor's policy to spread the payment over at least three months rather than pay it as a lump sum.
It's like the reform of parliamentary superannuation. It doesn't matter where good ideas come from—Labor or Liberal—let's get them done for the benefit of the Australian people.
A Labor Government will take this agenda further. We'll improve the rights of working parents, especially their ability to return to part-time work after having a child.
In government, we'll also overhaul and improve the tax and family assistance measures in this Budget.
When he was first elected, the Prime Minister promised to govern for all of us. In this Budget, he's forgotten about most Australians.

He's forgotten about the hard-workers on less than $52,000 a year the sales reps, the technicians, the shop assistants, the teachers, the office workers (the backbone of the Australian economy)—who expected tax relief in the Budget but got nothing. Not one red cent.
For them, last year's sandwich and milkshake looks like a feast.
Since 1996 the average Australian household is paying an extra $9,000 in Federal taxes. Yet in this Budget four out of every five families and singles have missed out on a tax cut.
They've been forgotten by the Government, but not by Labor. We will implement a bigger program of tax relief. A broader and fairer tax plan for the future.

That's the best way of growing the Australian economy—giving people incentive and reward—for effort. Ensuring that the hard workers—the people who do the overtime, the families with two or three jobs—receive a decent return on their work.

Prior to the next election Labor will be announcing our tax plan for Australia—a broader and fairer plan. Fairer for low income earners. Broader for middle Australia. A tax policy that puts incentive and productivity back into the Australian economy.

This Budget introduces three new taxes that affect business. Labor has a policy for a tax cut: to the superannuation contributions tax. We'll reduce the rate from 15 to 13. We want retirement savings to work for the retirement years, not be eaten up by taxes, fees and charges.
And we don't support the Treasurer's policy of `work till you drop'. Labor will always protect the aged pension and the superannuation system.

For families, the Government has produced a policy for the next election, not a plan for Australia's future. The new lump sum payment is compensating families for bad government policy—its inability to overcome the family debt crisis.
