To sum up, the overall outcome of the deal struck between the Howard Government and the United States has been left with an overwhelming feeling of uncertainty about the future impact on the broadcasting and film and television sector now and in the future.

Many in the industry have commented that it is not the next couple of years that full impact of the AUSFTA will be most notable—but over the next 5-10 years as technology emerges, the gap between local content actually shown on all formats and overall broadcast time in Australia will get far wider.

It is important to note, that in the Australian Film and Television industry, production of Australian Feature Films has plunged by one-third, down from 30 to 19 in 2002-2003 and that expenditure on feature film and drama production is also down by 23% to $513 million in a period of just 12 months.
It is because of this downturn and rising unemployment in the production sector that the AUSFTA is causing even greater concern for film and television stakeholders.
Ultimately local content quotas across free-to-air and Pay TV Quotas serve to ensure investment in Australian Feature film and television production.
This continued investment is critical to ensuring that Australian voices and faces are both heard and seen on Australian screens.

The tricky spin emanating from the Howard Government has worked hard to distort any impartial analyses about exactly what AUSFTA means for the Film and Television sector and indeed the broader cultural community.
Rumours are rife about organisations getting heavied by the Government to make favourable comment or to say nothing.

Let it not be forgotten that this uncertainty is a direct result of the Howard Government's failure to obtain a broad reservation for the cultural sector and consequently, many important mechanisms which are essential to ensuring the growth of Australian film and television are to be restricted under the proposed Agreement.
The Labor Party is seeking to clarify all of these issues raised through the Senate Select Committee on the Australian United States Free Trade Agreement.
This committee provides THE ONLY opportunity for the Australian people to delve into the detail and assess its impact.

It is important to note that Labor is not opposed to Free Trade, but we have reserved making a decision on whether we will support the Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement until after the Senate Select Committee reports on 12th August this year.
The recommendations arising from this report will shape Labor's position on AUSFTA and whether we will support changes to existing legislation required to implement the agreement.
The Howard Government has not yet indicated when they propose to introduce these legislative changes.
There is no doubt however about the trickiness the Howard Government has employed to get this deal signed.
What remains to be seen is just how much has been deliberately withheld from the Australian people about the perceived `benefit' to our nation.

Slightly removed from previously discussed issues but of much importance is the extension of Copyright from 50 to 70 years. While Labor has not expressed an opinion on this in terms of the cultural sector, it is important that we delve into the issues for Libraries and educational bodies.

The extension which the AUSFTA for which copyright payments must be made from 50 years after the death of the author to 70 years, in line with US law (article 17.4), is going to be costly for libraries and educational bodies, as Australia has adopted the US copyright standard without the US's more generous rules for copying for research and education purposes.
The Australian Fair Trade and Investment Network Ltd (AFTINET) had some particularly interesting comments which could be investigated further:

“Copyright law is supposed to provide a balance between fair rewards for authors and excessive protection which raises prices. The Australian Intellectual Property and Competition Review Committee recommended that copyright not be extended without a public inquiry. The USFTA denies us this public debate.”

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 July 2003:

question.para: (1) (a) How many personnel recently deployed to Iraq were in payment of a Department of Veterans' Affairs disability pension, under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; and (b) at what level.
(2) What physical and medical examinations were conducted prior to departure of each person deployed to Iraq.
(3) In the event that there is conflict between the medical assessment and the compensation assessment, what action has been or will be taken.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has advised that 97 veterans of the Iraq deployment were in payment of the general rate of disability pension under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. No personnel were paid the intermediate or special rate of disability pension.
(b) The level of the general rate of disability pension paid to personnel deployed to Iraq was:

(2) Defence processes are designed to ensure personnel are fit for operations. The objective of the Annual Health Assessment and the five yearly Comprehensive Preventive Health Examination is to confirm continuing good health and fitness for deployment. Australian Defence Force personnel must be Medical Employment Category 1 or 2, have a current Annual Health Assessment or Comprehensive Preventative Health Examination and have been found medically fit for deployment or seagoing service before they are permitted to deploy on operations. Annual Health Assessments or Comprehensive Preventative Health Examinations that fall due during the deployment period are conducted prior to departure. Additionally, personnel undergo another medical check within seven days of deployment to confirm their medical readiness, that is, no recent illness or disability and confirmation of their vaccination status. Members who are Medical Employment Category 3 or 4 are not deployed.

(3) At present, personal medical documents maintained by Defence do not contain Department of Veterans' Affairs compensation assessments. Under the Military Compensation and Rehabilitation Bill, which passed through Parliament on 1 April 2004, the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission will provide the relevant Service Chief with a copy of both a serving Australian Defence Force member's claim and the resultant Commission determination on that claim.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Broadcasting Authority: Commercial Television Code of Practice
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2551)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Does the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) check whether commercial television stations comply with regulated advertising limits; if so, how does it do this.
(2) Are all broadcasters checked for compliance 24 hours a day.

(3) When an advertising pop-up box appears during a program, advertising a forthcoming television series, for example, does the ABA include this as advertising for the purposes of advertising time restrictions; if not, why not.
(4) Does the ABA include commercial promotions which appear within programs as advertising for the purpose of advertising time limit restrictions; if not, why not.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) & (2) The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 establishes a co-regulatory scheme for broadcasting, whereby industry sectors, including commercial television, are required to develop a Code of Practice that must be registered by the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) if it meets certain statutory requirements.

Under the co-regulatory scheme, licensees are required to comply with the provisions of the Code. If there is a concern that a licensee has not complied, a complaint can be made to the licensee. If the complainant is not satisfied with the licensee's response, the complaint can be referred to the ABA for investigation. This is the primary method of ensuring compliance with the Code.
The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice specifies the amount of non-program matter that may be broadcast in every hour. Licensees must comply with the Code at all times.

(3) The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice specifies the amount of non-program matter that may be broadcast in every hour. Section Five of the Code goes into substantial detail as to whether non-program matter is considered exempt or non-exempt for the purposes of the hourly non-program matter quota.

Whether material is classified as non-program matter and counted towards the quota, or exempt non-program matter and excluded, depends on the specific nature of the material. For example, clause 5.5.7 of the Code specifies that “superimposed text or visual matter occupying only part of the screen during a program” is exempt non-program matter.

However, clause 5.4.3 of the Code specifies that non-program matter includes “a program promotion that is scheduled within a program break or between programs, or in the form of superimposed text or visual matter that occupies all of the screen during a program.” Clause 5.4.3.2 further adds that “this includes material of any length which promotes a program or programs broadcast by the station, or which promotes the station of its activities.”

(4) The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice specifies the amount of non-program matter that may be broadcast in every hour. Section Five of the Code goes into substantial detail as to whether non-program matter is considered exempt or non-exempt for the purposes of the hourly non-program matter quota.

Whether material is classified as non-program matter and counted towards the quota, or exempt non-program matter and excluded, depends on the specific nature of the material. For example, clause 5.4.2 of the Code specifies that non-program matter includes “advertising of the kind specified in clause 5.4.1 of the Code, but which takes the form of superimposed text or visual matter occupying all of the screen during a program.”

However, clause 5.5.5 of the Code specifies that exempt non-program matter includes “a shopping guide, infomercial or similar material, in which the presentation of advertising and information of general interest is an integral part of program or segment.”

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What are the ramifications for Australia Post of the proposed free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States of America.

(2) Are there any obligations in the FTA for Australia Post to: (a) be privatised; (b) be opened up to foreign ownership; (c) deregulate any of its reserved services; and (d) face any other form of increased competition.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States does not impose any specific financial or operational requirements on either party to the agreement.
(2) (a)-(d) There are no obligations in the agreement for any of the matters in (a)-(d).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How many community mail agents (CMAs) were there as at 1 January 2004.
(2) How many community postal agents (CPAs) were there as at 1 January 2004.
(3) Are there any community mail and/or postal agencies being run in conjunction with a Rural Transaction Centre.
(4) Were any Licensed Post Offices converted to CMA/CPA operations during the 2003 calendar year; if so, can details be provided.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice received from Australia Post:

answer.para: (3) There are five Community Postal Agents who also host a Rural Transaction Centre.
(4) There were two instances in 2003 where it was necessary to replace a licensed operator with a Community Postal Agency:
Glenorchy (VIC) in April 2003; and
Lowanna (NSW) in October 2003.

In the case of Glenorchy, the licence was handed back to Australia Post when the licensee was unable to find another party willing to take it over on assignment. In Lowanna, the former licensee ceased to operate and effectively abandoned the licence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 February 2004:

question.para: (a) Does Australia Post intend to continue paying public liability insurance premiums for community postal agents and community mail agents; if so, will Australia Post call for a public tender for this policy; and (b) at present, which insurance broker and/or company provides this insurance.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice received from Australia Post:

answer.para: (a) & (b) Yes. Community Postal/Mail Agents are primarily focused on providing a service to the community. They are by nature small operations attracting adequate, but not significant, returns to the operator. Under these circumstances Australia Post has found the most efficient and effective method of ensuring these agents are insured against public liability is under one policy held (and paid for) by Australia Post. The low insurance cost involved does not warrant calling for a public tender.
Heath Lambert/SGIO Insurance currently provides this insurance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 February 2004:

question.para: What provision is Australia Post making for mail contractors who find it impossible to source reasonably priced sickness insurance as required under their mail contracts.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice received from Australia Post:

answer.para: Under the terms and conditions of their Agreement, contractors are required to comply with the applicable Worker's Compensation Insurance scheme in the State where the services are being performed. It is up to the contractor to comply with the contractual requirements regarding the mandatory insurance cover.

Australia Post has provided contractors, on a no obligation basis, the details of four insurance providers that are aware of the Australia Post insurance requirements. The names are listed on information circulars and provided to all potential contract tenderers in the “Information Sheet for Tenderers” in the annual tender kit.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What is the status of the Memorandum of Understanding between Australia Post and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) with regard to the screening of both domestic and international mail.
(2) How is this managed in states that have different quarantine requirements, for example, Western Australia and Tasmania.
(3) Is a change required to the communications legislation or AQIS legislation to address this issue.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions. The answers to questions 1 and 2 are based on information received from Australia Post.

answer.para: (1) The Memorandum relates only to international mail. It came into effect on 23 August 2002, and replaced a previous Memorandum signed in 1995. It remains in effect until terminated by any of the three parties (Australia Post, Australian Customs Service and Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service). Any of the three parties can terminate the Memorandum by giving 30 days notice in writing of the intention not to be bound by the Memorandum.
(2) The Memorandum is for international mail only and has no relevance to State based agencies.

(3) The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts is currently exploring what legislative options might be available for the examination and opening of domestic mail items by State based quarantine agencies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 24 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Since 1 July 2002, has the Minister commissioned or is the Minister aware of studies to determine the extent of environment damage caused by acid pollution from the Mount Lyell copper mine entering Macquarie Harbour via the King and Queen Rivers; if so: (a) who conducted these studies; (b) if these studies were conducted by Commonwealth appointees, how were these selected; (c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these studies; (d) when did work on these studies commence and when was it completed; (e) when did the Minister receive these studies; (f) who was consulted during the preparation of these studies and when were they consulted; and (g) what records exist of any meetings undertaken as part of the consultation process for these studies and can a copy of these records be provided; if not why not.
(2) Can a copy be provided of the executive summary and recommendations of any such study funded in whole part by the Commonwealth; if not, why not.

(3) Since 1 July 2002, has the Minister commissioned or is the Minister aware of studies of the impacts on public health caused by acid pollution from the Mount Lyell copper mine entering Macquarie Harbour via the King and Queen Rivers, if so: (a) who conducted these studies; (b) if these studies were conducted by Commonwealth appointees, how were these selected; (c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these studies; (d) when did work on these studies commence and when was it completed; (e) when did the Minister receive these studies; (f) who was consulted during the preparation of these studies and when were they consulted; and (g) what records exist of any meetings undertaken as part of the consultation process for these studies and can a copy of these records be provided; if not why not.
(4) Can a copy be provided of the executive summary and recommendations of any such study funded in whole or part by the Commonwealth; if not why not.

(5) Since 1 July 2002, has the Minister commissioned or is the Minister aware of studies to determine the potential economic impacts of acid pollution from the Mount Lyell copper mine entering Macquarie Harbour via the King and Queen Rivers, if so: (a) who conducted these studies; (b) if these studies were conducted by Commonwealth appointees, how were these selected; (c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of these studies; (d) when did work on these studies commence and when was it completed; (e) when did the Minister receive these studies; (f) who was consulted during the preparation of these studies and when were they consulted; and (g) what records exist of any meetings undertaken as part of the consultation process for these studies and can a copy of these records be provided; if not why not.
(6) Can a copy be provided of the executive summary and recommendations of any such study funded in whole or part by the Commonwealth; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1)-(6) I am not aware of any studies of this nature commissioned since 1 July 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 26 February 2004:

question.para: (1) (a) Which lists of threatened ecological communities have been identified by the Minister for consideration under subsection 185(2) of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999; and
(b) how many threatened ecological communities are included on these lists.

(2) Can a list be provided of the threatened ecological community nominations that have been assessed by the Threatened Species Scientific Committee (TSSC) as not satisfying the listing criteria on the basis the ecological community concerned was not defined at a `national' scale.
(3) When did the Minister receive the advice from the TSSC concerning the nomination of firewood harvesting as a key threatening process under the Act.
(4) How much has the Government spent on measures to directly improve water quality since 1996.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) There are five State/Territory statutory lists that have been identified: namely New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory.

(b) 622, of which 522 are Queensland regional ecosystems, a state based category which breaks the ecological community down to a much finer scale than those of the Commonwealth and other States and Territories.
(2) 22 ecological community nominations have been rejected by the Threatened Species Scientific Committee (TSSC) for not satisfying the listing criteria. They are:
Eucalyptus populnea/Eucalyptus tereticornis Grassy Woodland/Tall Woodland
Eucalyptus melanophloia Grassy Woodland
Coolabah (Eucalyptus yoolabahs)/Blackbox (E. largiflorens) Woodlands of the Northern NSW Wheatbelt and Queensland Brigalow Belt Bioregion
Dry Rainforest of the South East Forest Community
Brogo Wet Vine Forest Community
Bega Dry Grass Forest
Candelo Dry Grass Forest
Robertson Rainforest in New South Wales
New South Wales Southern Highland Shale Woodlands
Austrostipa aristiglumis Grassland of the Liverpool Plains
New England Peppermint Woodland on Basalt
New England Peppermint Woodland on Sediment
Tall Open Forest with a Grassy Understorey on Basalt
Robertson Basalt Tall Open Forest in New South Wales
Cadellia pentastylis (Ooline) associations
Cook's River clay plain scrub forest
Forest Red-gum grassy community
Western Basalt Plains grassland
Northern Plains grassland
Central Gippsland Plains grassland
Semi-evergreen vine-thickets with Bottle tree emergents
Turpentine/Bloodwood tall woodland to open forest
(3) December 2002.
(4) The Australian Government has invested the following amounts in measures to improve water quality since 1996:

entry.para: Coasts and Clean Seas (relevant to water quality)

answer.para: As at 16 April 2004 the amounts below had been approved from the Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) extension for expenditure directly on measures to improve water quality.

para.inline: National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality

answer.para: The National Action Plan (NAP) for Salinity and Water Quality will provide $700 million in Australian Government funding (matched by the States and Territories) to tackle salinity and water quality issues. Some $170 million in Australian Government National Action Plan funds has been approved to date. As this program seeks to achieve integrated outcomes it is not possible to separate out our salinity and water quality investments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 8 March 2004:

question.para: Since the rollout of Employment Services Contract 3 began (in approximately April 2003), how many individuals have been found to be fraudulently claiming the New Start Allowance, Youth Allowance or any other allowance, for example, by claiming benefits when they were already in paid employment.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator Patterson
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Since the commencement of the Employment Services Contract 3 on 1 July 2003, there has been one person convicted of fraudulently claiming Newstart Allowance when they were already in paid employment.

The honourable senator should be aware that Centrelink, in responding to this question, has taken convictions as the criteria for determining whether or not fraud has been involved: to do otherwise would be contrary to the presumption of innocence.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation: Personnel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2693)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 11 March 2004:

question.para: (1) (a) How many personnel are employed within the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO); and (b) at what Australian Public Services (APS) levels are they employed.
(2) (a) How many personnel are employed in the Safety and Radiation Science Unit of ANSTO; and (b) at what APS levels are they employed.
(3) Does this unit have the capability to respond to an accident involving radiological material at an Australian nuclear facility.
(4) Would this capability be the same if there was a major radiological accident outside an Australian nuclear facility.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) As of 29 February 2004, 843 people were employed within ANSTO.

(b) ANSTO does not use APS levels. ANSTO has its own Enterprise Bargaining Agreement which has a series of salary bands specific to the organisation and, accordingly, it is not possible to answer this question in the terms asked.
(2) (a) As of 29 February 2004, 72 people were employed in the Safety and Radiation Science Division of ANSTO.
(b) As noted above, ANSTO does not use APS levels.

(3) ANSTO has a detailed response plan and procedures that would be activated in the event of an accident at Lucas Heights. Staff are well trained and equipped, and regularly participate in simulated emergency exercises.

(4) ANSTO's Safety and Radiation Science Division has trained health physicists and health physics technicians and radiological monitoring equipment that could be made available in the event of an offsite accident involving radioactive material in Australia or overseas. ANSTO also has other radiological analytical and environmental monitoring capabilities that could be employed if the need arose.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 March 2004:

question.para: (1) With reference to the advice provided by the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation (SBS) at the 2003-04 additional estimates hearing of the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee on 16 February 2004 (Hansard transcript, pp 55-56), how many hours of programming did SBS broadcast in languages other than English in 2002 and 2003.
(2) Excluding the program World Watch, how many hours of programming in 2002 and 2003 were broadcast in languages other than English.
(3) How many of these hours were broadcast in prime time.
(4) Of the total number of hours of programming in languages other than English, how many hours were subtitled.
(5) How many hours of subtitled programming were produced by the subtitling department in 2002 and 2003.
(6) How does SBS define what constitutes a broadcast in languages other than English.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: SBS has provided the following advice:
(1) It is assumed that this question relates to SBS Television only. Hours of radio and online broadcasts in languages other than English have not been included.
Hours of programming broadcast in languages other than English.
(2) Hours of programming broadcast in languages other than English excluding WorldWatch.
(3) Hours of programming broadcast in languages other than English in prime time (excluding WorldWatch).

(4) The Pilat data storage system used by SBS does not easily facilitate the retrieval of information to this level of detail. The figures provided below are estimates based on the analysis of 2 sets of weekly data from both 2002 and 2003.
Number of subtitled hours of programming in languages other than English (principal channel only)
(5) Hours of subtitled programming produced by the subtitling department in 2002 and 2003.

(6) The program content is in a language other than English. In a limited number of cases programs which SBS partly re-narrate and partly subtitle (such as the Hitler series) are also counted as being in languages other than English.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 March 2004:

quote.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 2438 (Senate Hansard, 22 March 2004)

question.para: (1) Does the Tasmanian Heritage Council's assurance that the owners `will not undertake any illegal work' mean that all road construction, logging or other works on the north east peninsula of Recherche Bay would be illegal; if not, what would constitute `illegal' work.
(2) What protection is currently afforded the north east peninsula of Recherche Bay under either Tasmanian or Commonwealth legislation.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Tasmanian Heritage Council has advised that no work can be undertaken in respect to road construction or logging until the Tasmanian Recorder of Titles has made a decision on the legality or otherwise of the application for a road into the peninsula. Further interpretation of the phrase `illegal work' should be sought from the Tasmanian Heritage Council.

(2) The Tasmanian Heritage Council has advised that the issue of the proposed declaration of the peninsula as a Heritage Area is presently before the Tasmanian Minister for Tourism, Parks and Heritage, the matter having been delayed owing to changes following the resignation of the Premier. It further advises that the Tasmanian Historic Cultural Heritage Act 1995 requires that the Minister consult with various organisations and individuals and this process is underway, this will take some weeks to complete and provisional protection of key sites has lapsed because of the delays, but it is understood that this protection is to be reinstated.

The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) affords the north east peninsula of Recherche Bay protection from actions that may have a significant impact on matters of national environmental significance. Matters of national environmental significance include (select as appropriate from the following) World Heritage properties, National Heritage places, Ramsar wetlands of international importance, nationally listed threatened species and ecological communities and listed migratory species. The EPBC Act also applies to actions being taken on Commonwealth land, or which may have an impact on Commonwealth land, in which cases the matter protected is the whole environment. There are a number of exceptions to these provisions of the EPBC Act, including actions that are RFA forestry operations undertaken in accordance with a Regional Forest Agreement.

Should the current nomination of this area for the National Heritage List be successful, then actions that are likely to have a significant impact on the National Heritage values for which it was listed (excepting RFA forestry operations), would require my approval as Commonwealth Minister for the Environment and Heritage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, 24 March 2004:

quote.para: With reference to the Government's New Apprenticeships Scheme:

question.para: (1) For the financial years 2000-01 and 2002-03, can a breakdown be provided, by state and electorate, or if electorate details are not available, by state and postcode, of the number of people participating in the scheme.
(2) Since 1 July 2001, what action has the Government taken to encourage people from regional communities to participate in the scheme.
(3) For the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03, what was the cost to the Commonwealth of this action.

(4) For the financial years 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06, what is the projected cost to the Commonwealth of proposed Government action to encourage people from regional communities to participate in the scheme.

(5) For the financial years 2000-01 and 2002-03, can a breakdown be provided, by state and electorate, or if electorate details are not available, by state and postcode, of the number of Indigenous Australians participating in the scheme.
(6) Since 1 July 2001, what action has the Government taken to encourage Indigenous Australians to participate in the scheme.
(7) For the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03, what was the cost to the Commonwealth of this action.

(8) For the financial years 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06, what is the projected cost to the Commonwealth of proposed Government action to encourage Indigenous Australians to participate in the scheme.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Attachment A provides a breakdown of New Apprenticeships commencements by State and postcode for the financial years 2000-01 and 2002-03. This data has been sourced from the Department's Training and Youth Internet Management System (TYIMS) and is not publicly available.
(2) Since 1 July 2001, the Australian Government has acted in three ways to encourage people from regional communities to participate in the New Apprenticeships Incentive Programme.

From 1 January 2003, the Rural and Regional Skill Shortage Incentive has been payable to eligible employers of New Apprentices at the commencement of their New Apprentices training arrangements (subject to the probationary period being fulfilled). Prior to this measure the Rural and Regional Skill Shortage Incentive was paid in respect to the progression of New Apprentices from Certificate II to Certificate III or IV qualifications. This change to the programme brought forward the timing of the payment of this incentive as well as significantly increasing the number of non-metropolitan employers who are eligible to receive it.

From 1 July 2003, eligible New Apprentices who move away from home are entitled to receive a second year of Living Away From Home Allowance. The allowance paid during the second year is half the rate of the entitlement for the first year. This means that an eligible New Apprentice receives $77.17 per week for the first year and a further $38.59 for the second year. While the allowance is not restricted to New Apprentices from regional communities it provides valuable assistance to New Apprentices moving to, from and between these communities.

As a result of the third tender round for New Apprenticeships Centres (commencing on 1 July 2003), employers and people looking for training will have greater access to more outlets - these have increased from around 300 to around 500. Employers in rural and regional centres will benefit especially from having better access to New Apprenticeships Support Services in their local area as the number of sites has been expanded to 333.
(3) The timing of the Government's actions meant that there was no additional cost in 2001-02.
The change to the Rural and Regional Skill Shortage Incentive from 1 January 2003 cost the Government an additional $546,800.

(4) The Australian Government will continue to pay the Living Away from Home Allowance to eligible New Apprentices for their first and second years. It is not possible to ascertain what proportion of this expenditure will relate to people from regional communities. On a national basis the projected costs for Living Away From Home Allowance are:
Living Away From Home Allowance

The Rural and Regional Skill Shortage Incentive will continue to be paid into the future. The following costs include the cost of phasing out the incentive paid at the progression point of a New Apprentice's training.
Rural and Regional Skill Shortage Incentive

(5) Attachment B provides a breakdown of New Apprenticeships commencements for Indigenous Australians by State and postcode for the financial years 2000-01 and 2002-03. This data has been sourced from the Department's Training and Youth Internet Management System (TYIMS) and is not publicly available.

(6) A national Vocational Education and Training strategy, Partners in a Learning Culture 2000-2005, is in place which seeks to address the needs of Indigenous Australians and the barriers they face. An implementation plan in the form of a Blueprint, was endorsed by Australian Government and State and Territory Ministers in 2000. Commitments relevant to New Apprenticeships are:
expanding New Apprenticeship opportunities for Indigenous people;
marketing higher level courses, apprenticeships and traineeships to Indigenous people; and
increasing student support services for Indigenous students doing higher level VET courses, apprenticeships and traineeships.

New Apprenticeships Centres play an important role in ensuring that opportunities to participate in New Apprenticeships are available to Indigenous Australians and that they are aware of the range of options available. It is also important that support provided to Indigenous Australians and their employers during a New Apprenticeship is culturally sensitive and sufficient to assist them in successfully completing a New Apprenticeship.

To assist in achieving these objectives the government has introduced a Key Performance Indicator which includes measuring the participation of Indigenous Australians in New Apprenticeships and the types of qualifications Indigenous Australians are pursuing.

(7) There is no additional cost to the Government as the Government's actions to encourage Indigenous Australians to participate in New Apprenticeships are incorporated in the New Apprenticeships Support Services contract 2003 - 2006.

(8) There is no additional cost to the Government as the Government's actions to encourage Indigenous Australians to participate in New Apprenticeships are incorporated in the New Apprenticeships Support Services contract 2003 - 2006.
