talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: (1) For each of the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03 and for 2003-04 to date: what representations has the Minister and/or the Government received from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, native title representative bodies, state governments, the mining industry and other organisations or industries expressing concern about the inadequacy of funding for native title representative bodies' statutory functions.
(2) How has the Minister and the Government responded to these representations.
(3) What concerns have been expressed by the Federal Court of Australia about the level of funding available to native title representative bodies to undertake statutory functions.
(4) How has the Minister and the Government responded to these concerns.

(5) For each of the financial years 2001-02 and 2002-03 and for 2003-04 to date, have any native title representative bodies been forced to withdraw from participation in any native title proceedings due to inadequate funding; if so, can details be provided, including the names of the native title representative bodies, the name and nature of the proceedings, the reasons for withdrawing and the date of withdrawal.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services (ATSIS) has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Representations regarding the adequacy of Native Title Representative Body (NTRB) funding received by the Minister and/or the Government are shown in Table 1 below.
`Representations' was taken to mean written correspondence.

Searches of representations received by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and/or the Government were confined to searches of representations received by: the Attorney-General, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, the Attorney-General's Department, and ATSIS.

It was assumed that representations received by other Ministers, Departments and Commonwealth agencies during the relevant period would have been referred to one or more of the aforementioned given that:
the Attorney-General and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous affairs are, between them, responsible for administering the Native Title Act 1993 (NTA);
the Attorney-General's Department is responsible for providing advice to the Attorney-General and the Government about the formulation and implementation of native title policy; and
ATSIS is responsible for advising the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs on those parts of the NTA administered by the Minister and for administering NTRB funding.

The search of representations received by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and ATSIS was confined to a search of representations processed through ATSIS' Ministerial Unit, on the basis of advice from ATSIS that:
relevant representations addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs could reasonably be assumed to have been processed in this way; and

a separate search of ATSIS files that might conceivably contain relevant representations would not have been possible in the time available without adversely affecting the work of ATSIS' Native Title and Land Rights Branch.
Representations included in Table 1 below do not include:
representations dealing with operational funding for particular NTRBs; or
representations dealing with funding support for NTRBs other than in connection with NTRB's statutory functions.
Representations break down as follows:
Table 1

entry.para: Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner
Other organisations and industries (community based organisations)

answer.para: (2) The Government has noted the various concerns expressed about the adequacy of NTRB funding levels. In recognition of the need to provide adequate resourcing to all elements of the native title system, in the 2001-02 Budget the Government committed an additional $86 million to the native title system as a whole, including supplementary funding to support NTRBs. The additional funding spanned four years and was designed to create better, more sustainable native title outcomes and, in particular, to meet two objectives:
the establishment of instructive legal precedents; and
speedier resolution of native title applications.

As part of this package and to promote the ongoing effectiveness of the native title system, the Government established the Native Title Coordination Committee (NTCC). The NTCC is chaired by the Attorney-General's Department and comprises representatives from relevant Australian Government agencies, including ATSIS. The NTCC oversees the performance and administration of the system, including those issues directly affecting NTRBs.
Additional funding for the native title system—support to NTRBs
Twenty per cent ($17.4 million) of the additional funding was directed to ATSIC over four years for:
NTRB capacity building (as the review process which led to the allocation of these funds identified this as the highest priority for NTRBs); and
facilitation of a more strategic approach to the prioritisation of claims by providing funding to assist the progress of key claims.
NTRBs receive the greatest proportion of overall funding provided by the Government and, in real terms, receive more funding now than ever before.
Improving NTRB resource allocation

Apart from issues of funding, the Government is considering how to ensure that existing resources are appropriately prioritised to improve NTRB's effectiveness. To this end, the Government recently commissioned a report (the Miller Report) to examine, among other things, whether mechanisms for distributing funds to NTRBs could be improved. The report suggested a new methodology for allocating resources which should be tied to outcomes. Moves are underway to implement this outputs/outcome based funding framework for the NTRB system, in order to provide for more effective NTRB performance and better prioritisation of resources.

While the Government does not directly fund Prescribed Bodies Corporate (PBCs), PBCs are able to access limited support through NTRBs. The issue of what funding and other resources PBCs may require is being considered by Government.

(3) NTRBs have informed the Federal Court of Australia (the Federal Court) that the combination of the sheer range and volume of activities which they are required to perform or be involved in under the NTA and insufficient resources to meet these demands is necessitating a focus only on the most urgent of matters. Such concerns have been expressed at Federal Court User Group Meetings. In specific cases the Federal Court has been provided with affidavits by NTRBs regarding funding for their native title functions in response to NTRB failure to comply with procedural orders of the Federal Court.
The Federal Court is a member of the NTCC and has brought these experiences to the NTCC's work in monitoring the native title system.
(4) See answer to question 2.

(5) Occasions upon which NTRBs assert that they have been forced to withdraw from participation in native title proceedings due to inadequate funding, and relevant details, are shown in Table 2 below. This information is based on advice obtained from NTRBs by ATSIS.
`Native title proceedings' was taken to mean Federal Court proceedings.
Table 2

* The Gurang Land Council advised ATSIS that on 15 March 2002, it withdrew as legal representative of the Koa Peoples, who were respondents to a non-claimant native title determination application by Noel Kennedy.

# The Kimberley Land Council advised ATSIS that on 25 February 2004, it withdrew as legal representative of Indigenous respondents and as a respondent in its own right to the Djabera Djabera native title determination application.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: With reference to the recent review of the Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) program facilitated by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services (ATSIS):

question.para: (1) What were the terms of reference.
(2) When did the review commence.
(3) Who undertook the review.
(4) What role did Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Board members play in the review.
(5) When was the review completed.
(6) What did the review cost and can a breakdown of the cost be provided, showing staff, consultancy, production and any other costs.
(7) When was the report of the review presented to the ATSIC Board.
(8) When was the report of the review provided to the Minister.
(9) Was the Minister provided with a copy of a draft review report; if so, when.
(10) What were the main findings of the review.
(11) What were the main recommendations of the review.
(12) Can a copy of the review report be provided; if not, why not.

(13) Did the review outcome inform the view of the then ATSIC/ATSIS Chief Executive Officer, Mr Wayne Gibbons, that the CDEP model is `flawed' and deserving of `fundamental reform', as reported on page 1 of the Australian newspaper of 20 December 2003.
(14) Has the Minister responded to the review; if so, can a copy of the Minister's response be provided; if not, why not.
(15) If the Minister has not responded to the review, does she propose to do so; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services (ATSIS) have provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: With reference to the recent review of the Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) program facilitated by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Services (ATSIS):

answer.para: (1) What were the terms of reference.

quote.para: There has been no formal review of CDEP involving terms of reference and a report. Over the past two years, ATSIC, supported by ATSIS, has been considering its policy on employment including the role performed by CDEP in assisting Indigenous people into training and employment opportunities while also promoting community development.

answer.para: The aim of this policy review was:
to clarify the employment goals being pursued through CDEP;

improve linkages between CDEP and mainstream training, employment and other services (eg the initiatives introduced under the Australians Working Together package—such as the Personal Support Program, Training Account and other Job Network assistance) which CDEP participants may not have enjoyed equal access to in the past;

to support `local jobs for local people' in limited labour market situations by tailoring CDEP to provide Indigenous people with the relevant skills and training to undertake such jobs as are available; and
where there is minimal labour market opportunities, ensuring that CDEP is designed and delivered so as to achieve sustainable community outcomes.
(2) When did the review commence.
See response to Question 1.
(3) Who undertook the review.
See response to Question 1.
(4) What role did Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Board members play in the review.
ATSIC's Economic and Social Participation Board Committee had responsibility for this policy area and for bringing a draft policy for consideration by the ATSIC Board of Commissioners.
(5) When was the review completed.

The new policy in relation to CDEP was endorsed by the ATSIC Board at its March 2004 meeting, entitled Community Development and Employment Program (CD&EP) Policy Statement: “CD&EP; the People's Program” 2004-2006.
(6) What did the review cost and can a breakdown of the cost be provided, showing staff, consultancy, production and any other costs.

See response to Question 1. There were no dedicated program or project costs associated with reviewing ATSIC's policy and no consultants were engaged. Costs to ATSIC and ATSIS were essentially operational and included as part of normal business.
(7) When was the report of the review presented to the ATSIC Board.
See response to Question 5.
(8) When was the report of the review provided to the Minister.
I was provided with a copy of the ATSIC's new CD&EP Policy in late March by ATSIS, following the ATSIC Board of Commissioners March meeting at which the Board endorsed the policy.
(9) Was the Minister provided with a copy of a draft review report; if so, when.
See response to Question 1. There was no such draft report.
(10) What were the main findings of the review.
See response to Question 1. ATSIC's new policy position is reflected in the CD&EP Policy Statement which it has released.
(11) What were the main recommendations of the review.
See response to Question 1. Outcomes are reflected in the ATSIC's new CD&EP Policy Statement.
(12) Can a copy of the review report be provided; if not, why not.
A copy of the ATSIC CD&EP Policy Statement is provided at Attachment A.

(13) Did the review outcome inform the view of the then ATSIC/ATSIS Chief Executive Officer, Mr Wayne Gibbons, that the CDEP model is `flawed' and deserving of `fundamental reform', as reported on page 1 of the Australian newspaper of 20 December 2003.

The ATSIC CD&EP Policy Statement is aimed at recognising and articulating the diversity of positive outcomes from the scheme and its future role in addressing Indigenous disadvantage. It reflects ATSIC's desire to see significantly improved outcomes achieved by CDEP and to clearly articulate the intended impacts of the program.
(14) Has the Minister responded to the review; if so, can a copy of the Minister's response be provided; if not, why not.
No.
(15) If the Minister has not responded to the review, does she propose to do so; if so, when; if not, why not.

The Government on 15 April 2004 announced a package of reforms to Indigenous affairs, including its intention to introduce early legislation relating to the future of ATSIC, together with the mainstreaming of programs previously administered by ATSIS. From 1 July 2004, CDEP will be administered by the federal Employment and Workplace Relations portfolio.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

quote.para: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM (CD & EP) POLICY STATEMENT

answer.para: “CD & EP; the People's Program”

quote.para: The Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) scheme currently is an employment, training and community development initiative involving approximately 36,000 participant places for people who voluntarily forego welfare income support entitlements to participate on the program. In 2002-03 over 56,000 individuals participated in the program nationally.

The CDEP scheme aimed to improve the economic, social and cultural status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In 2003/04, approximately $400m of the total CDEP allocation of $520m will be offset against welfare entitlements.

The CDEP scheme commenced in 1977 in remote Indigenous communities, as an alternative to the payment of passive welfare benefits to individuals, and also as a means of enabling community development. Since then, CDEP has been extended to Indigenous communities and organisations in rural, regional and urban situations throughout Australia where employment and other opportunities have been limited.
CDEP is a highly diverse and devolved program, regionally administered and managed by ATSIS, delivered by approximately 240 community based service providers.

In 2001/02 the expanded outcomes of CDEP were reflected in the program reporting against three ATSIC output groups, acknowledging the broader range of social, cultural and economic outcomes of the program.

Employment forecasts for Indigenous people predict a worsening employment rate for Indigenous people and recognise the important role and contribution that CDEP makes to employment, economic, social and community development outcomes for Indigenous people. CD&EP policy therefore is a key element within the overarching ATSIC Employment Policy 2004-2006 and the program will continue to evolve.
The existing Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) scheme will be known as the Community Development and Employment Program (CD&EP) from 2004-2005.

Nationally, CDEP currently accounts for approximately 25% of Indigenous employment and is also an important means of satisfying mutual obligation requirements, improving social cohesion and building individual and community capacity.

The recent Productivity Commission report “Overcoming Indigenous Disadvantage: Key Indicators 2003 noted that CDEP comprises a significant proportion of Indigenous employment, especially in remote and very remote areas, where it can account for the overwhelming majority of jobs.

Whilst the program promotes the transition of participants to mainstream employment, 65% of current CDEP services are delivered in remote Australia, where labour market opportunities and access to mainstream job network services and training are often limited.

75% of all CDEP participants have undertaken training within work activities, significantly contributing to the objectives of CDEP and the Indigenous Employment Policy, administered by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. 28% of CDEP Indigenous Employment Centre participants transitioned to a recognised job outcome.

CDEP has supported business and enterprise development with over 40% of CDEP activity contributing to economic development, particularly in remote and more remote areas which often have a limited economic base.
The revised CD&EP will continue to support training and employment opportunities and business and economic development opportunities.
The CDEP scheme has been operating for over twenty five years. Notwithstanding several major reviews during this time, CDEP has lacked a clear national ATSIC Policy Statement.

Over recent years, ATSIC has encouraged Regional Councils to strengthen CDEP by taking a proactive role in regional planning, identifying local need, setting regional CDEP policy direction, devising regional strategies, prescribing expected outcomes, applying more tailored performance measures, building regional partnerships, developing program linkages, supporting structural change and improving management and administrative efficiency.

Of the two broad outcomes sought from CDEP, building and maintaining a strong, functional, sustainable socio-cultural-economic base for individuals and communities, and increasing individual access to and participation in the labour market and broader economy, the relative emphasis given to either or both of these is highly dependent on where CDEP has been delivered. This diversity of outcomes has contributed to a lack of clarity of the policy objectives of CDEP in the past.

ATSIC's new Community Development & Employment Program (CD&EP) policy is written with particular values in mind. ATSIC acknowledges that while there is great diversity between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, there are some key values that are shared. These include:
- connection with place and country;
- importance of family;
- recognition of distinctive cultures;
- principles of self management and self determination, and
- cultural traditions and knowledge passed down over generations.

The Board of Commissioners of ATSIC has a mandated responsibility to improve employment, community development, and economic opportunities for all Indigenous people, through policy development and ongoing advocacy and monitoring of the activities and outcomes of ATSIS and other Commonwealth and State agencies.
The Board of Commissioners recognise the central and critical role the CD&EP plays in achieving ATSIC's policy objectives.

ATSIC's CD&EP policy is therefore an important component of ATSIC's overarching Employment, Training and Economic policies, and is a key element of the Indigenous Employment Policy administered by DEWR.
ATSIC's CD&EP policy statement provides the national policy context within which Regional CD&EP policies are to be formulated.
ATSIC's CD&EP policy statement is intended to provide clear, enabling, national policy direction for the CD&E Program from 2004/05 onwards.

Under the CD&E Program, service delivery organisations will manage Community Development and Employment projects which will provide community development, training or employment activities for participants.
THE ATSIC BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS NATIONAL
CD&EP POLICY STATEMENT 2004 -2006

1. The Community Development and Employment Program, CD&EP, is a national program which is a regionally focused, targeted and tailored initiative aimed at improving and developing the economic, social and cultural status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and:
1.1 CD&EP is a critical program element of the proposed ATSIC Board of Commissioner's Employment Policy 2004/2006 and the Government's Indigenous Employment Policy;
1.2 CD&EP is a regionally devolved and managed program, comprising a tailored suite of initiatives, flexibly responsive and relevant to regional environments, needs, aspirations and opportunities;
1.3 The Regional Council Plan is the key mechanism for determining priorities and delivery of CD&EP in each region;
1.4 The Regional Council Plan should demonstrate the relative need for CD&EP initiatives, and be supported by a Regional CD&EP policy addressing local needs;

1.5 The Regional outcomes required of CD&EP will be regionally focussed and directed by the Regional Council Plan and Regional policies and priorities and Community Plans where applicable within a shared responsibility framework;

1.6 The outcomes of each CD&EP project will clearly and directly relate to the performance measures regionally applied to the program, considering regional conditions including labour market and economic opportunities, and social, cultural and community development needs;

1.7 CD&EP funding is recognised and acknowledged as a foundational rather than supplementary funding base, upon which joined up, integrated funding, program delivery and other initiatives from strategic alliances with the private and public sectors should be built;
1.8 CD&EP is a tailored initiative with two broad orientations which are not mutually exclusive and which can be delivered concurrently by a CD&EP service provider;

One, a Sustainable Communities focus - aimed at building and sustaining individual and community social, cultural and economic capital base within an active participation model, in situations where access to labour markets, mainstream economies and employment, training and education services is limited. Sustainable communities activities are intended to foster shared responsibility, individual, family and community wellbeing and build local capacities of leadership; and two,

a Training to Employment focus - aimed at achieving targeted and measurable economic, employment and training outcomes, and building individual and community social, cultural and economic capital, where there is access to viable labour markets, economic opportunities, and availability of employment, training, and education services and facilities. Training to employment activities are intended to contribute and build experience, skills, ability, access and equity to employment opportunities, through preparatory work equipping participants for referral through IECs, Job Network and self- referral to both local and wider labour market employment opportunities.
2. CD&EP is an important means of developing strategic alliances, collaborative partnerships, effective coordination and program linkages, and CD&EP:

2.1 Will demonstrate clear, transparent linkages and articulation with other ATSIC Board of Commissioners policies including those relating to Community Participation Agreements, Municipal and Essential Services, Family Wellbeing, Business Development Funding and others as appropriate;
2.2 Will establish and demonstrate clear linkages, partnerships and relationships with the private sector and with other Commonwealth, State and Local Government policies and programs;
2.3 Will be a key tool in encouraging strategic alliances, cooperative partnerships with the private sector, corporate leaders, non government organisations and other industry groups;
2.4 Will enable and facilitate participation in, and access to mainstream services and entitlements, including training, employment and welfare services, such as job network providers and IECs;

2.5 Will provide access to training for all participants, through accessing other agency funding and services, against formal training needs analyses and training plans and demonstrating effective linkages with training providers.
3. The CD&E Program will be delivered through CD&E projects which will comprise activities that build individual and community social, cultural and economic capital bases.

3.1 CD&EP projects and activities will reflect the Regional Council policies and plan and should feature locally designed strategies and initiatives which contribute to better governance, community cohesion and development, health, family wellbeing and violence intervention, substance abuse prevention, treatment and management;

3.2 CD&EP activities will be culturally appropriate and recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people returning to country, cultural protection, language maintenance, land management, and individual, family, clan and community capacity building and development as important priorities in line with regional priorities and program guidelines;
3.3 CD&EP activities need to be inclusive of, and meet identified needs of women, men and youth and support stronger families;
3.4 CD&EP will support enterprise and economic participation and development, and support business incubation and expansion where possible;

3.5 CD&EP will support host placements with CD&EP enterprises, and with other public and private sector employers by way of formal, time defined contracts with clear agreed employment or other outcomes;

3.6 CD&EP service delivery organisations are encouraged, where possible and appropriate, to become registered training providers and/or group training providers in their own right, and to form linkages with ANTA and other training initiatives.
4. CD&EP Service Providers will demonstrate the highest level service delivery standards.

4.1 CD&EP is to be clearly focused on meeting the needs of, and delivering the required service to the participants and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community in a culturally appropriate manner and demonstrating integrity, fairness and honesty;

4.2 CD&EP service delivery will be via Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander local community controlled organisations that demonstrate the ability to meet performance requirements, cost effectiveness, value for money and economies of scale and funding will not be allocated through a process of tendering;

4.3 CD&EP service delivery organisations should be efficiently and effectively administered, adequately resourced, demonstrating the highest standards of corporate governance, financial accountability and professional project management;

4.4 CD&EP service delivery organisations must develop and maximise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leadership, management, and employment, with leadership, succession, career, training and skills development plans to support local people filling as many local jobs as possible;

4.5 CD&EP service delivery providers will have the option of being funded on a triennial basis, without disadvantage, and with annual funding renewal contingent on an annual review to assess satisfactory financial and operational performance and effectiveness;
4.6 CD&EP will be targeted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, with non Indigenous participation subject to Regional Council policy;
4.7 CD&EP funding is not available to full time secondary students and CD&EP participation should not be used as an incentive to leave school or to not pursue tertiary education;
4.8 CD&EP will support, but not fund, formal school to work traineeships and apprenticeships which are the responsibility of other relevant Commonwealth and State education and training authorities;

4.9 All CD&EP service providers will have a culturally sensitive, reasonable and flexible “no participation no pay” policy. Personal agreements should be signed by the participant and the provider to reflect the activities negotiated and to protect the rights of both parties;
4.10 CD&EP service delivery will be supported by appropriate I.T systems, resources and associated training.
5. CD&EP will have clear Performance Measures and an Evaluation strategy.
5.1 CD&EP performance measures will be regionally determined, demonstrating consistency with the Board of Commissioner's national CD&EP policy;

5.2 ATSIS will consolidate all regional reports into a national annual evaluation report which will be provided to ATSIC Board of Commissioners and Regional Councils and will provide the basis for the CD&EP outcomes reporting;

5.3 ATSIS will monitor, evaluate and report to ATSIC and other agencies on CD&EP performance by CD&EP service provider, by region and against regional performance measures, Whole of Government evaluation criteria and the Productivity Commission's Indigenous Disadvantage reporting framework.
6. ATSIC Advocacy and Influence.

6.1 ATSIC Board of Commissioners will advocate and influence Government and private sector policies concerning economic development, employment and training for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by way of engagement with Ministers at all levels of Government, and executives of Non-Government Organisations, Industry and the Private Sector as appropriate;

6.2 ATSIC Board of Commissioners will actively monitor and influence other relevant policies, programs and legislation which impact on CD&EP for eg. Social Security, Youth, Health, Family Wellbeing, Law and Justice, Land Rights, Land Acquisition and Land Management, Business Funding and Education;
The ATSIC Board of Commissioners will review this policy annually.
(Policy approved by ATSIC Board, Decision No 3604, Meeting No.84, March 2004)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 29 March 2004:

question.para: (1) For each regional television licensee: (a) how has the licensee complied with the amended licence conditions for aggregated markets; and (b) when did the licensee begin compliant broadcasting.
(2) How is the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) ensuring that licensees comply with their licence conditions.
(3) Have any investigations of compliance with the conditions been undertaken.

(4) In relation to regional and remote broadcasters outside the four aggregated markets, the ABA has advised that it `will continue to keep the situation under review and investigate further if and when appropriate. A decision on these investigations will be taken late next year, when the ABA has had an opportunity to review the matter': has a decision on these investigations been made; if not, why not.
(5) What action does the ABA intend to take to ensure that licensees broadcast matters of local significance.

(6) (a) Is it a requirement that local news be produced at local stations using local staff; and (b) is the ABA aware of any licensees producing local news which is presented by staff located outside the local market at which the local news is aimed.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Broadcasting Services (Additional Television Licence Condition) Notice 7 April 2003 (the licence condition) requires that each licensee subject to the condition must broadcast a minimum of 90 points per week of material of local significance, and a minimum of 720 points of material averaged over a six week timing period. Points accrue on the basis of 2 points per minute for local news and 1 point per minute for most other types of local content, excluding paid advertising.

Licensees are required to provide mandatory compliance reports to the ABA every 6 months. The first report is due within 30 days of 30 June 2004. The ABA understands that licensees have adopted a range of programming strategies for meeting the condition.
(b) Licensees' obligations under the condition and the mandatory reporting requirement came into effect on 1 February 2004.
(2) Licensees are required to provide mandatory compliance reports to the ABA every 6 months. The first report is due within 30 days of 30 June 2004.

Licensees must also keep records of the material broadcast to substantiate the type and amount of local content broadcast. This material is to be provided on request to the ABA. The ABA will utilise licensees' mandatory reports and other records of broadcast material when reviewing and auditing licensees' compliance with the licence condition.

I am advised that the ABA has informally requested and received information from the licensees about the type and duration of local content material being broadcast to satisfy the condition. The ABA will monitor any complaints received.

(4) I am advised that advice is currently being prepared for the ABA regarding the appropriate coverage of matters of local significance in regional and remote licence areas outside the four mainland aggregated markets. It is anticipated that the ABA will be in a position to report on this stage of its investigation in mid 2004.
(5) Please refer to the answer provided to part (2).

(6) (a) No. The condition requires that licensees broadcast a minimum amount of material of local significance. Material of local significance is defined in section 6(1) of the licence condition as follows:
“6(1) Material that is broadcast to a local area is material of local significance if it relates directly to:
(a) the local area; or
(b) the licensee's licence area.”

In addition to this definition, Schedule 3 to the licence condition provides extensive explanatory comments about what constitutes material of local significance, with clause 3.3 of the explanatory comments noting that: Most material of local significance is likely to be collected and prepared in the local area, using reporters and other resources located in the area. It is less likely that material prepared outside the local area, and distributed in a similar generic form to several licensees, will have an adequate local emphasis for this notice.
The explanatory comments provide a list of non-exhaustive examples of material that may be considered to be of local significance, including:
material that deals with the effects in the area of an event that occurs elsewhere;
material that deals with people, organisations, events or issues that are of particular interest to people in the area, in a way that focuses on the interests of people in the area;
material about a sporting event that involves a team from the area;
material about a sporting event that involves a team from a nearby area, whose principal support base includes the area, or a significant part of the area;
material about market conditions that closely affect a major business activity in the area, such as prices of a commodity in an area where that commodity is produced on a significant scale;
material about an individual in whom people in the area are particularly interested because of an association with the area, such as the individual's having grown up, or lived, in the area.
(b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What selection criteria were used by the team evaluating the tenders for the review.
(2) On what basis was Phillips Fox selected to conduct the review.
(3) (a) Who were the members of the selection team; and (b) what were their qualifications.
(4) Can a copy of the management plan be provided.
(5) Have the submissions to the review closed; if not, when will they close; if so, can a list be provided of all submitters.
(6) When is the review expected to be finalised.
(7) Will the findings of the review be made public; if so, when; if not, why not.
(8) If a Phillips Fox client makes a submission to the review, does Phillips Fox have to notify the department; if so, can details be provided.
(9) Is Phillips Fox permitted to assist existing clients in relation to submissions during the review period; if so, can details be provided of the circumstances under which this is permitted.
(10) Has Phillips Fox or its subsidiaries provided any assistance to clients in relation to submissions to the review; if so, can details be provided.

(11) (a) What mechanisms are in place for dealing with potential conflicts of interest; and (b) have any actual conflicts of interest been reported to the department since the time of tender; if so, can details be provided.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The tender evaluation was conducted in accordance with a Tender Evaluation Plan approved by the First Assistant Secretary of the Information and Security Law Division of the Attorney-General's Department.

In summary, tenders were evaluated on several levels. First, they were assessed against mandatory criteria, being the level of compliance with the requirements of the Request for Tender and Conflict of Interest. Second, they were evaluated for `technical worth' which included assessment of the proposed approach and methodology; specified personnel and expertise; management arrangements; and past performance. Reference checks were conducted as part of this evaluation. Third, consideration was given to financial assessment of tendered prices. Lastly, a comparative evaluation and assessment was conducted of overall risks and value for money to determine the tender which provided the best value for money to the Department.

(2) The Government is conducting the review of the Digital Agenda reforms. Phillips Fox was selected to conduct independent research and analysis on key aspects of the reforms, the results of which are being considered as part of the Government's review.

Phillips Fox was selected on the basis of the assessment of its tender compared to the other six tenderers in relation to their proposed approach and methodology; the specified personnel that would deliver the required services in terms of their expertise in copyright law, economic analysis and/or developments relating to communications technology; the management infrastructure arrangements perceived necessary to manage and deliver the required services; and their past performance.
(3) (a) and (b) Members of the Tender Evaluation Team from initial planning through to selection of Phillips Fox as preferred tenderer included:

Mr Simon Cordina, (then) Principal Legal Officer, Copyright Law Branch, Attorney-General's Department; and Ms Kylie Browne, (then) Acting General Manager, Intellectual Property Branch, Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts; Both Mr Cordina and Ms Browne are lawyers with many years of specialised experience in copyright law and policy. Mr Paul McIvor, Director of the Attorney-General's Department's Market Testing Unit was involved in the initial Invitations to Register Interest stage in which 11 out of the 14 Expressions of Interest received were selected to participate in the next phase of the procurement process. He was replaced by Mr Geoff Conn, a manager in the Financial Policy and Contracts Section who was involved in settling the Request for Tender and in Tender evaluation. Mr McIvor has a Certificate IV qualification in Government Procurement. At the relevant time Mr Conn had almost completed a Master of Business Administration. Both officers have many years of experience in high level procurement and market testing.

The Tender Evaluation Team recommended that approval be given to enter into negotiations with Phillips Fox to conduct the services proposed under the Request for Tender. This recommendation was endorsed by Mr Peter Ford, First Assistant Secretary of the Information and Security Law Division and approved by Mr Ian Carnell, (then) General Manager, Criminal Justice and Security Group, Attorney-General's Department.

(4) It is assumed that this question relates to the answer given to Question on Notice 2203 that referred to a management plan included by tenderers in their tenders for dealing with any actual or perceived conflicts of interest in connection with provisions of the contract services. The management plan provided by Phillips Fox is at Attachment A.

(5) Phillips Fox asked that submissions be made by 30 September 2003. Submissions made after that date up to 24 October 2003 were accepted and considered. Submissions received by Phillips Fox after 24 October 2003 were provided to the Attorney-General's Department for consideration by the Department in connection with its broader review of the Digital Agenda amendments as they were too late to be considered by Phillips Fox. In relation to the list of submitters, see below answer to question (6).

(6) Phillips Fox has completed the research and analysis of the reforms that they were contracted to conduct. The results of their research and analysis were contained in a report made to the Attorney-General's Department, a copy of which is at Attachment B. A list of parties who made submissions to Phillips Fox is at Appendix C of that report. The Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts are considering the recommendations made in the Phillips Fox report. The timing of the completion of that review has been delayed as implementation of the Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement has higher priority.
(7) The report by Phillips Fox was released on 28 April 2004. When the Government's review of the Copyright Digital Agenda reforms is completed, the findings will be made public.

(8) Phillips Fox specifically agreed that it would not act for any person, or provide any other assistance, in connection with any submission or possible submission to the review, without the Department's prior written consent. No such consent was sought or given.

During contract negotiations Phillips Fox specified a list of their clients with an interest in the proper and efficient operation of Australia's copyright system, and, possibly, an interest in making submissions to the review. In view of this the Department was on notice if any of these clients made a submission and their views were given any preferential status by Phillips Fox. The Department received copies of all submissions made to Phillips Fox. In the Department's view there was no evidence of any bias in the report provided to the Department by Phillips Fox.
(9) Not permitted—see above answer.
(10) The Department has been advised that Phillips Fox did not contribute in any way or assist with any submission.

(11) (a) Phillips Fox complied with the conflict of interest requirements in the RTF and satisfied the Tender Evaluation Team that they could carry out the contracted services independently of stakeholder interests. The contract between Phillips Fox and the Commonwealth contained provisions to deal with any conflicts of interest that `arises or appears likely to arise' during the performance of the contract. Phillips Fox was required to notify the Department in writing if any conflict of interest arose or was likely to arise during the performance of the contract services. This obligation ceased when Phillips Fox provided their report to the Department on 4 February 2004.

(b) No actual conflicts of interest were reported to the Department by Phillips Fox. Phillips Fox notified the Department on three occasions during the term of the contract when they were instructed to provide legal services in relation to various matters concerning aspects of the Copyright Act 1968. The Department considered each of these notifications as they arose. None involved issues that were within the terms of reference for the Phillips Fox consultancy or matters concerning the Copyright Digital Agenda reforms. None of these instructing clients made submissions to Phillips Fox or the Department. In the Department's view there was no conflict of interest in relation to Phillips Fox performing that work and the performance of the contract services.

quote.para: Attachment A
CONFLICT OF INTEREST CRITERIA - PHILLIPS FOX RESPONSE

Phillips Fox is not aware of any circumstances that may give rise to an actual conflict of interest with the Department. However, there are a number of circumstances that may give rise to a perceived conflict of interest with the Department in connection with the provision of the Contract Services.

Philips Fox acts for a number of owners and users of copyright, who have an interest in the proper and efficient operation of Australia's copyright system and, possibly, an interest in making submissions to the review.
[List of relevant Phillips Fox Clients - subject to Legal Professional Privilege]
As far as the firm is aware, Phillips Fox is not the exclusive or sole provider of legal services in respect of copyright or other intellectual property matters to any of these clients.
Phillips Fox is not aware whether any of these clients, or any other clients, currently intend to make a submission to the review.

It is important for the Department to be aware, in addition to this perceived conflict of interest that Phillips Fox operates a library that currently falls within the definition of section 18 of the Copyright Act 1968, which may be affected by any decision, whether as a result of the review or otherwise, to exclude “corporate libraries” from the operation of the Act.

If Phillips Fox is contracted to provide the Contract Services, the firm is prepared to agree not to act for any person, or provide any other assistance, in connection with any submission or possible submission to the review, without the Department's prior written consent.

Further, an important part of managing any of these potential conflicts is the process and methodology to be undertaken in carrying out the Contract Services. In providing the services, Phillips Fox is undertaking research and analysis, identifying issues, receiving and considering submissions and, in the light of those submissions and extensive public consultation, making certain recommendations to the Department. Any final decision on the acceptance or otherwise of those recommendations will be by the Department, with no involvement or influence by Phillips Fox. Further, the Department will be involved in every stage of this transparent and public process, and will have approval on all aspects of the proposed methodology.
Phillips Fox will treat equally all submissions and other material received in the course of the review.

Phillips Fox believes that its involvement with these clients, and its knowledge and understanding of copyright issues as a result, will be invaluable in fulfilling the requirements of the review. Further, if the Department is to engage any contractor with the necessary, relevant experience and industry knowledge, the contractor is likely to have similar possible or perceived conflicts of interests that must be appropriately managed. The way in which Phillips Fox intends to deliver the Contract Services, and its undertaking not to provide assistance to any clients in respect of the view, adequately addresses and properly manages these issues.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Other than Fremantle class patrol vessels, what other classes of Australian naval vessels are able to undertake boarding operations of other vessels when enforcing Australian Commonwealth law.

(2) (a) Can a list be provided showing the class and name of each of the vessels able to undertake these boarding operations; and (b) can these vessels undertake boarding operations where the use of force or lethal force may be expected, or the crew or passengers of the vessel to be boarded are behaving in an overtly hostile manner; if not, which vessels can undertake these boarding operations.

(3) (a) Since 1996, how many boarding operations have been undertaken by naval personnel enforcing Australian Commonwealth law where: the use of force was expected, the use of lethal force was expected, or the crew or passengers of the vessel to be boarded are behaving in an overtly hostile manner; and (b) can a breakdown be provided of each boarding operation showing; (i) the name of the naval vessel involved, (ii) when the boarding occurred, and (iii) the location of the boarding.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) All commissioned Royal Australian Navy (RAN) surface ships.

(2) (a) All commissioned RAN surface ships are required to have a properly trained and drilled boarding organisation on achieving a minimum level of capability after appropriate workup training. A definitive list of vessels that meet the requirements changes frequently as they move through their operating cycles.
(b) Yes, noting that the use of lethal force, other than in self-defence, is subject to special conditions and approval processes.

(3) (a) Nineteen, of which only one boarding during a counter-drug trafficking operation involved the low expectation of using lethal force, whereas the remainder involved an expectation of non-lethal force to overcome belligerent behaviour.
(b)(i), (ii) and (iii)

entry.para: Heard Island and McDonald Island area
Heard Island and McDonald Island area
Heard Island and McDonald Island area
Heard Island and McDonald Island area
Heard Island and McDonald Island area
Heard Island and McDonald Island area

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 30 March 2004:

quote.para: With reference to the $25.6 million of new funding for students with disabilities, announced as part of the funding for Australian schools for the period 2005 to 2008:

question.para: (1) Can a breakdown be provided of that funding, including: (a) details of the programs and/or grants administered by the department; (b) the level of funding provided through these programs and/or grants for the financial years 2000-01 and 2001-02; and (c) if specific projects were funded, for each project, the nature of the project and the level of funding.
(2) (a) How much does this funding exceed indexation of previous funding; and (b) to which programs will these funds be directed.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (2) (a) and (b) The Australian Government has announced $2 billion over 2005-08 for the Literacy, Numeracy and Special Learning Needs (LNLSN) Programme. This includes additional funding of $25.6 million that will be made available to improve the way the Australian Government determines the allocation of funding to education authorities for the Schools Grants element ($21.1 million) and the Non-Government Centre Support element ($4.5 million). These elements of the LNLSN Programme were formerly known as the Strategic Assistance for Improving Student Outcomes (SAISO) Programme and the Special Education - Non-Government Centres (SENGCS) Programme.
The $25.6 million is on top of indexation of the previous level of funding provided under the former SAISO and SENGCS Programmes.
(1) (b) The level of funding provided over 2000-01 and 2001-02 under these programmes that make up the LNSLN Programme from 2005-08 was as follows:

(1) (c) The SAISO and SENGCS programmes are not project based programmes. Under the SAISO Programme, the Australian Government contributes funding to education authorities for educationally disadvantaged students who most require additional assistance. This includes students with disabilities. Education authorities are responsible for determining where the greatest priorities are and to determine appropriate funding amounts to schools.

Under the SENGCS programme, funding is provided to improve the educational opportunities and learning outcomes of children with disabilities who receive services provided by non-government centres. The funding may be targeted to provide learning and development opportunities for children with disabilities who are below school age to prepare them for integration into regular pre-schools or schools; assist school-aged children with severe disabilities by improving their access to educational programmes; or assist children with disabilities in residential care.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Given the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) professed commitment to quality national coverage, why has the ABC in Tasmania not had a full-time journalist working on the 7.30 Report since a staff retirement in December 2003.

(2) Why, following the full-time journalist's retirement, did ABC management change the position to a combined television and radio current affairs position, thereby making it difficult to fill, with the consequence that the ABC in Hobart lost a full-time journalist position.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The ABC has provided the following advice:

(1) The position on The 7.30 Report was not full-time prior to the staff retirement in December 2003. While the person who retired from that role, Judy Tierney, did work for the ABC full-time, she also undertook other duties including being the presenter of Tasmania's Stateline and in 2003, she worked for almost eight weeks on Australian Story.

The new position has responsibility to one program only, The 7.30 Report. The position as Presenter of Stateline has been filled separately. The position on The 7.30 Report has been kept as a part-time role.
(2) There were two current affairs vacancies in Hobart at the end of last year and News and Current Affairs management decided to create a combined radio and television current affairs position.

The position was advertised and a candidate selected and accepted. This candidate later withdrew for personal reasons. A suitable alternative to fill this position could not be found, so two positions were advertised: one full-time position for Radio Current Affairs and another three-day a week position for The 7.30 Report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What, if any, consultative forums were held in relation to the Copyright Digital Agenda Review.
(2) When and where were these forums held.
(3) What was the outcome of each of the forums.
(4) Were the outcomes documented; if so, can a copy of the documentation be provided.
(5) Are any more forums planned; if so, when.
(6) Were the consultative forums advertised; if so, when and can a copy of the advertisements be provided.
(7) Were invitations seeking expressions of interest sent out prior to a decision to hold a consultative forum; if so, to whom were they sent.
(8) Were invitations sent to existing clients of Phillips Fox; if so, can details be provided.

(9) Has any information on the review been forwarded to existing clients by Phillips Fox during the term of the contract; if so, can details be provided including the nature of the correspondence and a copy of the information.
(10) (a) What did the forums costs; (b) who paid for them; and (c) were any sponsorships involved; if so, can details of sponsorships for each forum be provided.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A distinction is drawn between consultative forums planned by the Department and Phillips Fox as part of the performance of the contract and forums participated in by Phillips Fox that were outside contractual requirements. All of the forums that Phillips Fox participated in during the consultative phase of its consultancy are listed in response to question (1). The answers in relation to questions (2) and (10) are confined to only those forums planned by the Department and Phillips Fox.
Consultative forums planned by the Department and Phillips Fox

Phillips Fox convened three roundtable meetings on 5 June 2003 in their Sydney office with leading organisations representing copyright stakeholder interests: Government, Owners/Creators and Users/Industry.

Following the release of the issues papers on 1 August 2003, public consultation forums were held in Melbourne on 14 August 2003 and in Sydney on 4 September 2003. An online forum was held on 9 September 2003 for the benefit of anyone who was unable to attend the Melbourne or Sydney forums.
Other consultative forums

Phillips Fox participated in several events convened by other bodies with an interest in the review during the consultative phase of their consultancy. Participation in such events was not required under the contract with the Department but Phillips Fox considered they provided opportunities for targeted consultation with stakeholders and could assist it in formulating its advice to the Department. None of these events were organised by Phillips Fox or the Department. Phillips Fox did not issue any invitations to those events and did not charge for their participation. As far as the Department is aware, all costs associated with these events were met by the organisers. Phillips Fox gave the Department prior notice of its involvement in all events they participated in and officers of the Department were invited by the respective organisers to attend. Details of these events are set out below. Phillips Fox also gave presentations at various conferences and met with various interested industry bodies during the consultancy to inform those present about the research and analysis it was undertaking. As these were merely for information dissemination and not consultative forums they have not been included in answer to this question.

A forum was hosted by the Australian Centre for Intellectual Property in Agriculture (ACIPA) at Griffith University, Brisbane. The forum was chaired by Matthew Hall, Partner, Phillips Fox and Professor Brad Sherman, Director of ACIPA. It was held in Phillips Fox Brisbane office on 15 August 2003. The forum was to provide an update on the progress of the review and allow interested parties to participate. While the Department was invited to attend, attendance was not considered necessary.

A symposium titled `The Digital Agenda Revisited' was held as part of the Baker & McKenzie Cyberspace Law and Policy Centre of the University of NSW Cyberspace Law and Policy Series 2003. This event was co-hosted by Phillips Fox and the Baker & McKenzie Cyberspace Law and Policy Centre and held in the Phillips Fox Sydney office in Sydney on 21 August 2003. Details of the symposium can be found at the following website: http://www.bakercyberlawcentre.org/ 2003/Digital_Agenda/index.htm. The symposium acted as one of Phillips Fox's Sydney based consultative workshops to assist its advice to the Department. It focussed on public interest concerns about the copyright digital agenda framework. Attendance at this symposium was by invitation determined and issued by the Centre. Attendees included intellectual property lawyers from major Sydney law firms, copyright academics from various universities and other leading copyright stakeholders. Officers from the Department were invited to attend and one officer attended at Departmental expense.

On 28 August 2003 a meeting was convened by the Copyright in Cultural Institutions (CICI) group at the National Museum of Australia in Canberra. Phillips Fox were invited to give a presentation to the meeting and did so at no charge. The purpose of the meeting was for discussion of the issues of particular interest to cultural institutions and provided an opportunity for clarification of concerns for the preparation of stakeholder submissions to Phillips Fox. The meeting was open for attendance by CICI members; that is, representatives dealing with copyright in libraries, archives, galleries and museums from around Australia. The Department was invited to attend the meeting and one officer attended.

(2) In addition to the information provided above, the roundtable meetings on 5 June 2003 were held in a meeting room in the Phillips Fox Sydney office. The Melbourne forum on 14 August 2003 was held in a meeting room in the Phillips Fox Melbourne office. The Sydney forum on 4 September 2003 was held in the Metcalfe Auditorium in the State Library of New South Wales.

(3) The purpose of the roundtable meetings on 5 June 2003 was to meet with a small number of key stakeholder representatives to ensure that any major concerns were included in the issues papers that would form the basis for detailed public consultation. At each meeting those present were able to raise any issues or concerns they had on matters within the terms of reference for the Phillips Fox consultancy.

The public forums held in August and September provided any interested party with an opportunity to comment on issues raised by Phillips Fox in the four issues papers. Issues were discussed under the following headings:
- Libraries, archives and educational copying;
- Carrier and carriage service provider liability;
- All other issues including rights issues, technology protection and other technology issues.

A list of the names of persons who registered to participate in each forum is in Appendix C of the Phillips Fox report. The forums were to assist Phillips Fox in their task of formulating its views on the matters covered by their terms of reference for reporting to the Department. This was the only outcome of the forums.

(4) The only outcomes were the views expressed by persons participating in the forums. No written documentation was made of those views. The Melbourne and Sydney forums were recorded for the purpose of giving Phillips Fox a record of discussion to assist internal consideration of responses to the issues. The recording was not transcribed and was not for further dissemination. Those who participated in the online forum were able to view the comments made by other participants during the forum.
(5) No. Phillips Fox has already reported to the Department.

(6) Interested parties were informed of these consultation forums in each of the issues papers and on both the Phillips Fox and Department's websites. Notification of Public Consultation, including the release of the issues papers and details of the public forums in Melbourne and Sydney and the online public forum, was published in the Australian Financial Review on 8 August 2003 and The Australian on 9 August 2003. A copy of the notification published is at Attachment A. Notification of the forums was made in the June 2003 edition of e-News, the copyright newsletter of the Copyright Law Branch of the Department, which was sent electronically to over 1200 e-mail subscribers.
(7) No. The consultative forums were planned as part of the methodology proposed by Phillips Fox in their Request for Tender and agreed by the Department in the contract with Phillips Fox.

(8) The only consultative forums planned by Phillips Fox and the Department that were by invitation were the stakeholder roundtable meetings held on 5 June 2003. The list of invitees was settled in consultation with the Department. No one invited to attend the roundtable meetings was a client of Phillips Fox.

(9) The Phillips Fox regular IT and e-commerce bulletin in August 2003 focussed on the issues raised in the issues papers. This publication was sent to all regular recipients who are on the mailing list for that bulletin. This includes, but is not limited to, clients of Phillips Fox. The bulletin was also posted on the Phillips Fox website and is generally available. A copy of that bulletin is at Attachment B. Phillips Fox has advised that the only statements that have been made to clients relate to the fact that Phillips Fox had been appointed by the Department to conduct the research and analysis for the review or other information that is on the public record.

(10) (a) and (b) It was agreed between Phillips Fox and the Department that the venue cost of the Melbourne, Sydney and online forums were included in the cost of the consultancy on the basis that they would be hosted in the respective Phillips Fox offices. Additional charges for venue hire were to be incurred only if the number of persons who registered to attend the Melbourne or Sydney forum exceeded the capacity of any meeting room Phillips Fox could offer.
In relation to the Melbourne forum costs incurred by the Department consisted of:
Hire of audio-visual equipment, 1,081
Consultant travel and accommodation costs (not covered by consultancy fee), 1,903
Departmental officers travel costs, 907
Given the number who registered to attend the Sydney forum, an alternative venue was required. The Department met the cost of hosting this forum. Costs incurred by the Department consisted of:
Venue hire, audio visual equipment hire and catering, $3,081
Consultant travel and accommodation costs (not covered by consultancy fee), 809
Departmental officers travel costs, 840
(c) There were no sponsorships for these events.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 31 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In the past 12 months has the department or its agencies used, retained or paid for legal or other services from Phillips Fox Lawyers or any of their subsidiaries; if so: (a) can details of each instance be provided; and (b) as a general overview, what was the nature of the work undertaken.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 30 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Threatened Species Scientific Committee established national conservation priorities for threatened species and ecological communities; if so, can details of the priorities be provided.
(2) Since November 2001, how many regional recovery plans have been prepared for threatened species and ecological communities.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Threatened Species Scientific Committee (The Committee) has considered national priorities for conservation of Australia's threatened species and ecological communities and has recommended a landscape level approach for recovery planning to assist the integration of threatened species recovery into regional planning and investment through the Natural Heritage Trust.

The Committee has also continued to advise on the adoption of recovery plans for threatened species and ecological communities, and these plans identify priority actions for the conservation of these species, particularly the on-ground habitat protection and restoration work being conducted at the regional level.
The Committee has advised the Government on the identification of Australia's biodiversity hotspots, and this identification is informing allocations of funds from the Natural Heritage Trust.
In its advice on the listing of threatened species and ecological communities, the Committee also continues to give guidance on the conservation status of a species.

(2) No regional recovery plans have yet been prepared for all threatened species in a region. Two pilot regional recovery plans are currently being initiated—one in Western Australia and one in South Australia—to test the development of plans that provide for the recovery of all listed threatened species within a region. As well, three recovery plans have been adopted at the regional level for groups of related threatened species and a further 13 such plans are in preparation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 2 April 2004:

quote.para: With reference to the Telecommunications Act 1997, which authorises a carrier to enter a property to install a facility if the facility is `low-impact' with the Telecommunications (Low-impact facilities) Determination 1997 defining what a low impact facility is in relation to several classes of land use (i.e. areas of environmental significance, residential, commercial, industrial and rural): Does the Determination cover publicly-owned recreational areas and areas of heritage significance; if not, will the Government legislate to define what constitutes a low-impact installation in such areas.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Telecommunications (Low-impact Facilities) Determination 1997 (the Determination) identifies the areas in which a facility may be installed, by reference to zoning arrangements under State and Territory planning laws, encompassing all classes of land use, including publicly owned recreational areas and areas of heritage significance.
A facility proposed to be installed in an `area of environmental significance' cannot be a low-impact facility.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 2 April 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the testing undertaken by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) confirmed that the meat found onboard the South Seas 1 in January 2004 was whale meat.
(2) Can an update be provided on the investigation of the master and crew of the SouthSeas 1.

(3) Has the owner or master of the South Seas 1 formally notified the Secretary of the department of an incident involving a whale or other listed species under Part 13 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999; if so, can details of the incident be provided.

(4) If the testing undertaken by the AFP confirms the master and crew of the South Seas 1 killed, treated, had in their possession, and/or imported a whale or a product derived from a whale, will enforcement action be taken against the relevant persons or are they covered by the terms of the amnesty referred to in the December 2000 issue of AFMA News (vol. 4, Issue 8).

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) On 12 February 2004, a brief of evidence in relation to this matter was submitted by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration.
(4) See the answer to Question No. 2 above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 April 2004:

question.para: (1) Have licences been granted to Melbourne Zoo and Taronga Zoo to import elephants from Thailand?
(2) Will these elephants be quarantined on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands; if so, how much will it cost to quarantine nine elephants on the islands for 6 months?
(3) Will the Australian Government share the cost of quarantine with the New Zealand Government?
(4) How much will the Australian Government pay for the quarantine of the elephants on the islands?

(5) Has the importation of elephants from Thailand to Australia been arranged in exchange for Australian native wildlife; if so, what Australian native wildlife will be exported to Thailand in exchange?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. Taronga Zoo and Melbourne Zoo are in the process of submitting applications for import of elephants from Thailand. Once all information has been received, the applications will be assessed under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

(2) An application for quarantine of the elephants for a three month period on the Cocos Islands has been received by the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and is under consideration. All costs associated with any quarantine, if approved, will be met by the applicants.
(3) See answer to (2).
(4) See answer to (2).
